PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware of reports that the Reserve Bank Chief of Bank Supervision, Mr Brian Gray, has slammed the Treasury plan for a buyer beware system of bank regulation, labelling it as `naive conceptually' and `certain to compromise the stability of the financial system'? Is the minister further aware of Mr Gray's comments that the Treasury plan could put Australia's financial system at risk of a major collapse? Given Mr Gray's comments, what are your views on the Treasury plan, or do you think Mr Gray is wrong?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry is referring, I suspect, to a submission made by the Treasury to the Wallis inquiry. A large number of organisations, government and otherwise—250 in all—made submissions to that inquiry. Senator Sherry will be aware that a discussion paper was released last Thursday. He will also be aware that further papers have been called for by the Wallis inquiry from people who wish to make further submissions and comments. So I think what Senator Sherry is referring to is the material that has been delivered to the Wallis inquiry. The public will have a chance to make comments on those submissions.

ANSWER.PARA: The government, when in receipt of the recommendations from the Wallis inquiry after March 30, will then consider what position it proposes to take on the recommendations which have been put forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Was Treasury's submission cleared or sighted by the Treasurer prior to its being submitted? Would the move to a buyer beware system of bank regulation lead to depositors demanding higher interest rates on what would become riskier banking deposit investments? Would not higher depositor rates lead to higher lending rates and, therefore, to an increase in home loan mortgage rates?

—I am amazed that Senator Sherry is raising the issue of interest rates, having been in a government which presided over record interest rates. For Senator Sherry to stand up in this parliament and express concern about the level of interest rates is absurd. The Wallis inquiry—
—You haven't got a clue.
—Order!

—Senator Carr is here, back from his efforts in Victoria. Not a good weekend for you. The government will be responding to the recommendations of the Wallis inquiry after those recommendations are released in March.

—My question is also addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, you will be aware of the tremendous benefit that Australian families are enjoying as a result of the low interest rate policy of the coalition government after 13 years of neglect by Labor. Have the government's efforts to rein in Labor's budget deficit blowout contributed to this good interest rate environment? Is it important, minister, that the whole budget be passed to secure the full interest rate benefit for Australian families and businesses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to hear another question being asked on the interest rate issue, one which shows the continuing concern.
—You can answer this one, can you?
—On this side of the parliament about interest rates of the levels.
—You don't need to waffle this time, Rod.
—Order!

—I know it hurts the Labor Party for us to be talking about the interest rate levels. I remind senators opposite that when they were in office and when the election was called home loan interest rates were in the order of 10.5 per cent. Now they are 8¾ per cent. For the family who has an average mortgage in the order of $100,000 this has meant an interest rate benefit of over $140 a month. Some loans are at 8 per cent or less, the lowest rates in two decades. This is a tremendous benefit for Australian families, a benefit which the proven fiscal failures opposite continue to oppose and, with their efforts in the Senate, try to put at risk.

ANSWER.PARA: It cannot be stressed too much the important role that responsible fiscal policy plays in helping to take the pressure off interest rates. The government's policy to balance the books over three years and get government debt down is an important aspect of its policies in continuing to take pressure off interest rates. The Labor Party has no idea what to do in relation to policy or, indeed, any other thing. All we get—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is rubbish, total and utter rubbish!
—Senator Cook!

—Don't you love him? Don't you really love Peter Cook? Every time someone forgets the policy failures of the Labor government, Senator Cook yells out and reminds us all. He was one of the senior ministers in the Keating Labor government which presided over record interest rates which absolutely devastated Australian families and business.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Cook, I am glad that you raised that issue and you bought into this debate. Under your government, home loan interest rates reached a record verging towards 17 per cent, which was pretty horrifying for most Australian families. The Labor Party, in its last five bad budgets, spent—

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we go again.
—Listen to this figure, Senator Carr. You might actually learn something.
—We have heard it three times before.

—It has not registered; that is the problem. The Labor Party, in its last five budgets, had an excess of expenditure over revenue raising of close to $70 billion. That is what you ran up. All those Keating ministers who lit up the front bench of the Labor Party must take a heavy responsibility for that effort—not a voice was raised in protest.

ANSWER.PARA: It is important because the current leader of the Labor Party—I am not talking about the putative leader, former Senator Evans, or Mr Crean—Mr Beazley said that a few billion dollars is not going to make a difference on the interest rate front. That is what he said. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Minister, could you tell us why it is important that the whole budget be passed to secure the interest rate benefits to families and small businesses?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections from the opposition.

—Thank you, Madam President. We have seen the absolutely unedifying sight in this chamber of Labor reverting to its old habits of high spending and trying to force the government to raise taxes and to raise debt. What we want and expect in this chamber is for this budget to be passed in full. The sort of performance that we have seen in the last week is one where Senator Faulkner waltzed in here and casually proposed—would you believe—a further billion dollars on the appropriation bills. It is the same old Labor Party. It has learnt nothing. We urge this Senate to make sure that this budget is passed and in full.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, why did the Prime Minister refuse to meet with Hong Kong senior elected politician, Mr Martin Lee Chu‐Ming, for talks on the future of democracy in Hong Kong? Is it a fact that the Prime Minister in a letter to Mr Lee claimed that he was too busy to meet with him, but offered instead to meet with him at a cocktail party in Canberra at a time when Mr Lee would be in New Zealand? What is the reason for this extraordinary and comic discourtesy, and how can it but be interpreted as a diminution in Australia's commitment to democratic reform in Hong Kong?

—If the Prime Minister met every senior politician visiting Canberra who sought to meet with him he would do nothing more than attend meetings. As you would know, Senator Schacht, because of your interest in this matter, Martin Lee, a senior Hong Kong politician, is due to meet with the foreign minister, Mr Downer, and Mr Ruddock, the immigration minister, on matters that relate to that. It was not possible for the Prime Minister to fit him into his program. Nevertheless,—
—Oh, yes. Pull the other one.
—the Prime Minister indicated that he expected to meet him at a certain cocktail party. As I understand it—
—When was that said?

—No, it was announced by Martin Lee afterwards that he would not be able to attend. If you are trying to insinuate some deliberate attempt to avoid meeting him, that is unfounded, Senator. You would concede, I think, that Mr Howard is on the record as saying he would be pleased to meet with Martin Lee at the cocktail party and was looking forward to the discussions that would ensue at that time.

—I ask a supplementary question. Minister, do you concede that Mr Martin Lee has been the most prominent and vigorous defender of democratic reform in Hong Kong for many years now and should be given the courtesy of a prime ministerial meeting in view of the change in Hong Kong's status starting in July next year?
—I concede that he is a senior politician in Hong Kong—
—Senior elected politician.

—elected politician in Hong Kong who has sought democratic rights. I have been pleased to meet with him in the past, as no doubt you have, Senator. On this occasion, the Prime Minister was unable to fit him into his program. That is just a fact of life. I would have thought that you would be pleased to hear me confirm that two senior ministers of this government will be formally meeting with him during his visit here. As I said, the Prime Minister was expecting to meet him at a cocktail party. Unfortunately, it is Mr Lee's choice not to attend that cocktail party.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Has Telstra responded to claims made by Senator Kim Carr and Senator Chris Schacht on 6 November in this chamber that our national carrier had established a war room to manage public opinion and manipulate the media during the Telstra privatisation debate? Would the minister inform the Senate what Telstra's response has been to these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, the fact is that I thought Senator Carr might have had the courage to be addressing questions to this side of the chamber but, given that he has not, I think it is important that the parliament and the Australian electorate are made aware of the damage which Senator Carr is doing to one of Australia's greatest institutions. What Mr Blount, as the Chief Executive Officer of Telstra, says in writing to Senator Carr is:

ANSWER.PARA: Your most recent comments have the ability to severely damage the brand—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this correct this time?
—Why didn't you give it to Paul Calvert to ask?
—Order! There are too many opposition senators interjecting, and it is disorderly to do so.
—As I think we would all understand, the reputation of Telstra and its ability to compete both domestically and offshore are critically important, and that is why when Mr Blount says:

ANSWER.PARA: Your most recent comments have the ability to severely damage the brand and reputation of Telstra in a competitive environment—
We all ought to take this problem very seriously. Mr Blount goes on to say:

I have now had the opportunity to read the press release and the Hansard pinks. There are many statements which are simply incorrect, untrue or deliberately misleading. I do not propose to take issue with all of them, but I am obliged to comment on some of the key statements.
The first one, he says:
This is simply untrue.
Again he says:
You claim that Telstra is driven by the government's plans for privatisation. This again is distorting its long term business plan. This again is far from the fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —True! True! True again!

—You would not know the difference between fact and fiction. It is one thing to try to unload Andrew Theophanous by leaking to the Sunday Age , as you did yesterday. This has to be the most bitter and divisive factional struggle we have ever seen in this country. I can understand why Senator Robert Ray and Senator Conroy wanted to raise Emily's list in the national executive recently. It is simply because Senator Carr is doing untold damage, not just to your party—that does not particularly trouble us—but he is certainly doing enormous damage to one of Australia's greatest institutions. You get to the point where Glenn Milne quotes one senior Victorian MP as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: Kim Carr is promoting biological women, and the difference between a biological woman and a quality woman who has the capacity to get into a Federal Labor Cabinet is profound.

I presume that was Senator Robert Ray, and it is not quite right because you do not have to be too good to get into a federal Labor shadow cabinet. But, if we are talking about this crowd ever coming back into government, it is critically important that people who make the sorts of irresponsible statements that Senator Carr has been making be brought into line. If you are going to have factional disputes, if you are going to have knock down drag outs, you ought to be prepared to stand up and say, `This is not acceptable', because Telstra's reputation is important—

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I take a point of order, Madam President?
—Order! Senator Alston, I draw your attention to the question.
—Madam President, that was the point I was about to make. You are making it, so I will regain my seat.
—Senator Alston, I draw your attention to the question that you were asked.

—Madam President, I am delighted that you have done that. The question was: has Telstra responded to claims made by Senator Kim Carr? I am answering that in spades, and I am going on to point out the significance. This is not just an academic discussion or debate; Mr Blount was driven to do this because he felt he could not cop it any longer. He was not going to stand by and see Telstra damaged by Senator Carr.

ANSWER.PARA: You ought to have the courage to recognise that this is not just damaging your party and all the factions and breakaway groups that we now see emerging in Victoria—because Martin Ferguson won't put up with it; he wants a more inclusive approach—but that is not our problem, that is not Australia's problem: Australia's problem is that you have blokes like this running around prepared to say or do anything to promote factional alliance. In other words, he does not care whether it is true or not; he is just interested in whether he can spin out something that might haul in a few suckers. He will play the hard line game. Now I know that is not working; it is blowing up in his face. But it cannot be allowed to reflect on major Australian companies. You are constantly fond of saying that this is a government‐owned enterprise, but you ought to have the guts to defend it; you ought to be prepared to do something constructive. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given Telstra's response, does Telstra identify the potential damage to its reputation as a result of the wild claims of Senator Carr and Senator Schacht?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I might say also that Mr Blount expresses deep disappointment that Senator Carr made no attempt to contact any Telstra people, from either the corporate area or those involved with the document tabled. This goes very much to the heart of the integrity of the criticism. Run your ideological lines; get out there as much as you like and bag any form of privatisation, even though you privatised everything in sight when you were in government, but at least have the decency to run an argument that is factually related—and that is the very sort of thing Senator Carr is not prepared to do. He is using Telstra as a pawn in a factional game. He is using Telstra to somehow be able to say, `Support me and I will defend you against all these horrible things that are happening.'

ANSWER.PARA: And you, Senator Robert Ray, ought to have the courage to say, `Enough is enough'. Get your acolyte to do the job on the federal executive; that is fine. Get rid of him or leave him to Martin Ferguson, that is okay, but at the same time recognise that you cannot walk away from the damage to Telstra. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Parer representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the minister's attention been drawn to reports that Sunraysia citrus farmers have threatened to burn half a million citrus trees as a consequence of the federal government's failure to implement a rescue package for their industry? What is the potential impact of this action on the long‐term capacity of the region to manage the change from the harvesting of valencia oranges to that of navel oranges? What support has the government provided to farmers in this region who are now faced with the threat of bumper orange crops from Brazil and Florida?

—I thank Senator Bob Collins for his question. I did see the article in the paper about the valencia oranges. I will refer the detail of your question to Minister Anderson because I do not have a full brief on it, but I think it is—
—Why haven't you got a brief? You have come unprepared.
—I think it is a very important question. I will refer it, Senator Collins, and come back after question time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, on 27 November on the John Laws program Mr Laws put to you:

QUESTION.PARA: So really they—
that is, new migrants—
can get everything but the dole?
You replied:
That's essentially it, yes. I suppose in a rough way of speaking that's pretty right.

Minister, were you not very loose with the truth? Is it not true that the Senate voted to extend from six months to two years the waiting period for unemployment benefits, sickness benefits and the youth training allowance? Is it not true that the Senate approved the vast bulk of $549 million worth of savings that were you seeking with these extensions and that to claim that you have lost $400 million of this is a deliberate and blatant untruth? Is this not, in a very rough way of speaking, designed to further the politics of division, which your government is pursuing in a very cold and calculated manner? Are you not just adding new migrants to your list of scapegoats to bash?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of Senator Kernot's question is that, effectively, the extension from six months to two years that the Senate passed last week relates to employment type payments.
—It was more than that. You just made it clear. You were not even here.
—Order! Senator Bolkus!
—The newstart allowance and the youth training allowance—
—She was not here handling the bill. She would not know a bit more about it.
—Order! Senator Bolkus!
—Well, that is the truth. She was not here handling the bill.
—Order! Senator Bolkus!

—The major payments—in fact, the only really substantial payments—that have been passed, that have been extended to two years, all have implications for people in employment or unemployment. That is the basis on which I answered that question, and I was quite accurate. I cannot really be sure whether you are wilful, Senator Kernot, or just plain ignorant. I would like to think that it is the latter. I give you the benefit of the doubt.

ANSWER.PARA: I have with me a briefing note from my department as to the composition of the $400 million. If you like, I will acknowledge that it is actually $399.719 million, so it is as near as makes no difference to $400 million. I hope you accept that in round figures it is accurate.

The lost savings from the amendments to the bill are comprised of the following. Lost savings from the change in the start date from 1 April 1996 to the date of royal assent, assumed to be 1 January, for the newstart allowance, sickness allowance and youth training allowance total $124.9 million over the four years. Included in this figure are the savings lost from the non-exemption of partners, which cannot be singled out from the total.

When it comes to the second item, it is a question of special benefit. By not applying a 104‐week waiting period to special benefit, it is estimated by the department that 30 per cent of those covered by the 104‐week waiting period for the newstart allowance, sickness allowance and youth training allowance will be granted special benefit during their waiting period at an additional cost of $65.3 million over the four years.

The third item relates to the parenting allowance. The loss of savings by not extending the parenting allowance 26-week newly arrived residents waiting period to 104 weeks will be $90.7 million over the four years.

Finally, the fourth item on the briefing note is entitled `Other payments and entitlements'. The loss of savings from not applying a 104-week waiting period to the proposed other payments and entitlements totals $123.7 million over the four years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that answer. Firstly, I would like her to table the briefing note from which she was reading so I can make an examination of her claims. Secondly, as a supplementary question, where did the $200 million figure come from in this wider debate? Thirdly, would you deny that you gave many interviews around the country deliberately giving the impression that the Senate had blocked any changes to benefits for new migrants? Did you not say that there is no wait for the parenting allowance when in fact it is six months? You did not say—did you?—that it has not been extended to Medicare and family payments when it was your express election commitment not to. Would you comment, please, on the last part of my question—that is, this is now the new way politics works in this country by adding people to your list to justify what is wrong with the economy? Who is the next scapegoat you are going to add to this list?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out once again that this was an election commitment which we gave very publicly during the election, although the Labor Party has tried very hard to suggest that we somehow went beyond what we set out in the election. In the document Meeting Our Commitments, which was launched on 15 February by the then shadow Treasurer, we spelt out what we expected to be the savings over three years.

ANSWER.PARA: If Senator Kernot chose to sit down and analyse those figures over three years, would she have stopped to think what that would mean for four years and would she have started to think about how those extra savings were to be found? The savings were not to be only from newstart, the sickness allowance, et cetera.

It is quite clear that, if you did your homework, Senator—and I would be happy to sit down with you and help you do it—we were absolutely up front. We made it clear that, if circumstances changed, special benefits would still be available. We made it clear that Medicare would stay. We made it clear that the minimum family payment would say. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not in your interview.
—Yes, it was.

—My question is directed to Senator Alston, the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the minister aware of agreements negotiated recently in the building and construction industry whereby building workers will receive wage increases of between 21 per cent and 24 per cent over the next three years? Minister, given the government's supposed support for employers and employees and their representatives negotiating their own agreements on wages and working conditions, why is it that the Minister for Industrial Relations and the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism are interfering in the process in an attempt to stop such agreed outcomes in wages being achieved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President—
—Because you are two faced.
—It is about time they had a reshuffle, I think. You really have lost the plot.
—You are.
—Recent economic data from the ABS points to a welcome fall in inflation and moderation in economy wide wage growth.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If you want an answer to the question, you will get it. It is quite clear that, whilst inflation is currently under control, there is no room for complacency on the wage front. The average annualised wage increase per employee in federal enterprise agreements was 5.6 per cent in the June quarter. Despite that, we are seeing increases negotiated in the building industry which are significantly higher than those that prevail elsewhere and which have the capacity to cause significant problems.
—That is what your system asks for.
—Order!

—As I indicated, it is one thing to take the view that inflation is under control in the short term. It is another to ignore the fact that wage pressures can ultimately cause inflation to go in the wrong direction and with them interest rates and the general shape of the Australian economy. That is why it is particularly concerning if we see negotiations and agreements that are reached which are well outside those average levels of increase that operate elsewhere.

ANSWER.PARA: If the average annualised wage increase per employee in federal enterprise agreements is up in the June quarter from the March quarter, then again it ought to be obvious to all that the last thing we want is to have any more break‐outs in this area. And the building industry is notoriously one in which very little regard has been paid—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about executive pay?
—What about executive pay? If you regard executive pay as beyond the pale—and when I see people getting $2.8 million a year, it strikes me that it is very hard to justify that—
—What are you doing there then?

—I do not recall you being able to do much about it in government either, other than to decry it. If you regard that as a wrong, an additional wrong does not make it any more palatable. In the building industry where all these costs—
—Leave the wealthy alone. That is you.

—If you are a shareholder in a company that chooses to overpay its executives and you do not like what it is doing, you can bail out. You do not have to buy those products. But when it comes to building, where quite often the unions have a stranglehold on whether the building process goes ahead at all, the last thing you want is people being held to ransom and management having no choice but to comply with agreements that are well beyond the norm. That is the worry that we have in this particular instance and it is about time you blokes woke up to it.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, the question that was put to you involved, firstly, whether or not you were aware of the increases. It is obvious that you are, but it is obvious also that you do not have much knowledge beyond that. The second part of the question was why are the Minister for Industrial Relations and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy seeking to interfere in a process whereby the employees, the employer and the organisations representing those bodies have actually agreed upon these increases. Why are these ministers interfering contrary to the very principle upon which your workplace relations bill, which was passed only a week or so ago, is based—that is, non‐interference by government in the workplace?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure what you mean by interference but if you mean commenting adversely on wage increases that might be negotiated—that might in the old terminology have been sweetheart deals—that nonetheless have the potential to adversely affect the economy, I would have thought we had the responsibility to do just that, in the very same way that Senator Sherry asked me to comment gratuitously on high management salaries.

ANSWER.PARA: If we are simply to sit on our hands and say, `That is a matter for private negotiation, I do not have a view', then of course you are not showing leadership on the issue. But where we do have deals—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't like the unions and you don't like the building workers. That is the problem.

—Look, at the end of the day you either have to take a position on this or not. If your position is `Whatever the unions can screw out of management is fine by us', then we understand where you are coming from. But if you are not prepared to say, `There is a line beyond which we are prepared to say we do not think that is in the national interest, that they have gone too far', then you ought to be prepared to say it. We are; your not.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. I refer the minister to a response by Dr Wooldridge to a dorothy dix question from the member for Groom on 11 September, and I ask: was the practitioner he referred to as `Jumbo Jet' because he allegedly billed 747 75‐ minute consultations for one patient in one 12‐month period a real person? If so, was this doctor a registered psychiatrist purporting to be performing psychoanalysis? Was this the same or a different practitioner to the one referred to by the minister in the Adelaide press when he referred to an Adelaide psychiatrist who billed 900 consultations through Medicare in a year? Given that any second claim on a given date would automatically trigger a code 162 response from the Medicare computer requiring a letter of explanation from the practitioner, how could such a series of claims occur? Has the alleged practitioner been prosecuted? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Margetts for some advance notice of a detailed question in that I am representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. I am advised by Minister Wooldridge that the case referred to as the `Jumbo Jet' is in fact a real case and the doctor in question is a psychiatrist. The treatment provided to the patient was psychiatric treatment. However, the precise nature of that treatment is not known.

ANSWER.PARA: I am also advised that the minister is not aware of the Adelaide press article you referred to. However, only one practitioner is billing at these levels, but it is not appropriate to comment on the location of that practitioner. And the number of claims varies depending on the time frame being considered.

I am further advised that there is no such thing as an automatic code 162 response from the Medicare computer that requires a letter of explanation from the medical practitioner before Medicare benefits can be paid for the services provided to the same patient by the same practitioner on the same day. Medicare benefits are payable for each of several attendances on the same day by the same medical practitioner provided that subsequent attendances are not a continuation of the initial or earlier attendances.

If the patient account for such services includes the times of each service, Medicare benefits would normally be paid for each service. Only if the times have not been included on the account will the operator not pay benefits for the second consultation claimed and only then would the operator enter the code 162 into the computer to indicate that Medicare benefits had already been paid for that service.

I understand also that the practitioner has not been prosecuted. However, the case has been investigated by the Health Insurance Commission and there is no reason to believe, apparently, that fraudulent claims are being submitted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Madam President. I thank the minister for her answer. I find it amazing to think that the minister for health does not know about the code 162 computer response which generates a letter requiring explanation. I understand that the Medicare schedule book says that subsequent attendances are not a continuation of the earlier attendance. It would be very difficult not to consider three times an hour and a quarter a continuation. Perhaps the minister might like to work out how many hours would be left in the day and how a practitioner could explain that without having to complete a full `please explain' to Medicare. Minister, if the alternative to intensive psychotherapy may be hospitalisation at, say, $600 a day, or even suicide, what is the basis of this decision? Is it not a case of constructing a medical `Dr Wright' to justify cuts to yet another vulnerable community group? (Time expired)

—I think that is a bit of cheap shot, Senator. It really does not become you. Nevertheless, I have given you the advice which I have received on your behalf from Minister Wooldridge. I guess I share the concern of most people that one person could claim so much from Medicare. After all, people who are struggling to pay their taxes and look after their families are also being asked to look after a social security bill of $40 billion per year and meet the claims of the psychiatrist in question. We should all be concerned, I would have thought, at the blow‐out in medical costs that this indicates.

—My question is directed to Senator Vanstone, Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, can you confirm that your department has become aware of a group of departmental employees who attempted to establish a business so that they could submit a tender for an employment placement enterprise anonymously? Do you accept that this would place these employees in a very serious conflict of interest situation and that it would compromise confidential information gained through public sector employment? What assurances can you give Australia's unemployed that details of their private lives will be protected under your new regime of contracting employment services out to private enterprise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for that question. I do not have a brief with me with respect to that matter. I will check what has come in in the last couple of days to see whether I have been advised of the allegations that you raise. I can assure you, Senator, that I will get you a response very quickly on that because I will be particularly interested to see the outcome of any investigation into such allegations. I will come back and give the Senate a reply as soon as is possible.

—I ask a supplementary question. Minister, thank you very much. I must say that I am amazed that the department has not brought this to your attention or briefed you in relation to it. It is an incident that has come to light on the north‐west coast of Tasmania. In a more general sense, what action will you take as minister to ensure that this sort of behaviour is prevented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I do not want to rush to judgment on this. Let's have a look at what has happened and make assessments then as to how to ensure that, if something has happened that should not have, it cannot happen again. I am not going to rush to judgment. I told you that I am unaware of it. I have told you that I will get a brief as soon as I can. Then I will take appropriate action, obviously, and I will bring an answer back to the Senate. That may be the time to ask if it is necessary to have any measures to prevent what you allege has happened from happening again.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Newman. Minister, in the light of newspaper reports in the Australian over the weekend and again this morning, what is the government's policy in relation to encouraging greater representation of women in parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I can certainly say it is not Emily's list, as Senator Alston has already pointed out. We have a track record of excellence in promoting women into parliament, as you would be well aware, Senator. We have proven our commitment. It is not just talk. We have increased the number of women in parliament and we have done it through a technique that is little used in the ALP: one of merit. We seek out talented women, we mentor them, we nurture and encourage them. Then we preselect them and then the people vote for them. It is interesting that in the House of Representatives now there are 18 coalition women as a result of that policy—
—How many?
—Eighteen coalition women now in the House of Representatives—
—How many Labor?

—There are four Labor women. But, Madam President, you would realise also that the Lindsay by‐election gave another example of just how much the people of Australia recognise that we have gone for the merit principle, not quotas. You saw that we had an up‐and‐coming talented woman against a tired Labor man and the people not only said they wanted a woman—our woman—once; they said it twice, with some exasperation, I might say. If you compare the government's policy on the advancement and representation of women in parliament, you only have to look at what the ALP is doing now that the quota has failed.
—What has happened with Langmore resigning?
—Yes, we have the ACT preselection coming up shortly and it will be very interesting to see whether Labor rises to the challenge of preselecting a woman there.

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. Senator Newman was asked very clearly and specifically by Senator Ferguson what the government's policy was in relation to representation of women in parliament.
—Order!

—I suggest to you, Madam President, that it is not in order for her to canvass issues in relation to the ALP, however interesting they may be to her. I ask you, therefore, to confine her remarks to the question that was directed. I suggest to you, Madam President, that, if she strays and talks about the opposition or the Labor Party or the candidate for Fraser or any other matter, then she is clearly out of order and you should rule her out of order.

—Order! The minister should certainly be answering the question, but the number of interjections and the amount of comment from the opposition are a distraction and some ministers are distracted by it. The minister should be answering the question that has been asked and we should be able to hear the answer without interjections.
—Madam President, I do point out to you that I have been answering the question about the government's policy.
—No, you have not!
—Order!

—The problem is that the ALP does not like the comparison with its policy. We could have had a policy of quotas. We chose not to have a policy of quotas. We said that was not a smart way to go and that, anyway, it would rebound on women and that it would not achieve anything. But the ALP said that we knew nothing and they went down the quotas road. So, you see, our policy actually worked: we got women into the House of Representatives. When the Labor Party found their policy did not work, they looked for another—

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Regardless of whether you consider there is a great deal of noise in the chamber, Madam President, clearly Senator Newman is not answering the question that was directed to her. She is canvassing other issues which are out of order. You, Madam President, should call her to order and not allow her to flout your ruling.

—Order! The minister may well have a different view from others as to how the question should be answered. She should be answering the question that was asked. I can see that there may well be differences in the way one person would see it being answered from another.

—The question was: what is the government policy in relation to encouraging greater representation of women in parliament? I have demonstrated, and have been continuing to demonstrate, the differences in methods of getting women into the parliament. One method has succeeded; another method has failed.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Just a minute, Senator Newman. Order!

—It is quite clear that the opposition does not like to hear home truths. Our policy does not require that we import an American idea called Emily's list to somehow succeed in getting women into the parliament where quotas have failed. We think that is just as inadequate a solution as the quotas. We believe that the tried and true way of getting women into parliament is to support them, to mentor them, to nurture them and to preselect them. Then they will be elected by the people because they have been chosen on merit.

BREAK.PARA: There can be nothing more devastating to the opposition than to have it recognised by their own side of politics that they have not been putting up women of merit. It has been a factional issue. It is only the Left trying to have a battle with the Right, as we saw last weekend in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Minister, under what circumstances apart from actually finding a job would you think it appropriate for people who are long-term unemployed to exit case management? Have contracted case managers indicated that there are any particular groups of unemployed people they would like to `terminate'? Has the department made recommendations about what might be appropriate reasons for terminating clients?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for his question. I have a long and detailed brief—if I am thinking of the right one—with respect to the circumstances under which it is appropriate to exit case management. I will have a good look at that and will come back to you with some detail on it. I am happy to provide you with such information as I can. You will understand that we are at the moment in what I would describe as a `transitional phase' between the one‐on‐one case management, which was introduced by your party, the previous government, and which was one of the things of Working Nation that did work, and a system that we would like to introduce where some 90 per cent of our funds will go into the intensive employment assistance—you might describe it as a contract of case management by another name—of those who are either long-term unemployed or at risk of becoming long-term unemployed.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a detailed brief for consideration because, in that transition phase, we will have some people who will have entered case management under the old system and who perhaps have not concluded that case management. There will need to be a sensible alignment as to what to do when the two systems merge into one. I do not see that there are any difficult policy decisions in the sense of differences that there might be between the two major parties, the Democrats or the Independents on this. It is a case of simply considering the complexity—`complexity' is the wrong word because it is a matter of who entered on which dates, what date you shift to a new system and where you put the people who were on the old system. It is not as if it is intellectually difficult; it is `technically messy', if I could explain it to you in that way.

As I have indicated, Senator, one of the things that did work in Working Nation was the recognition by your party that some people need one‐on‐one case management; they need a really significant boost to get them back into the work force. That part of Working Nation worked and that is the part we are building on and expanding. I look forward to your support and that of your colleagues when we seek legislative approval for the changes we want to make. The changes we want to make are basically those which will cash out all of the labour market programs and shift to a system where the majority of assistance—in financial terms and in other terms—goes to people who are either long-term unemployed or at risk of becoming long-term unemployed.

Without wishing to be political about my criticisms of Working Nation, one of the mistakes the previous government made—not intentionally, in my view—was that it did not pay enough attention to those who were at risk of becoming long‐term unemployed. So, what you had happening is that people who were long-term unemployed were put into make‐work schemes in the hope that they would end up in a real job. You and I know the effectiveness of that was not very good: 22 per cent for some programs and up to 30‐something per cent for others. They were very ineffective; they are the programs we are discarding.

During that time they were not considered unemployed. When they came off that program and did not get a job, they went on the short‐term unemployed list. They have started to channel through again—it is a funnelling process. That will always happen unless we devise a scheme to stop people flowing into the long-term unemployed bucket. As to the detail of the question you raised which specifically related to those already in the bucket and already getting contracted case management and the appropriate exit point for them, I will come back to you on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you for that answer. I look forward to receiving the information that you have undertaken to provide as quickly as possible. Can you assure the Senate that, whatever you approve in relation to those terminating events, you will not approve terminating events which serve only to remove the long-term unemployed from case management?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand your question, I would have to say that I find it slightly offensive. You are suggesting that there is a brief that says, `Why don't you just remove these people off the list for no other reason than they are long-term unemployed.' With the greatest respect, I find that a bit rich.

ANSWER.PARA: I have given you a good explanation of what we are doing. I have told you that there are some technicalities in shifting from one system to another. I have told you that I will come back to you with the information, and I will. I will scout through it and see whether I can find a suggestion that long-term unemployed people ought to be cut off the list because of the fact that they are unemployed. That is what the previous government did. They picked out and focused on the long-term unemployed at the expense of those who were at risk of falling into the bucket so that they could churn the people through to make the figures look better. That is something that the previous government did. It is not something that this government is looking to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry Science and Tourism, Senator Parer. Is the minister aware of the significant harm that huge cuts to working and effective R&D and industry assistance programs, such as the early abolition of the ships bounty, will have on industry in Tasmania and Western Australia? Is the minister aware that Premier Richard Court strongly lobbied Prime Minister Howard this weekend on the foolishness of these anti-business measures saying, `We want to make it very clear to the Prime Minister that we don't want to see that five per cent bounty removed while our competitors still have a 10 per cent protection level.' and, I continue the quote, `It is not an even playing field and it will damage our local industry if we have that unfair competition.' Will the minister heed Mr Court's warning on this matter, or at least undertake a cohesive cost/benefit analysis which addresses the downside effects on jobs, investment and growth, of the cuts to industry and export assistance programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this follows a question asked by Senator Forshaw last week. I am not aware of what Premier Court said. The government made a decision at budget time to remove bounties. This was brought out in a report by the Industry Commission and the Bureau of Industry Economics. It recommended the termination of bounties.
—No, it was not.
—Senator, the Senate committee inquiry into bounties—
—No, it was not. That is factually wrong.
—Order! There is an opportunity after question time, Senator Cook, for you to make comments on the answer, if you wish to do so. It is disorderly for you to continue to interject during the answer.

—Senator Murray will be aware that the report of the Senate committee inquiry into bounties was tabled last Friday. It highlighted the points I have just made, and which Senator Cook objected to, which resulted from studies by the Industry Commission. It recommended the termination of these bounties because of the marginal effect of a low bounty rate against the administration and compliance costs. These measures give certain industry sectors preferential treatment. The minister has advised that the government will formally respond to those reports in the near future.

ANSWER.PARA: It has been a priority of this government to reduce the administration and compliance costs of industry. This was highlighted in the recommendations made by the small business deregulation task force. Furthermore, it is the government's intention that all sectors of the economy should make a contribution to reducing the budget deficit to avoid anomalies. That was done. The impact of the withdrawal of certain bounties is being considered—for instance, with regard to the computer bounties—by the government's industry task force which is due to report in April next year. The government is currently formulating a more strategic approach to industry development and we have commissioned a review of business programs which will review all assistance to all industry and ensure that Australia industry receives optimum support to enable it to improve its competitiveness.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you for your answer. Will the minister acknowledge that these R&D bounty cuts are not supported by Premier Court, were hasty and ill‐conceived, were driven by Treasury, not by industry, not by the industry minister and not by the industry department, and do not enjoy the support of large numbers of senators and members on all sides of both houses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said to you earlier, I have no idea what Premier Court said. We made a decision in regard to the budget. You might recall that when we came into government, notwithstanding the comments by those on the other side when in government that there was no budget deficit, we were confronted with a $10 billion budget deficit. In other words, the previous Labor government had put $10 billion on the credit card for future generations to pay.

ANSWER.PARA: This government took the hard decisions and did it in a fair and equitable way. That is the view taken by the community at large. We had no option but to make cuts. Everyone has to take a bit of pain. I believe that the view of the community at large was that it was done fairly and justly and that we acted in a most responsible fashion, which is more than I can say for those on the other side who were in government for 13 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Given that the two original short‐listed firms for the gun buyback campaign PR contract were represented in Canberra by former Labor staffers, can the minister guarantee that they were not blackballed because of their previous associations? Further, to what extent has the campaign by the selected PR firm been marginalised by government timetable bungling, which has made the launch of the gun buyback advertising campaign a total damp squib?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, there is one thing I can assure you of; that is, under this government contracts will be awarded on merit. Themere fact that it occurs to you—you see, Madam President, what immediately occurs to Senator Bolkus? He looks at a list of people who have been considered and he sees that a couple of those people may or may not—I do not know; I do not assume that Senator Bolkus is lying to me when he says this—have been involved as Labor staffers. He immediately assumes that, for that reason, they would not get the contracts. Why does he assume that? Because that is how the previous government worked. That is absolutely how it occurs to you.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator, you have had hours and hours and hours of time on these issues, at vast expense to other taxpayers. You have got the answer to just about every possible question you could ask. As a gesture of goodwill, because we are nearing the end of the session, I will take this question and I will give it to the Attorney‐General and I will ask him whether there is anything he wants to add to the mountain of information that you have already received on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since you are taking that on notice, can you also take this on notice: can you or the Attorney‐General confirm that Burson‐Marsteller, the government's favoured firm for the PR contract, has suffered a major computer crash and lost all the material relating to the gun buyback campaign? Can you take that on notice. Can you also tell us to what extent this further incident will further delay and impair this vital campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —During question time, Senator Collins asked me a question with regard to the surplus of valencia oranges. It relates to the falls in the international price of frozen concentrated juice with increased local and overseas production of valencia oranges. This has caused serious concern in the citrus growing areas.

QUESTION.PARA: The government is fully aware of the adjustment pressures faced by citrus growers and has programs in place to assist adjustment in the industry. Citrus growers have been aware for many years that they need to diversify away from dependence on income from processing fruit used for concentrate production which does not cover the cost of production. Thus they have been reworking their orchards to produce a higher proportion of fruit suitable for sale as fresh product, and a higher proportion of fruit has been processed for fresh juice.

These industry efforts, supported by government programs and agencies, are paying off, with exports in 1995-96 accounting for 20 per cent of the crop or 100,006 tonnes worth $107 million. Exports have increased over the last six years from 35,000 tonnes in 1989‐90, and the industry's goal of exporting 30 per cent of production by the year 2000 is now in sight. The government support programs include an $8.4 million five-year citrus market diversification program and a dollar for dollar matching of industry contributions for R&D, the tri‐state fruit fly program and adjustment assistance under the rural adjustment scheme.

The next meeting of the citrus market development group on 16 December, which manages the citrus market diversification program, is to consider the current pressures facing the industry. Assistance with improving citrus orchards is also available under the rural adjustment scheme and includes: grants and loans for acquisition of farm management skills and professional advice, interest subsidies, loans for enhancing farm productivity and re-establishment support.

If the government were to return to the protectionist measures of the past, it would amount to assisting the unprofitable sector. Returns to growers from exports range from about $450 per tonne in Asia to $1,000 per tonne in the United States, whereas oranges used in the production of concentrate returned $50 to $100 a tonne. The industry has taken the right decision to move away from dependence on juice concentrate, and the government will continue its support for those industry efforts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —In a debate after question time on 26 November, during which I had answered a question about the cost to Australia of reducing greenhouse gas emissions, Senator Kernot asked Senator Hill if I would table the modelling to which I had referred in my answer. I seek leave to table some short documents in response to her request and to make a short statement explaining what the documents are.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am tabling three documents. The first is a note by the Executive Director of ABARE, Dr Brian Fisher, which explains how ABARE concluded that on a per person basis it would cost Australians $1,900, or $7,600 for a family of four, to stabilise emissions of carbon dioxide from fossil fuel combustion at 1990 levels and maintain the emissions at that level thereafter.

QUESTION.PARA: The second document is a copy of a paper by Dr Fisher and other officers of ABARE, which was delivered publicly in June this year. The paper presented the results of using the Megabare model to estimate the cost of greenhouse gas abatement to Australia and some other countries. Megabare is a general equilibrium model of the world economy, which models production, consumption and investment behaviour in 30 countries and regions and identifies trade flows between regions. Megabare has been applied to a variety of issues, including greenhouse policy and trade liberalisation.

BREAK.PARA: The third and final document entitled `The Megabare Model—interim documentation' is a publication from February this year which describes in more technical terms the main features of Megabare and how it works.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), to a question without notice asked by Senator Kernot today, relating to social security benefits for new migrants.

In question time today we saw what has become another in a series of inadequate responses from an incompetent minister. Unfortunately, for this country and for this parliament, what is happening in this place is that we have a continuing campaign of using migrants and using people of Aboriginal background as political footballs. We saw it played last week in the public and in this parliament. This afternoon the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) has just reinforced that particular action.

In discussing the minister's answer, I should place on record comments made today in Parliament House by the Bishop of Bathurst, the Right Reverend Bruce Wilson, and a member of the executive of the NCCA. He made this point:

At a National Council of Churches task force meeting in September, Aboriginal leaders had never looked so depressed. From all over the nation, indigenous people were reporting outbreaks of racial hatred such as they have not experienced for years.

When you start the bushfire of racial intolerance, it hits everybody. When you target migrants, it hits the blacks; when you target the blacks, it hits migrants. This government is about playing that political football—kicking it for as much as it is worth for their own grubby, direct political advantage—regardless of what it does to this country's cohesiveness and prosperity. It is cohesiveness and prosperity that are at stake here. This minister has shown absolutely no morality or responsibility. But, unfortunately, she is following the lead of her Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and she is encouraged by the new Mr Le Pen, Peter Costello, the Treasurer in the other place.

What we have seen is that, when people migrate to Australia, two-thirds of them find jobs within the first 12 months and 75 per cent find employment within the first 18 months to two years. What this government has sought to do willy-nilly—without review and without policy analysis—is to deny all these people rights of access to services for two years. What the Senate did last week was to make this government fit the commitment they made at the last election, and that was to extend the waiting period to two years for some selected benefits which are paid to permanent residents of Australia.

What we saw after that was nothing short of disgraceful. We had the Minister for Social Security who was not sighted at the front table in the course of the debate but she hovered around the back—I do not know what she was paid for on those days—watching Senator Tambling do the hard work for her. She was sitting there bludging on the backbench whilst the work was being done by the parliamentary secretary. But this minister, who chose not to be involved in the debate, then went out on the public airways and together with the Treasurer deliberately went out to stir divisiveness—something that should have no place at all in modern Australia—on race.

They were stirring up antagonism towards migrants and migration, people like Senator Panizza who probably arrived here without the English language but who very quickly learned how to make a buck, how to get employment and pay taxes here. From day one, people pay indirect taxes in this country. This minister shows absolutely no sense of social responsibility, and that is unfortunate for this debate.

When Peter Costello and other government ministers and members go out there and say, `We're making sure that migrants don't from day one get access to services,' they are not telling the truth. They are denying the fact that for many benefits in the past migrants have had to wait six months and that for many benefits, even now, migrants have to wait not just six months but two years.

BREAK.PARA: What we have done in the past in this society is to recognise the importance and value of migration, the importance of getting a cohesiveness together and the importance of social assistance in that. We have also recognised that, no matter where the migrant group has come from, Australia has been the winner. We have benefited from that migration. As a whole, Australia has broadened and prospered enormously on the basis of continued high growth migration in the 1950s and 1960s, and continued migration ever since.

But if we are—like this government is—going to go out and continually stir the flames of racial divisiveness, then it is going to be our society that will suffer. Bishop Wilson this morning made another plaintive plea. He said:
Our unity, prosperity and wellbeing as a nation is also at stake.

He called on all political leaders and all opinion makers, both secular and spiritual, to become a lot more sensitive in treating these issues. It is a pity this government has lit the bushfires of racial divisiveness. They came into government on the back of it and they have kicked it for all it is worth ever since. But fortunately for this country it is starting to backfire. You are looking sleazy, you are looking amoral. The church leaders are coming out calling for a better standard on your part. Let us hope, for this country's prosperity and cohesiveness, we get it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we should look at what the coalition election policy said and then compare it with what it has cost and the claims that are being made by this government. The coalition's election policy proposal on this matter was to extend Labor's existing waiting lists from six months to two years, and that means on the same allowances and the same conditions. Part of that policy was to expressly exclude family allowances and Medicare and to provide a safety net in the form of special allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: We remember vividly when the coalition held this policy up and said, `We've had Access Economics independently cost this.' Their costs were $616 million over three years, which would have been $900 million over four years. Where do we get this $400 million that the government is now talking about? The first thing is that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) is blaming the Senate for not starting its work until May. The government is saying, `But, look, our start-up date was April.' Is it the Senate's fault that this government did not call the parliament together in order to meet the start-up dates of their election policy promises? I hardly think so.

The second part that I want to point to in this $400 million total is the special benefit, the payment of last resort, which is paid in lieu of newstart, sickness and youth training allowances which will be $65 million over four years. This government is now blaming the Senate for the cost of implementing an important part of their election policy commitments. This is really rich! It is the Senate's fault for not starting before the start-up date of their proposed legislation and it is the Senate's fault for implementing the cost of coalition election policies.

I suggest the minister take another look at these costings. I have the paper that she has given me. I certainly will examine it overnight. But, from a cursory look, it seems to me that the government is still using these two excuses. They are unacceptable excuses. In interviews around this country over the past few days, the Minister for Social Security and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) have deliberately given the impression that the coalition's election policy was not about the four allowances—the six which had the six-month wait under Labor—but about 14 to 16 separate measures that the Senate was refusing to pass.

The government—specifically, the Minister for Social Security and the Treasurer, and on occasions the Prime Minister (Mr Howard)—have quite deliberately and distinctly given the impression that all measures were blocked, when in fact the waiting period for the dole, sickness allowance and youth training allowance was increased from six months to two years. And this is where the bulk of the coalition's savings were to come from.

BREAK.PARA: The coalition—specifically, the Minister for Social Security on the John Laws program—gave the impression that this wait applied only to the dole; that the Senate had only given permission to extend the six months to two years for the dole. This is absolutely deliberately misleading, and we know why. Nobody could say it better than Alan Ramsey, actually, and I want to quote him in Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald:

An underlying thread of the Government's policy behaviour ever since it came to office is the divisive way it always seems ready to play one group or other off against so‐called "mainstream Australia", or what it likes to constantly invoke as the country's "battlers".
Either it's Aborigines, or the unions, or public servants, or Asian migrants, or groups as undefined as the "elite" and the "politically correct".

Always, it seems, those who come into these categories are, either explicitly or implicitly, held up in the Government's rhetoric as somehow not behaving in the broad national interest of the rest of the community . . .
Now it's the turn of new migrants, or what Peter Costello calls "those people", as if somehow they're just bludging off "good Australian taxpayers". . .
Alan Ramsey concludes:
That's the way politics works, too. Now we've got new migrants to bash, along with all the other scapegoats this Government keeps coming up with to justify what's wrong with the economy.
Who do we blame next?

That is what is behind this misrepresentation of how the Senate voted on waiting periods for new migrants. It is disgraceful, divisive politics and it is especially disgraceful coming from the mob who said they were going to govern for all of us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments on this motion because I want to pick up where Senator Kernot just left off, in terms of what is disgraceful and what is not. I believe that the Australian Democrats went to the people at the last election saying that they would keep the bastards honest. They have gone to election after election—successive elections—promising the same thing. What they have done on this occasion is try to make us dishonest, because what was a key and instrumental part of our election platform at the last election, and for which we received a very clear mandate, was to introduce a two‐year waiting period for most welfare payments.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened is that the Labor Party and the Democrats have seen fit to make sure that we do not keep that promise. We believe that the people of Australia are owed more than that. This measure would have simply reinforced the commitments made by intending migrants or their sponsors to support themselves when they first enter Australia. All we are saying is that the commitment that they give to this country and to the taxpayers of this country should be upheld.

The Labor government, during its 13 years in government, failed to implement that. This government is trying to do the right thing by Australian taxpayers and is saying that this is an important part that is owed to Australian taxpayers—where intending migrants and their sponsors give that commitment, they are asked to honour that commitment. It is unreasonable to expect Australian taxpayers to help people to dishonour a commitment of that nature.

This is not a race issue and it disturbs me that Senator Kernot and the Labor Party are trying to turn it into a race issue. The Labor Party has been incessantly suggesting that it is a race issue. I am now disturbed to hear that Senator Kernot is jumping onto that bandwagon. It is simply that these new migrants have given that commitment and they are being asked to honour that commitment. The opposition parties have simply deliberately flouted the views of the Australian people.

PARA.BREAK: What the opposition parties fail to accept is the decision of 2 March 1996. At some stage they have to come to accept that they lost this election. They lost it, and they lost it comprehensively. We gave commitments at that time to make sure that measures such as this were to be taken to protect the interests of migrants, sponsors and Australian taxpayers. But the Labor Party and the Democrats are deliberately and simply playing games with the revenue contributed by the battlers of this country. They don't seem to mind that, for every dollar they snatch away in these meas ures, they put an extra burden onto the battlers of this country. Again, they have no regard for the taxation contribution of those battlers and want to see bigger and bigger government expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: The difference between what we are trying to do in government and what has happened over the previous 13 years is that they simply went on spending and spending. We cannot live in that society any more. We cannot pretend that it is utopia any more. We have to put the brakes on somewhere along the line.

I am advised that the actions of the opposition parties have increased government expenditure by approximately $130 million in a full year and, as Senator Newman said in question time today, just a smidgin under $400 million over the first four years. —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 25 November 1996 of the Hon. James Donald Mathieson Dobie, member of the House of Representatives for the division of Hughes, New South Wales, from 1966 to 1969, and for the division of Cook, New South Wales, from 1969 to 1972 and from 1975 to March 1996, and Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister from 1971 to 1972.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 25 November 1996, of the Honourable James Donald Mathieson Dobie, member of the House of Representatives for the division of Hughes from 1966 to 1969, member for the division of Cook from 1969 to 1972 and from 1975 to March 1996, Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister from 1971 to 1972, Deputy Chair of Committees from 1970 to 1971, 1979 to 1983, and 1987 to 1994, member of the Speaker's Panel from 1994 to 1996, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and its profound sadness at his passing.

Don Dobie was born on 28 July 1927 at Glasgow in Scotland. He was educated at Brisbane Grammar School, and went on to complete a Bachelor of Commerce degree at Melbourne University and a Master of Business Administration degree at Columbia University in New York.

Before entering federal politics, Don worked for the Bank of New South Wales from 1943 to 1966. He also served with the 2nd Light Anti-Aircraft Regiment, Royal Australian Artillery, Citizens Military Forces, with the rank of gunner between 1951 and 1952.

Don became a member of the House of Representatives in 1966 when he won the New South Wales seat of Hughes for the Liberal Party. In his maiden speech in the House in February 1967, he placed on record his total commitment to the welfare of his constituents and spoke on a range of issues, including housing finance for young people, education and the need to ensure quality of teaching, services for the disabled, and the importance of international trade for Australia's economic future.

As I have said, Don was Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Deputy Chair of Committees and Chief Opposition Whip and he also served on the Speaker's Panel. During his long service in this parliament, Don also contributed tirelessly to the work of a wide range of House of Representatives committees, including the committee on environment, recreation and the arts; the House committee; the privileges committee; the long‐term strategies committee; the community affairs committee; and the members' interests committee. He also served on a number of joint committees, including foreign affairs and defence; the Australian Capital Territory; the new Parliament House; the parliamentary zone, and public accounts.

Don made many friends in this parliament on both sides of politics as well as among the Comcar drivers and staff of the parliamentary departments. He made mention of this in his valedictory speech on the eve of his departure not so long ago from this parliament. Characteristically, he also made special reference to his constituents and the personal satisfaction that could be gained from being a local member.

Don will be sadly missed by all of us who knew him. Personally, I regarded him as a good bloke and he gave me a lot of good advice. I enjoyed his company and learnt a lot from him, particularly in my early days in this parliament. He will be remembered by all of us as a fine parliamentarian and a dedicated local member.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the opposition to support the motion of condolence that has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Hill has indicated, Don Dobie was first elected to parliament in 1966. Don had a difficult early parliamentary career because he was defeated in the 1972 and 1974 elections in the seat of Cook by Mr Ray Thorburn, whom I knew very well. They were always very well contested elections down there and tough battles indeed.

As has been said, Don Dobie served as Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister from 1971 through until the defeat of the McMahon government in 1972. He had some very distinguished parliamentary committee service and was Deputy Chairman of Committees for many years.

Don Dobie was a very vocal advocate for the electorate of Cook. When I first became a senator, I had my own electorate office in Caringbah in the electorate of Cook and I knew Don Dobie well. He was very dedicated, as I have said, to his electorates, and many of us in the opposition knew Don Dobie well for quite a long period. I can assure you, Madam President, that we join with the government in expressing our sincere condolences and expressing our sincere regret at his death.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to join the Australian Democrats in this motion of condolence on the death of Mr Don Dobie. I knew Mr Dobie reasonably well from the time that I was a staffer.
