TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate mem bers of the National Party in the Senate with the condolence motion moved by Senator Hill on the death of the Hon. Don Dobie. Don Dobie passed away last week at the age of 69. He was a former assistant minister in the McMahon government. He was one of the parliament's longest serving House of Representatives members, serving for 26 years and winning 10 elections on the way. He first entered parliament as the member for Hughes in 1966 in the big Harold Holt win. Following a redistribution, he was re-elected in 1969 in the seat of Cook, which he held until 1972 and then regained in 1975. He held Cook from then until his retirement last year.

SPEECH.PARA: Don Dobie was born in Glasgow in 1927, and his parents relocated to Brisbane, where he went to the Brisbane Grammar School. He then went on to study commerce at Melbourne University. In 1943 he joined the Bank of New South Wales, where he pursued a banking career for the next 20 years. He served from 1951 to 1952 with the anti‐aircraft regiment.

His capabilities were recognised by the bank, and it sent him to New York to study for an MBA at Columbia University. He returned to Australia, where he was approached by the Liberal Party to stand for Hughes, and his long parliamentary career was launched.

He attained a ministry in 1971 as Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister. He was Deputy Chair of Committees from 1970 to 1971, 1979 to 1983 and 1987 to 1994, and he was chief opposition whip from 1983 to 1985. He stated in his final speech last year that he saw being a member of parliament as an end in itself, not as a means to pursue further ambitions. He derived immense satisfaction from being an effective local member who succeeded in getting things done for his constituents, in particular with their battles against the bureaucracy.

He participated fully in committee work in the parliament. He was a member of the public accounts committee from 1967 to 1971—serving as the chair from 1969 to 1971—and also from 1976 to 1977. He took an interest in the foreign affairs and trade portfolios, and he served on the foreign affairs and trade committee from 1978 to 1983. He was the special parliamentary adviser to the 37th UN General Assembly in 1982. He was Liberal Party representative on the New Parliament House Arts Advisory Committee, and I know that he enjoyed that job immensely as he had a very strong interest in the arts.

He was a hardworking member. He was known affectionately amongst the coalition as a strong whip. He used to have a few little jokes with us in the party room. He was hailed by the Prime Minister during the valedictory debate last year as a `quintessentially superb local member', a great accolade with which everyone who knew him would concur.
On behalf of the National Party in the Senate, I extend sympathy to Don Dobie's family and his friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put on the record my sadness at the passing on 25 November of the Hon. Don Dobie, the member for Hughes from 1966 to 1969, the member for Cook from 1969 to 1972 and, again, from 1975 to 1996. Also, as has been mentioned, amongst many other things, he was the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister—that is, Prime Minister McMahon—in 1971-72.

SPEECH.PARA: Don Dobie had a long and meritorious record as a distinguished member of the federal parliament. I had the pleasure of being a member of the House of Representatives with him between 1975 and 1980 and, during that period, found him to be very generous in the way in which he shared his earlier parliamentary experience with newcomers like me. On his retirement earlier this year, Don was second, I think, only to the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair, the member for New England, in the length of service of the then still sitting members. That is a terrific record of achievement.

Don Dobie contributed much as a member of parliament both as a local member and as a parliamentarian. He was probably best known as a local member and, as Senator Boswell said in his comments just prior to this speech, in the valedictories last December the then opposition leader and now Prime Minister, John Howard, described Don as a `quintessentially superb local member'. His record in holding the marginal seat of Cook for such a long period with just one glitch, the period between 1972 and 1975, bears eloquent testimony to that fact.

He saw the full and effective representation of all his constituents, regardless of political allegiances, as his primary responsibility as a member of parliament. Important as that was—and it was primarily important to him—Don, though, was also a significant parliamentarian. He had strong academic qualifications. He had a Bachelor of Commerce from the University of Melbourne and a Master of Business Administration from Columbia University in New York. He was an employee of the Bank of New South Wales—now Westpac—for more than 20 years before entering parliament. That prior career experience enabled him to contribute effectively over many years to economic issues in the parliament.

In his maiden speech way back in February 1967, he drew attention very correctly to the fundamental importance for Australia of international trade and our ability to compete in an increasingly competitive world. That is something we hear much about nowadays, but perhaps it was not so much in those days.

He was also interested in a wide range of other issues, particularly foreign affairs, the environment and the institutions of parliament. He represented the parliament on many parliamentary delegations to other countries and to international agencies. I, along with my friend Senator McKiernan, was privileged to be a fellow member with him on one of these occasions: namely, the parliamentary delegation to Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia in November 1993. Don was a very amiable member of that delegation and we benefited from his long experience of such representation.
Don was appointed as Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister in 1971-72. He was also Chief Opposition Whip between 1983 and 1985 and, as has already been outlined, he occupied many other positions.

The respect and high regard in which Don Dobie was held by his coalition colleagues was reflected in his being the coalition's nominee for Speaker of the House of Representatives after the elections in 1987, 1990 and 1993. He was seen by his colleagues—and I am sure by many in the Labor Party too—as a person who had a real feel for the institution of parliament, who could command the respect of both sides of parliament and who could enforce the authority of the House with his admirable qualities of fairness and courtesy, which I think were widely recognised. Don Dobie was very much a very courteous man.

He did not enjoy good health in his latter years, but he bore that with good humour, fortitude and courage. It is a great pity that Don did not live to enjoy much of his retirement. Perhaps, however, that was not of particular concern to him because, in essence, parliament and the electorate for which he cared and worked for so long were not just work for him. They were his delight, his enjoyment and, indeed, in many respects his whole life. I think we are all the poorer for his passing. We have benefited greatly from the life he led.

But Don had a terrific win, in his terms, and went on to effectively make Cook a pretty solid, safe seat for the Liberal Party thereafter.

I conclude by saying that I am now the duty senator for Cook, having succeeded Bruce Childs and Senator Faulkner. We seem to have a long line of duty senators for the seat of Cook. That is due, no doubt, to the legacy of Don Dobie, who, as somebody said, was the quintessential local politician and local member, who served his electorate well for many years. I found it somewhat ironic that, having been an activist in the ALP at a very young age when Don went in and having dreamt in those days of being a member of parliament, when I finally arrived, Don was still here. That was a pretty big tribute, I think, to his service to the community and to the parliament, as has been recognised by other speakers. I join with other speakers in supporting this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Like all of my colleagues, I support the condolence motion. My wife and I also extend our sympathy to his family and friends. I did not know Don all that well—regrettably, the Senate is a long way away from those who sit in the other chamber. But we did converse briefly and happily at joint party meetings.

SPEECH.PARA: I do want to briefly associate myself with the motion because, in his own quiet way, he was a great support and encouragement to me in my role in North Queensland in my early years in parliament. Don had some very close family friends in Townsville, and he would often drop into my office to lend encouragement during his visits to the north. Those contacts—to him, a natural part of his everyday and easygoing friendliness and interest in his colleagues—were significant to me and were greatly appreciated by my staff and me. I acknowledge that northern association in my support for the condolence motion.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Before putting the motion, I wish to speak briefly. This morning, at the Presbyterian church in Cronulla, I attended the thanksgiving service for the life of Don Dobie. Senators have spoken of Don's service to his community, and had you been there this morning and seen the number of organisations represented—many in blazers with pockets indicating the groups they belong to—you would have been left in no doubt about the way he was regarded in the electorate of Cook. There was representation from the surf‐lifesaving club, in particular, where there was to be a reception afterwards for those who were able to attend; from scouts, guides, schoolchildren; from older and younger people. Clearly, from the grief and emotion at the service, it was very obvious that what has been said today is absolutely true. The story recounted just now by Senator Forshaw about Don being assistant to the Prime Minister was also recounted there and enjoyed by those in the church, many of whom, of course, remembered those days.

INTERJECT.PARA: The service was conducted by the Reverend Neil Eriksson, a longstanding friend of Don Dobie, who returned to the church to conduct the service this morning. The tributes were given by former New South Wales senator, Chris Puplick—which was an excellent tribute—and Mr Malcolm Kerr MP, the member for Cronulla, and by the Reverend Neil Eriksson himself.

BREAK.PARA: For most of my time since I came to the Senate, I have been the only Liberal senator for the ACT, and that was sufficient for a man like Don Dobie to take an interest in me, knowing I had no other party colleagues from my own area. He always took the sort of interest that Senator Ian Macdonald has referred to in relation to himself. I valued the friendship that grew. I did serve on two joint standing committees with him and had the opportunity to know him and to appreciate his work as a local member—which I tried to emulate—his skill as a parliamentarian and his commitment to the parliament and what it meant.

I mourn his passing. Although we all knew he had suffered from diabetes for a long time, I do not think any of us expected the end to come so soon. It was a heart attack in the end, but I think we all would realise that it was the diabetes that was the underlying problem that he had. I think we all would have imagined him living on for a number of years, enjoying travelling, as he did. It is sad that he has died so soon after leaving the parliament. This morning many people mourned his passing but gave thanks for what he had done for them over so many years. I invite senators to stand and signify their support for the motion by their silence.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that any reform to Australia's system of industrial relations should recognise the special needs of employees to be protected from disadvantage, exploitation and discrimination in the workplace.

We the petitioners oppose the Coalition policies which represent a fundamentally anti‐worker regime and we call upon the Senate to provide an effective check and balance to the Coalition's legislative program by rejecting such a program and ensuring that:
1. The existing powers of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) be maintained to provide for an effective independent umpire overseeing awards and workplace bargaining processes.

2. The proposed system of Australian Workplace Agreements (AWAs) should be subject to the same system of approval required for the approval of certified agreements (through enterprise bargaining). Specifically, an AWA should not come into effect unless it is approved by the AIRC.

3. The approval of agreements contained in the legislation should be public and open to scrutiny. There should be provision for the involvement of parties who have a material concern relating to the approval of an agreement, including unions seeking to maintain the no disadvantage guarantees.
4. Paid rates awards be preserved and capable of adjustment, as is currently the case in the legislation.
5. The AIRC's powers to arbitrate and make awards must be preserved in the existing form and not be restricted to a stripped back set of minimum or core conditions.
6. The legislation should encourage the processes of collective bargaining and ensure that a certified agreement within its term of operation cannot be over‐ridden by a subsequent AWA.
7. The secondary boycott provisions should be preserved in their existing form.

8. The powers and responsibility of the AIRC to ensure the principle of equal pay for work of equal value should be preserved in its existing form. We oppose any attempt by the Coalition to restrict the AIRC from dealing with overaward gender based pay equity issues.
9. A `fair go all round' for unfair dismissal so that all workers currently able to access these remedies are able to do so in a fair manner, at no cost.
10. Workers under state industrial regulations maintain their rights to access the federal awards system in its current form.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Senate to reject the above proposed reforms to the area of industrial relations.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Childs, Sen Bruce; Margetts, Sen Dee
PETITION.TITLE: Telstra: Privatisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators, and to the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that:
As members of the Australian community, considering:
the strategic important of Telstra in the national economy;
the high levels of foreign ownership in the rest of the telecommunications industry;
the growing importance of communications services to the lives of all Australians;
the threat that privatisation poses to the universal availability of both present and future communications services;
We believe that it is in the national interest for Telstra to be kept in full public ownership.

We therefore call on the Federal Government to abandon its proposal to privatise Telstra, the nation's chief telecommunications provider, and to explore alternative means of funding its environmental policy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Childs (from 21 citizens)and Senator Margetts (from 844 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned recognises the vital role of a strong and comprehensive Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and asks that:
1. Coalition Senators honour their 1996 election promise, namely that "The Coalition will maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC".
2. The Senate votes to maintain the existing role of the ABC as a fully independent, publicly funded and publicly owned organisation.
3. The Senate oppose any weakening of the Charter of the ABC.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that we, as residents of the State of Western Australia, urge the government to:
reject moves to cut the funding of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and instead maintain funding in real terms.
recognise and maintain the role of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation as a comprehensive, mainstream and independent media organisation, and not just a complementary service to commercial media.
recognise the ABC Charter as a valuable instrument for the expression of Australian cultural life that should not be devalued as a result of economic and political considerations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ramsar Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia in Geelong requests that the Senate examine the proposal to set aside land currently protected under the Ramsar Treaty in order to provide for a chemical storage facility at Pt Lillias. Further, we request the Senate to examine whether the proposal to set aside an area alternate to the one now nominated by the Ramsar Treaty is in accordance with the requirement of that Treaty.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows: That the East Timorese asylum‐seekers, who have fled terror in their country and who have sought refugee status in Australia, are being unfairly rejected on the basis of dubious ascription of Portuguese nationality. Your petitioners therefore pray that the Prime Minister and his Minister for Immigration:

1. Acknowledge the burden on charitable organisations and basic human need and permit the continuation of Asylum Seekers Assistance for all East Timorese refugee applicants until a decision by the Federal Court is made.
2. Reinstate the right of an interview in all East Timorese refugee determinations.
3. Grant special humanitarian consideration for East Timorese refugee applicants.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

that changes to funding proposed in the State Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1996 will cause disruption to the education of students in government schools allowing new private schools to be set up without consideration being given to the impact on existing schools in the area of the new school; that the `enrolment adjustment benchmark' will cause unfair reductions to school funding in excess of the saving to government systems when a student transfers to a private school; and that by OECD standards our government schools are substantially underfunded.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

amend the Bill to retain the existing arrangements for taking into account the social consequences of setting up new schools, to reject the enrolment adjustment benchmark, and to increase funding per student at least to average OECD levels.

EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION OF PROVIDERS AND FINANCIAL REGULATION) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2)
The proposed Bills will impose a Provider Registration Charge upon approved providers of courses for overseas students.

The charge is a cost-recovery measure to offset the administration costs involved in maintaining and distributing the national register (the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS)) and the associated facilitation of immigration processes and the monitoring of providers against te statutory requirements, which give all providers the measure of protection for the industry they have said they want and which enable Tuition Assurance Schemes to limit their risk.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee entitled National well-being: A system of national citizenship indicators and benchmarks. I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: NATIONAL WELL-BEING: A SYSTEM OF NATIONAL CITIZENSHIP INDICATORS AND BENCHMARKS
REPORT RECOMMENDATIONS AND THE COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT'S RESPONSE

SPEECH.PARA: NOVEMBER 1996

PARA.EMPHASIS: Introduction:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government expresses its appreciation to the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee for its report on the development of a system of national citizenship indicators and benchmarks. The Government recognises that a sound system of social statistics is vital to the effective development of social policy, to informed decision making on policy issues and to the evaluation of the impact of social and economic policy. Reliable and well focused social statistics are also vital for informing public debate both within countries and at an international level.

The Government considers that the Committee's report provides useful recommendations for further developing the extensive array of information already available from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS), agencies such as the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare (AIHW) and the Australian Institute of Criminology (AIC), and the many other Commonwealth and State agencies involved in the compilation and analysis of social statistics.

The thrust of the Committee's recommendations is generally supported, although any new initiatives that may arise from proposed review activities will need to be considered within the context of normal budget review processes. The ABS will seek further submissions from State and Commonwealth government agencies to inform these processes.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 1

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Australian Bureau of Statistics be resourced to carry out a two stage audit of its collection of statistics on human well‐being with the aim of identifying the areas where potentially valuable nationally consistent data is not available. The second stage of the audit should concentrate on ways that the identified `gaps' can be remedied. Relevant bodies, such as the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare and the Australian Institute of Criminology, should be involved in both stages of the review.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Response:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government accepts the on‐going need for the ABS to audit national statistical collection activities, with reference to other agencies such as the AIHW and AIC. This will ensure the availability of statistics on human well‐being to support the government and community in the development and evaluation of policies and programs. While additional funding might expedite the audit process the Government is satisfied that existing processes within the ABS will address the Committee's concerns. The Government therefore does not intend to provide additional funding.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Comment:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes that the ABS, other agencies charged with informing debate on issues of social concern (such as AIWH and AIC) and many other agencies at both Commonwealth and State levels, produce a vast array of social statistics. In 1996 the ABS alone expects to publish 36 titles relating to social topics, including labour force, education, child care, women, Indigenous people, sport and recreation, health, crime and justice, and income distribution. An indication of the breadth of information available is evident from the annual Australian Social Trends publication (ABS Catalogue 4102.0) which presents social statistics and indica tors from both the ABS's own collection program and from other sources. The range of available data reflects the interests and priorities of the community and government in addressing issues of ongoing social concern.

As the central statistical authority, the ABS has the task of co‐ordinating government statistical services as well as collecting and compiling statistics across the broad range of population, social and labour statistics. Many other agencies, at both Commonwealth and State levels, also have responsibility for statistics in a particular area or produce statistics for and about their own administration. In these cases, the ABS seeks to coordinate the activities of the other agencies, placing particular importance on statistical standards and classifications.

An ABS Review of Social and Labour Statistics, published in 1990, assessed levels of demand and unmet need for statistical information taking into account the full range of statistical activities and responsibilities of other agencies at State and Commonwealth levels. This comprehensive review, involving extensive consultation with key stakeholders, has been complemented by an on‐going program of reviews in various areas. These continuing audit processes identify information gaps and the strength of demand for such information. They assist in setting priorities within the ABS work program for the provision of timely and relevant information taking account of the costs associated with meeting those needs.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 2

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Australian Bureau of Statistics be resourced to collect relevant data and develop indicators in the area of social and political participation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Response:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has asked the ABS to establish, in consultation with other relevant agencies, the level and nature of the unmet demand for information in the area of social and political participation and to assess its priority in the context of the overall ABS work program.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Comment:

SPEECH.PARA: While the Government acknowledges the Committee's finding (para 4.41) that there are gaps in statistical information relating to the area of social and political participation, valuable indicators of levels of participation in important domains of social life are available from existing sources. For instance, the ABS has long provided information which enables the assessment of changing levels of participation in employment, schooling and further education. Other national collections, including recent surveys of voluntary work, time use and ageing and disability, have also provided information on patterns of social participation.

The ABS will identify areas of unmet demand for data on political and social participation. It will give attention to conceptual frameworks already developed by international and national statistical agencies in assessing the type of indicators that are likely to be useful for policy development purposes. It will also identify options for extending existing and proposed collection activities to obtain additional data.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendations 3 and 4 will be addressed together.
Recommendation 3

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government give high priority to the establishment of a National System of Indicators and Benchmarks, capable of measuring performance in the area of legal, economic, social and cultural significance.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 4

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Government take the following steps towards implementing a National System of Indicators and Benchmarks:
(a) that a relevant portfolio, possibly the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, be given the responsibility for co‐ordinating the development of the system;
(b) that the Australian Bureau of Statistics be resourced to carry out an audit of existing indicators to identify gaps and to expand their current system into a comprehensive system of indicators;
(c) that the Citizenship Project of the Centre for Urban and Social Research, Swinburne University of Technology, be commissioned to carry out a qualitative study‐

(i) to assist the Australian Bureau of Statistics in the content definition of indicators by building on international systems, on the various Australian attempts now in progress including work by the Australian National Audit Office and advice from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission on the human rights component of the system; and
(ii) to design a process for the development of the benchmarks.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Response:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not intend to establish a formal National System of Indicators and Benchmarks. Rather, it considers that national indicators and benchmarks should be developed progressively and that, initially, these are best advanced in the context of the COAG review of Commonwealth/State service provision and other Commonwealth/State Government initiatives.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Comment:

SPEECH.PARA: Indicators and benchmarks are currently being developed in a number of areas. The COAG review of Commonwealth/State service provision has as its main task the development of agreed national performance indicators for key services delivered by governments. The first annual report of the review, `Report on Government Service Provision: 1995' was released on 20 December 1995. It examined the effectiveness and efficiency of the following social services: public acute care hospitals, public rental housing, primary and secondary education, vocational education and training, police, courts administration, corrective services and support services for individuals and families. The review will report annually with the second report to be released in February 1997. Furthermore, and as noted in the Senate Committee's report, the Government has also given attention to development of benchmarks of adequacy as a basis for monitoring well‐being. These have direct relevance to income support programmes. More recently, Commonwealth, State and Territory governments have agreed to the development of a set of benchmarks for primary school literacy and plan to conduct surveys to determine whether those benchmarks are being reached. These developments complement those associated with the current review of performance information (being co‐ordinated by the Department of Finance) which aims to improve the clarity of objectives, and associated performance indicators, for the activities of Commonwealth Departments.

Recommendation 4 proposes steps towards implementing a National System of Indicators and Benchmarks. While additional resources will not be committed to this task, the Government considers that the ABS, as the national statistical agency, is best placed to perform the role of drawing together and reporting on the indicators of social well‐being and associated benchmarks, as they develop over time (Recommendation 4a). This activity complements the Bureau's role in assessing, through well established consultation processes, unmet demand, as discussed in the response to Recommendation 1 (Recommendation 4b). In view of the above, recommendation 4c is not supported.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 5

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Government provide appropriate support to establish links with relevant activities, notably the proposed United Nations Research Institute for Social Development Conference on Globalization and Citizenship to be held in Australia this year and the various civics and education programs.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Response:

SPEECH.PARA: The recommendation is supported.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Comments:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government recognises the value of international and national conferences in shaping priorities for possible community and government action and expects that relevant agencies would participate in and act on developments, as appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —Generally speaking, this is a very disappointing but not surprising response from the government to what the Senate considered to be a very important matter. I know one person who will be more disappointed than anybody else, but who is not here to share in the disappointment—that is, former Senator Sid Spindler from the Victorian Democrats who did not recontest his seat at the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee presented to the parliament in April of this year is one of the many legacies of former Senator Spindler. I am sure that he, along with most members of the committee, would be disappointed with the government response. The response has a good opening which states:
The Government expresses its appreciation to the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee for its report . . .
The response goes on to state:

The Government recognises that a sound system of social statistics is vital to the effective development of social policy, to informed decision making on policy issues and to the evaluation of the impact of social and economic policy. Reliable and well focused social statistics are also vital for informing public debate both within countries and at an international level.

The committee made five specific recommendations that would have carried out that objective but, unfortunately, the government has seen fit to reject or, in some cases, accept in part what the committee has recommended. Recommendation No. 1 of the committee was:
. . . the Australian Bureau of Statistics be resourced to carry out a two stage audits of its collection of statistics on human well-being . . .
The government accepts that there is a need for such an audit but, unfortunately, when it comes to additional resources they are not going to be found. The response states:

BREAK.PARA: While additional funding might expedite the audit process the Government is satisfied that existing processes within the ABS will address the Committee's concerns. The Government therefore does not intend to provide additional funding.
Recommendation No. 2 of the committee was:
. . . that the Australian Bureau of Statistics be resourced to collect relevant data and develop indicators in the area of social and political participation.
The government has responded by stating:

The Government has asked the ABS to establish, in consultation with other relevant agencies, the level and nature of unmet demand for information in the area of social and political participation and to assess its priority in the context of the overall ABS work program.
The response goes on to state:

While the government acknowledges the Committee's findings . . . that there are gaps in statistical information relating to the area of social and political participation, valuable indicators of levels of participation in important domains of social life are available from existing sources.
Recommendation No. 3 of the committee was:

. . . that the Australian Government give high priority to the establishment of a National System of Indicators and Benchmarks, capable of measuring performance in the area of legal, economic, social and cultural significance.
Recommendation Nos 3 and 4 are taken together. Recommendation No. 4 of the committee was:
. . . that the Government take the following steps towards implementing a National System of Indicators and Benchmarks . . .
The government responded by stating:

The government does not intend to establish a formal National System of Indicators and Benchmarks. Rather, it considers that national indicators and benchmarks should be developed progressively and that, initially, these are best advance in the context of the COAG review—
the Council of Australian Government review—
of Commonwealth/State service provision and other Commonwealth/State Government initiatives.
The government goes on to comment:
Indicators and benchmarks are currently being developed in a number of areas.

The response mentions the government service provision report which was released on 20 December 1995. It says that a second report of that review will be released in February 1997. I am sure all senators will wait with bated breath to see what is contained in that report. In relation to recommendation No. 4, the government states:

Recommendation 4 proposes steps towards implementing a National System of Indicators and Benchmarks. While additional resources will not be committed to this task, the Government considers that the ABS, as the national statistical agency, is best placed to perform the role of drawing together and reporting on the indicators of social well‐being and associated benchmarks . . .
Of course, as was indicated earlier, there are no additional resources to be given to the ABS. The committee did score some success with recommendation No. 5. We recommended:

. . . that the Government provide appropriate support to establish links with relevant activities, notably the proposed United Nations Research Institute for Social Development Conference on Globalisation and Citizenship to be held in Australia this year and the various civics and education programs.
The government supported that and stated that it:

. . . recognises the value of international and national conferences in shaping priorities for possible community and government action and expects that relevant agencies would participate in and act on developments, as appropriate.

I am disappointed that Sid Spindler is not in this place to make his contribution to the government response. I think he would be criticising me for being kind in my criticisms of the government for delivering what could be described as a very weak response to a unanimous report by a parliamentary committee. I believe it was deserving of a better response than that which has been given. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods, Sen Bob

TALKER.NAME: Senator WOODS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Community Affairs References Committee on psychotherapeutic medication in Australia. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: GOVERNMENT'S RESPONSE TO REPORT OF THE SENATE COMMUNITY AFFAIRS REFERENCES COMMITTEE—PSYCHOTHERAPEUTIC MEDICATION IN AUSTRALIA
Overview of Government's Response

SPEECH.PARA: Overall, the Government agrees with the basic tenets of the Report of the Senate Community Affairs References Committee, "Psychotherapeutic Medication in Australia", namely, that it is important to:
. encourage a range of medical and non‐medical services and therapies in the treatment of people with mental illness;
. ensure an effective allocation and use of resources, particularly in relation to the mental health workforce; and
. ensure more stringent monitoring of the prescription and use of psychotherapeutic medication.
The Government has responded to most of the recommendations individually, although some responses have been combined when similar issues were involved.

The Government supports all of the recommendations of the Report, except recommendation 15, and it only partly supports recommendation 12. While agreeing with the principles behind recommendation 15, the Government does not support the specific reporting and data collection activities associated with this recommendation. There are also limitations to some of the information that is published in the Australian Statistics on Medicines (under recommendation 12).

In considering its response to this Report, the Government noted that many of the Report's recommendations are currently being implemented through initiatives related to the National Mental Health Strategy (NMHS). This is acknowledged in the foreword to the Report.

The NMHS is a joint Commonwealth-state initiative which commenced in January 1993, shortly after the commencement of Senate Inquiry into Psychotherapeutic Medication in Australia. An overview of the NMHS is provided at Attachment A .

A number of the recommendations of the Report relate to the planning and delivery of mental health services, in which states and territories have a major role. All state and territory health ministers have been encouraged to take into account relevant recommendations of the Report in the future planning of mental health services.

A number of the Report's recommendations also involve pharmaceutical issues, in which the Commonwealth has a significant role. Background information on relevant pharmaceutical policies and advisory bodies is provided at Attachment B.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Detailed Response to Recommendations
Recommendation 1

That a national assessment be made of the number of people with a psychiatric disability who require access to appropriate Home and Community Care Program services. In this context, "disability" means a long‐term effect which limits the capacity of the person requiring services to provide those services himself/herself.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees that more information is necessary to ensure that people with mental disorders and associated psychiatric disability receive access to appropriate health and family services.

Under the NMHS, a "National Survey of Mental Health and Wellbeing" is currently being developed (see also the response to recommendation 6). The survey is expected to estimate how many Australians have specific mental disorders, what disablement is associated with these disorders, and what use is made of health and family services.

The survey is expected to be conducted in early 1997. Survey results will be available for analysis. Subject to the continuing development of the survey design, the survey results are expected to enable some assessment of the number of people with a psychiatric disability requiring access to support services to help them sort out practical issues such as housing and money problems.

The Home and Community Care (HACC) Program provides financial assistance to basic maintenance and support services for people living in the community who are at risk of premature or inappropriate long‐term residential care. The Program is not currently aimed at funding specialist psychiatric services. The presence or absence of psychiatric disability, per se, is not taken into account in determining a person's need for services funded under the HACC Program.

The demand for HACC funded services is estimated using data on recipients of HACC services, together with Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) data on moderately, severely or profoundly handicapped people living in households. It is possible to use ABS data on moderately, severely or profoundly handicapped people in households to establish how many people living in the community have a difficulty or need personal help or supervision with self care, mobility and verbal communication.People with a psychiatric disability would be included in this population and some of those people would require access to appropriate HACC funded services. However, as the HACC Program does not fund specific disability services, where services would be specialist or intensive in nature, the need for information about the nature of a person's disability, as opposed to the level of that person's handicap, is not really relevant for effective service planning and delivery.

HACC funded services are but one part of a network of support available to those in need and the demand for HACC services is influenced by the dynamics of this network. Accordingly, data obtained on the numbers of people with a particular level of disability or handicap, are not necessarily indicative of a need for HACC funded services. A range of other factors, including the availability of informal support, as well as the cost effectiveness of community versus residential care, must be taken into account.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 2

That, without invading privacy, there be an assessment by qualified personnel to estimate the number of people with psychiatric illness who access the Supported Accommodation and Assistance Program services.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government supports this recommendation .

In the new National Data Collection for the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program (SAAP), to commence on 1 July 1996, there will be a client data question relating to mental health status. As with any data collection, privacy of the client remains paramount and protocols will be in place to ensure that the collection complies with the requirements of the Privacy Act. The effectiveness of this question will rely heavily on clients' willingness to self identify.

Under its case management strategy, SAAP will be assessing and referring clients to other support services as deemed appropriate. While training of SAAP workers in assessment remains a key strategy of SAAP, it is nevertheless clear that any specialist services needed by clients with mental health problems will need to be provided by referral to other agencies. It is estimated that a significant number of people currently using SAAP services present with some form of mental illness or psychiatric disability, including as a result of substance abuse.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 3
That appropriate accommodation services be a priority for people with psychiatric disability. Such services must address the needs of people in all age groups.

The Government supports this recommendation in‐principle, although the provision of housing and accommodation support for people with psychiatric disability is primarily the responsibility of state and territory governments. It is also important that accommodation services address the special needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

SPEECH.PARA: The key point is that, under the Commonwealth/ State Disability Agreement (CSDA), state and territory governments are responsible for the administration of accommodation and other support services for people with a disability (other than nursing homes and hostels for aged people), while the Commonwealth is responsible for the administration of employment services.

The Agreement gives both levels of government (Commonwealth and state and territory) joint responsibility for funding disability services, but does not provide for funds to be tied to particular services, models of service or target groups.

The CSDA is currently being reviewed, to examine the effectiveness and efficiency of service provision under the current Agreement and to assist in developing new Commonwealth/State arrangements for disability service provision, to come into effect when the current Agreement ends on 30 June 1997.

The review is being conducted by an independent consultant, Professor Anna Yeatman, of Macquarie University, who will report to the Commonwealth and state and territory ministers for disability services. An interim report was published in February 1996, with a final report due to ministers in mid 1996.
The recommendations of the Report on "Psychotherapeutic Medication in Australia" have been passed to Professor Yeatman for consideration in the context of her review.

One of the objectives of the NMHS is to increase the number and range of community‐based supported accommodation services to ensure a level of support which is appropriate to the needs of consumers. State and territory governments may use mental health reform and incentive funding (provided by the Commonwealth) to enhance these services.

In addition, the Mental Health Forum on Intersectoral Linkages (established by health, housing and community services ministers at both Commonwealth and state and territory levels) examined the effectiveness of existing links between the health, housing and disability services sectors in meeting the needs of people with mental illness and associated psychiatric disability. The Forum's report (entitled "Report of the Mental Health Forum on Intersectoral Linkages—July 1995") contains 24 recommendations to enhance linkages between these three sectors at the Commonwealth, state/territory and regional/local levels. The report was accepted by ministers and consideration is being given on how best to implement the recommendations.

In a broader housing context, the Department of Health and Family Services (HFS) recognises the importance of appropriate accommodation services for homeless people with a psychiatric disability, or for people at risk of homelessness.

As a consequence, HFS is funding several boarding house pilot projects from SAAP reform funds to provide outreach services for people in boarding houses, particularly those with a psychiatric disability. The people assisted through these pilots are recognised as very vulnerable in terms of possibly falling into homelessness.

While SAAP services are available to people with a psychiatric disability, the legislation which governs SAAP specifies that the program is unable to provide or duplicate services and assistance which are the responsibility of any other government programs or services (unless otherwise agreed jointly by the Commonwealth and state or territory ministers). Examples of such services include those which cater predominantly for clients requiring substitute care or specialised clinical treatment, or exclusive services for people with a disability (including psychiatric disability).

However, in recognition of the fact that a significant number of people currently using SAAP services do have psychiatric problems, the Commonwealth has directed that a proportion of SAAP reform moneys be directed to developing better ways of meeting the needs of these clients. Through the introduction of quality case management standards generally in SAAP, greater emphasis will be placed on ensuring that clients with mental illness and psychiatric disability are effectively linked with existing support and specialist services, both state and Commonwealth.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendations 4 and 5

SPEECH.PARA: 4. That annual reports be provided under the National Mental Health Strategy on the provision of services for people of non‐English speaking and Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander background.
5. That estimates be made in these reports of the number of persons requiring and obtaining services, and of the development of culturally and linguistically appropriate services.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Government agrees that better information is desirable in these areas and is taking steps to improve it.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Mental Health Report (produced under the NMHS) does not currently include specific performance indicators that identify specialised mental health service provision for people of non-English speaking and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander backgrounds. However, performance indicators are reviewed on an annual basis after the publication of each report. The next review will consider the feasibility of including specific mental health service provision indicators for people of non-English speaking and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander backgrounds.

At present, the National Mental Health Report provides aggregate information which is primarily based on a survey of individual mental health services. It does not collect patient level data associated with the supply of mental health services or data on the demand or need for those mental health services (as suggested in recommendation 5).

However, there is a proposal that a national mental health minimum data set be developed within the framework of the National Health Information Agreement. Such a data set would be expected to include patient level data items. To date, definitional work has occurred and been included in the National Mental Health Report processes. Two data elements (psychiatric days in care and legal status) have also been included in the National Health Data Dictionary and will be added to the institutional health care minimum data set from 1 July 1996. Work on furthering the concept of a minimum data set is continuing.

Schedule F of the Medicare Agreements sets out the conditions under which Commonwealth mental health reform and incentive funding is provided to the states and territories, as well as the roles and responsibilities of both the Commonwealth and the states and territories in implementing the NMHS.

The original Schedules covered funding provided in the 1992‐93 Budget. The Schedules have been revised to incorporate the additional funding provided in the 1994‐95 Budget.Under the revised Schedule F of the Medicare Agreements, which have been agreed with all states and territories, Commonwealth funding is available to states and territories on the basis of sufficient progress against performance targets agreed between the Commonwealth and each state/territory. Consistent with the original Schedules, states and territories will continue to be required to maintain current levels of expenditure on mental health services. The four indicator areas under the revised Schedules are:
. access to appropriate services;
. consumer participation and rights;
. service quality; and
. catering for special needs groups.

It is expected that broad indicators and targets for the development of culturally and linguistically appropriate services for people from non-English speaking and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander backgrounds would be established in the area of catering for special needs groups.

The HFS has contracted the establishment of a national network on mental health issues for people from non-English speaking backgrounds (known as the "Australian Transcultural Mental Health Network") to the Victorian Transcultural Psychiatry Unit. Establishment funding is being provided for three years from NMHS funds, after which time it is expected that the Network will become self-supporting.

The Network's key role is the co‐ordination and dissemination of information on mental health to the non-English speaking background community and relevant mental health workers. The Network will also undertake a number of specific projects to improve mental health services to the non-English speaking background community. Two projects, relevant to these recommendations, are expected to commence in mid 1996. They are:
. development of methods for engaging non-English speaking background communities in partnership in mental health service development; and
. development of methods for estimating the needs of non-English speaking background communities for mental health services.

Community and consumer involvement is fundamental to the development and management of the Network. This will ensure that the functions of the Network are responsive to the needs of non-English speaking background communities.An allocation of $2 million has been approved under the NMHS for national initiatives related to mental health issues for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. A key priority is improved data collection and the Senate Committee's recommendations will be taken into account in developing initiatives.

However, there are currently no reliable ways of ascertaining the number of indigenous people presenting for service. There are problems with data collection in communities of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders due to the sensitivity of the information requested.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 6

That the Department of Human Services and Health occasionally provide reports on studies relevant to Australian circumstances which have been undertaken on the relationship between socio‐economic status and mental health.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government supports this recommendation .
Under the NMHS, a "National Survey of Mental Health and Wellbeing" is currently being developed. The survey aims to:
. estimate the prevalence of the main categories of mental disorder and of significant psychological symptoms in the Australian population;
. determine the amount of disablement associated with those disorders; and
. determine service utilisation by persons with mental
disorders, including an estimation of unmet need.

The survey will comprise three studies: an adult study using a national household survey methodology with a sample of 10,000 households of those aged over 18 years; a child and adolescent study of between 3,000-5,000 of those aged 4-17 years; and a low prevalence (psychosis) disorders study, providing a catchment based sample of between 700-900 people.

It is expected that results will start to become available in mid 1997. Survey results will be available for analysis and should enable linkages with socio‐economic status to be examined. Occasional reports are likely to be published.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 7

That there be a specific program to facilitate the awareness of psychiatric illness in rural, regional and remote communities. This should include education and information packages on psychotherapeutic medication, including videos, tele-conferencing workshops and seminars by specialist teams.
The Government supports this recommendation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government acknowledges the need for improved access to effective mental health services for people living in rural Australia. This need continues to be addressed through the National Rural Health Strategy in which mental health is specified as a priority area under recommendation 10 of the Strategy document.

Consistent with this priority, mental health has been nominated as a priority area in several funding rounds of grants under the Rural Health Support, Education and Training (RHSET) Program. Since the RHSET Program's establishment in 1990, 33 grants (at a cost of $3.1 million) have been approved to develop mental health educational resources and training programs for rural health care providers.

The RHSET mental health projects include distance education programs for rural nurses and other health and community service providers, educational videos, and a pilot project involving regular visits to a rural region from academic psychiatrists who share patient care and provide training for local health professionals. Five of the above projects specifically target Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

In addition to the specific mental health projects, 10 other RHSET projects (at a cost of $422,700) have been funded to increase the knowledge and skills of rural pharmacists and other health care providers in the use of medications, of which psychotherapeutic medications are an important component. These pilot projects are developing and documenting initiatives in which pharmacists work more closely with, and provide training for, other rural health professionals to improve medication use.

Following completion of these pilot projects, the outcomes will be widely disseminated to employers, rural health professional peak bodies and practitioners to encourage further take‐up and mainstreaming of successful initiatives.

The need for education and information packages to be culturally and linguistically appropriate for use by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people will be taken into account.Funding of $108,640 over two years has been approved under the NMHS to support the establishment of a Rural and Remote Mental Health Clearinghouse. This clearinghouse will enhance the general role already filled by the Australian Rural Health Research Institute (ARHRI) in acting as a clearinghouse for rural and remote health research and information about education and training initiatives for rural and remote area health workers.

The Rural and Remote Mental Health Clearinghouse is expected to disseminate a broad range of information relevant to the needs of mental health consumers, families and carers, service providers, policy makers and planners. This will include information on service models, mental health programs and projects, management information, evaluation practices and outcomes, indigenous mental health, and service planning frameworks.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 8

That educational institutions and professional bodies be encouraged to emphasise training for general practitioners, nurses, psychologists and other community workers (including police and teachers) in psychiatric illness.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government supports this recommendation .

The NMHS recognises that general practitioners (GPs) and other primary care workers are often the initial point of contact for people with mental health problems, and therefore, have an important role in helping people with mental health problems.

The Strategy also recognises that considerable attention needs to be given to increasing the skills, at both undergraduate and graduate level, of primary health care providers to strengthen their capacity for early detection, diagnosis, treatment and, where appropriate, referral of people to specialised mental health services. Workers in other sectors, such as police and teachers, can assist in the identification and referral of people with mental health problems and can participate in their management.

PARA.EMPHASIS: General Practitioners

SPEECH.PARA: The HFS is providing funding of $200,000 under the NMHS to enable the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP) and the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists (RANZCP) to improve education and training for GPs in the mental health area. This initiative will develop new mental health curricula for GPs undertaking vocational training and continuing medical education, which will assist GPs to adopt enhanced roles in mental health care.

The RACGP conducts the only vocational training program for doctors wishing to practice as GPs. This training program is funded annually by the HFS. One of the outcomes identified in the current training program contract with the RACGP is that the College will "develop a strategy to provide appropriate training in mental health for all trainees within the broader framework of the training program". The mental health education and training initiative (described above) forms part of this strategy.

The Commonwealth is also providing funding under the NMHS (approximately $93,000) to the Victorian and South Australian Governments to trial different education and training programs aimed at enhancing the knowledge and skills of GPs in the treatment of people with serious mental illness. Reports on these education and training projects are expected to be available in late 1996. In addition, the HFS has allocated funding of $1.35 million over the years, 1995‐96 to 1998‐99, for demonstration projects to support GPs and community health personnel in identifying, referring and treating young people with mental illness and young people at risk of suicide. These projects are expected to build on existing education and training initiatives for GPs in the area of youth suicide prevention. Although focusing on GPs, it is expected that the education and training initiatives might also have applications for other community mental health personnel (e.g. nurse practitioners, psychologists, mental health nurses, occupational therapists and social workers).

PARA.EMPHASIS: Specialist mental health service providers

SPEECH.PARA: A mental health education and training consultancy was established to assist the Australian Health Ministers' Advisory Council (AHMAC) National Mental Health Working Group in the development of a national approach to education and training of specialist staff working in the mental health area, and make recommendations on the continuing training needs of existing personnel in mental health services.

The consultancy involved extensive research and consultation with a wide range of organisations in the mental health field, including academic institutions and professional bodies representing psychiatrists, mental health nurses, psychologists, social workers and occupational therapists.

After considering both the recommendations of the consultancy report and comments received from over 60 organisations in response to the report, the AHMAC National Mental Health Working Group has recommended the development of a co-operative approach, involving professional associations, educational bodies, service providers, consumers and carers, to influence the education and training of mental health professionals. These recommendations are currently being implemented.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Non‐specialist service providers

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Mental Health Community Awareness Program (CAP), which is being conducted as part of the NMHS, school children and their teachers have been identified as a critical target audience. An audit of education resources currently available in schools, relevant to the teaching of mental health issues, was completed in February 1996. The HFS is considering the feasibility of conducting a pilot schools' mental health program and developing a new mental health curriculum for teachers and students under the CAP. The CAP will also be researching, developing and implementing a specific youth strategy during 1996. These strategies will complement information and education provided to the general public via the mainstream electronic media promotion and the distribution of CAP Information Kits.

In October 1995, the HFS launched a new training package called "One in Five". This consists of a 24 minute video accompanied by a facilitator's handbook. The video is an extended interview with a young consumer of mental health services who discusses his experience of mental illness, societal response to that illness and his approach to overcoming attitudes to his condition.

The video is generically targeted at a service provider audience, primarily officers from the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. However, its structure is such that the package can be used in a variety of training contexts, or even as a stand-alone documentary.

"One in Five" has been distributed to occupational health and safety, equal employment opportunity, and staff counselling officers in a range of Commonwealth departments and agencies. The video has also been distributed to trainers of state and territory government employees and to those responsible for police education and training, via state and territory mental health services.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Other initiatives

SPEECH.PARA: The HFS is currently developing guidelines to support the Department's policies and priorities for its involvement in competency based education and training for the external health and community workforce. Where relevant, the HFS will promote the inclusion in training programs of competencies related to working with people with mental illness through the appropriate industry training advisory boards.

In response to a number of recent fatal shootings by police of people with mental illness, the Government agrees that there is a need for urgent national action to address this and other crisis intervention management issues.

The Commonwealth has convened an expert group to share information about existing crisis intervention systems and police and mental health worker training procedures, with a view to identifying good practice in the way police and mental health services cooperate to resolve mental health crisis situations and in training for those likely to be involved in crisis situations. The group will report with recommendations for the consideration of health and police ministers in mid 1996.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 9
That crisis teams be recognised as an important component of emergency care.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government supports this recommendation .

The NMHS recognises that an integrated and comprehensive mental health service must cater for both acute and emergency episodes and long-term needs. Services for those experiencing acute and emergency episodes would include acute hospital care, community and home-based acute care, emergency assessment and day treatment. Crisis teams, operating on a 24 hour mobile basis, are an important component of this care.

Under the NMHS, state and territory governments are responsible for the planning and provision of specialised public sector mental health services, including acute and emergency care. All states and territories have recently established or expanded their crisis services, with many using mental health reform and incentive funding (provided by the Commonwealth) to supplement their own funding.Recommendations 10, 11, 26 and 27
10. That specialist teams be established as a matter of priority to meet the needs of people of non‐English speaking background.
11. That funding continue to be specifically devoted to developing teams and services to meet the needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

26. That both community and hospital psychiatric health services take all measures necessary to provide culturally and linguistically appropriate services, especially where these will help limit inappropriate service provision.

27. That both community and residential psychiatric health services identify the specific needs of special groups (including young people, older people, the homeless) in their service area and develop strategies to meet these needs.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Government supports these recommendations and recognises that services and strategies to meet better the needs of these groups should be developed in consultation with agencies and organisations representing special needs groups.

SPEECH.PARA: Provision of services that are responsive to the special needs of particular groups (including people from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander and non-English speaking backgrounds, young people, older people and the homeless) is a key element of the NMHS.

While provision of these services is primarily the responsibility of state and territory governments, some states and territories have used mental health reform and incentive funding (provided by the Commonwealth) to plan for, or enhance service provision to these groups.

In addition, a high proportion of the $5.5 million in grants funded by the Commonwealth under the innovative grants program is for services for people with special needs. (The Commonwealth's innovative grants program is described in more detail in the response to recommendation 22).

PARA.EMPHASIS: People from non‐English speaking backgrounds

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Transcultural Mental Health Network (referred to in the response to recommendations 4 and 5) will undertake specific projects to improve mental health services to the non-English speaking background community. Two of these projects are expected to commence in mid 1996. They involve:
. the development of methods for engaging non-English speaking background communities in partnership in mental health service development; and
. the development of methods for estimating the needs of non-English speaking background communities for mental health services.

As discussed in the response to recommendation 8, a mental health education and training consultancy was also established to assist the AHMAC National Mental Health Working Group in the development of a national approach to education and training of staff working in the mental health area, and make recommendations on the continuing training needs of existing personnel in mental health services.

During the consultations, a range of stakeholders and professional groups commented upon the need for all mental health staff to become more aware of the cultural sensitivities and traditions of consumers and carers, and to provide culturally appropriate forms of treatment. One specific suggestion that emerged from the consultations was for mental health professionals to become more skilled in the use of interpreters when dealing with consumers and carers from non-English speaking backgrounds.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people

SPEECH.PARA: In recognition of the special needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities is to be conducted prior to the funding of services for this group.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Older people

SPEECH.PARA: In September 1995, the AHMAC National Mental Health Working Group endorsed a Scoping Study on Mental Health and Older People. The study is making a diagnostic examination of the types of accommodation, care and treatment currently being provided for older people with a mental illness and the nature and dimensions of that client group. The study will identify any work which needs to be done to deal with access of this client group to appropriate care.

The study is jointly funded by the mental health and aged care programs of the HFS. A working party, comprising mental health and aged care representatives from Commonwealth and state and territory governments, consumers and data experts, is undertaking the project.

The report on stage one of the study, including a proposed work program for any further work, is expected to be presented to, and considered by, the AHMAC National Mental Health Working Group at its July 1996 meeting.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 12
That Australian Statistics on Medicines provide information on the following issues as part of its annual reports:
. Measures undertaken to ensure that prescribed drugs are the most appropriate available for the individual and for the condition;
. Details of procedures for monitoring patients on long-term medication;
. Survey of prescribers and consumers to establish their awareness of the range and effects of the prescribed drugs;
. Research undertaken to minimise adverse effects of medication;
. Surveys conducted to establish whether consumers and prescribers are aware that there is often a range of drugs available for some illnesses; and
. Monitoring of quantity of drugs prescribed by individual prescribers.
The Government only partly supports this recommendation.
Measures undertaken to ensure that prescribed drugs are the most appropriate available for the individual and for the condition.

SPEECH.PARA: The Drug Utilisation Sub-Committee (DUSC), which collects and analyses data on the use of prescription medicines in the Australian community, seeks to identify potential health problems and benefits related to these patterns of drug utilisation.

There are, however, important limitations to the information that is available to the Sub-Committee and subsequently published in the Australian Statistics on Medicines (ASM). Firstly, these are aggregate data only and, at present, they cannot be reliably assigned to an individual. Additionally, there is no information to link the prescribed drug to the reason for its use or to the diagnosis of the patient's condition. This information needs to be obtained from patient-GP encounter surveys.

Reviews on the utilisation of drugs or therapeutic groups of drugs and advice on changes in drug utilisation patterns, as a consequence of changes in drug availability or restrictions on drug use, are provided to the parent committee, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). Recommendations concerning therapeutic drug groups thought appropriate for development of an educational intervention are referred to the Pharmaceutical Health And Rational use of Medicines (PHARM) Committee.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Details of procedures for monitoring patients on long-term medication.

SPEECH.PARA: This procedure would ideally be operative at the level of the general practitioner. At present, automated prescription drug databases, as mentioned above, cannot reliably track an individual's drug use—in the case of the general beneficiary, only a name and address are provided. These are notoriously difficult to match, particularly if hand-written. For social security patients, this may be possible in the near future when a new patient identification number is installed at the Health Insurance Commission. This would still only allow analysis at an aggregate level, i.e. the number of patients on long‐term therapy could be determined, but patients could not be individually identified (since the data available to the HFS by legislation cannot identify individuals).

PARA.EMPHASIS: Survey of prescribers and consumers to establish their awareness of the range and effects of the prescribed drugs.

SPEECH.PARA: ASM is entirely quantitative and consists of two large tables of drug utilisation statistics. Any qualitative surveys involving prescribers or consumers would have to be considered by PHARM and the HFS in the context of other drug research priorities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Research undertaken to minimise adverse effects of medication.
Surveys conducted to establish whether consumers and prescribers are aware that there is often a range of drugs available for some illnesses.

SPEECH.PARA: A combined response is provided to these two sub‐recommendations.

DUSC has access to data from the Adverse Drug Reaction Advisory Committee (ADRAC) on voluntary reports from health professionals of suspected adverse drug reactions. Recommendations can be made to restrict the access to medications that show increased risk of adverse reactions overall, or in certain groups, such as the elderly. Once again, these are population not individual patient level studies.
Patient level cohort studies need to be co-ordinated at the patient-doctor level. These studies would need to be co-ordinated through PHARM, as would a consumer‐prescriber survey.

The Australian Pharmaceutical Advisory Council (APAC) has established a Working Party which is exploring the potential for consumer involvement in reporting of adverse drug events. The Working Party is developing recommendations on ways to improve the information flow from consumers to their health professionals and other relevant parties, regarding their experiences while taking medication. This could contribute to better post-marketing surveillance of pharmaceutical products, which may assist in reducing the incidence of adverse drug events.

The PHARM Evaluation Sub‐committee has developed a manual of indicators to measure the effect of quality use of medicines (QUM) initiatives. A number of indicators in the manual are designed to measure the availability and usage of educational programs and established reporting and feedback mechanisms for adverse drug reactions used by both prescribers and consumers. Indicators have also been developed to measure the improvement of QUM by consumers by gauging their knowledge and actions relating to the appropriate use of medicines. Research is currently underway on data collection options for these indicators. The use of consumer and prescriber surveys is one such option.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Monitoring of quantity of drugs prescribed by individual prescribers.
