SPEECH.PARA: DUSC conducts analyses based on the prescribing of particular drugs by individual prescribers. A much wider project is currently underway at the Health Insurance Commission whereby individual doctors are being notified of their prescribing relative to that of full-time practitioners for the country as a whole. About 2500 full time general practitioners working in non-urban centres in Australia are participating in the trial. All participating doctors receive information on their prescribing and the comparison of their prescribing patterns with the national average on five main drugs, namely ACE inhibitors, anti-ulcer drugs, hypolipidaemics, antibiotics and NSAIDs.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 13

That research be done in conjunction with the Drug Utilisation Sub‐Committee (DUSC) to assess the relationship between the current levels of prescription of psychotherapeutic medication and the extent of psychiatric illness or disability in the community. Excluded from consideration is psychotherapeutic medication prescribed for people whose major illness/ disability is intellectual disability or brain injury, since this requires separate study and specialist consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government supports this recommendation .

DUSC maintains comprehensive data on the community use of prescribed psychotherapeutic medications. The extent of psychiatric illness or disability in the community is more problematic, although the proposed epidemiological survey (referred to in the response to recommendation 6) is expected to provide valuable information in this area.

Some efforts have been made to estimate the prevalence of various disorders, based on available survey data and attempts to correlate this with drug utilisation data. The measurement unit in this situation is the World Health Organisation (WHO) approved unit—the defined daily dose (DDD) per 1000 of the population per day. The defined daily dose is established on the basis of the assumed average dose per day of the drug, used for its main indication by adults. Use of the DDD allows for comparisons independent of differences in price, preparation and quantity per prescription. For a chronically administered drug, this unit gives a rough estimate of the prevalence of its use in the community, given a number of important caveats.

Depression : 12.391 defined daily doses/1000 population/day were dispensed for antidepressants in 1990, which would equate to around 211,454 persons on continuous medication at the DDD. The 1989‐90 Australian Bureau of Statistics National Health Survey (NHS) estimate, based on self-reports, was 110,500 persons. It is important to note that if the prescribed daily dose in Australia is higher than the DDD, then the estimate of treated persons based on drug utilisation would fall. The lower estimate from the NHS may result from people either sensitive to reporting this condition or previously depressed but not considering themselves currently or recently affected.

Anxiety and insomnia : 33.975DDD/1000/day for benzodiazepines were dispensed in 1990, which equates to 579,787 persons on the DDD continuously. A previous DUSC report had examined benzodiazepine utilisation in the 1989‐90 NHS and estimated that there were over 750,000 users of benzodiazepines, of whom approximately 330,000 were using the drugs daily for 6 months or longer. This appears consistent with the drug utilisation data.

Also from the NHS (based on self-reports), there were an estimated 502,300 persons in Australia suffering from "nerves, tension, nervousness and emotional problems" and 524,100 persons reporting "insomnia". Use of the anxiolytic agents in 1990 was 16.029DDD/1000/day (almost exclusively benzodiazepines)—or enough to provide 273,536 people with a full adult dose every day. Use of the hypno-sedatives in 1990 was 18.691DDD/1000/day (benzodiazepine representing 96% of this usage)—enough to provide 318,964 people with a full adult dose every day. Information on the duration of therapy would be needed here, as this may represent larger numbers of people using drug therapy short‐term rather than long‐term.

Major psychoses: The NHS estimate, based on self-report of persons suffering from "psychoses" in 1989‐90, was 30,200. 1990 use of anti-psychotic agents dispensed through community pharmacies enough to supply 89,421 people with continuous adult doses. This may reflect how the information is elicited from the questionnaire, the insight of the respondee, the adequacy of capture of subjects with major psychoses in the sample or the adequacy of the DDD itself.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 14
That where hospitals (including general hospitals) do not already produce reports on admissions/re‐admissions of people with a psychiatric illness or disability, that they do so annually.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government supports this recommendation .

While the Government supports this recommendation, it should be noted that hospitals can only report on their own re‐admissions. Each hospital has its own medical record numbering system. Therefore, if a patient was admitted to hospital A and then re‐admitted to hospital B, it would not actually be recorded as a re‐admission. Subject to privacy issues, the HFS supports efforts towards the development of a common medical record number across hospitals or a way of linking episodes of care between different hospitals.

As part of the National Hospital Outcomes Program, the HFS has funded a research project to assess the validity and reliability of a quality of care indicator for the rate of unplanned re‐admissions within 28 days in general public hospitals. The development of a risk adjustment method in order to analyse the results is also part of the project. Hospitals will be involved in the piloting of the indicator. This project commenced in October 1995 and is expected to finish in May 1997.

As indicated in the response to recommendations 4 and 5, agreement has been reached between the Commonwealth and all states and territories to link Commonwealth funding under the NMHS to state and territory progress against agreed performance indicators and targets. The areas for development of indicators and targets are:
. access to appropriate services;
. consumer participation and rights;
. service quality; and
. catering for special needs groups.

One of the indicators in the area of service quality is the reduction in re‐admission rates for people with mental illness. Developmental work will commence in mid 1996 to enable admission and re‐admission information to be collected by all hospitals and summaries published annually in the National Mental Health Report.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 15
That reports be made available by the Department of Human Services and Health to determine:
. the percentage of re‐admissions resulting, primarily, from a failure to take medication; and
. the percentage of re‐admissions resulting, primarily, from other factors such as shortage of required support services in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not support this recommendation in its current form, but it will take into account re‐admission factors in developing indicators and targets for future reporting.

The HFS is unable to make such a report available. Firstly, the data that is supplied to the HFS does not include a patient identifier that could link admissions to re‐admissions. Secondly, each hospital (whether it be general or psychiatric) has its own medical record numbering system. Therefore, admissions from one hospital cannot be tracked to another hospital.

Reasons for admission such as failure to take medication or shortage of required support services in the community, are not routinely collected and coded by general hospitals. Therefore, a prospective study would need to be conducted to capture this information. Furthermore, the issue of how to determine the relationship between one admission and a previous admission has been widely debated. Clinicians can be unwilling to make such assessments.

However, as referred to in the response to recommendation 14, the HFS is funding a research project to test the reliability and validity of a quality of care indicator for the rate of unplanned re‐admissions within 28 days. This project commenced in October 1995 and is expected to finish in May 1997. If the indicator is shown to be reliable and valid, the HFS may consider providing reports on re‐admission rates within individual hospitals, allowing comparisons to be made between hospitals at a state, regional or hospital level.

As indicated in the response to recommendations 4, 5 and 14, agreement has also been reached between the Commonwealth and all states and territories to link Commonwealth funding under the NMHS to state and territory progress against agreed performance indicators and targets. The areas for development of indicators and targets are:
. access to appropriate services;
. consumer participation and rights;
. service quality; and
. catering for special needs groups.

One of the indicators in the area of service quality is the reduction in re‐admission rates for people with mental illness. Developmental work will commence in mid 1996 to enable admission and re‐admission information to be collected by all hospitals and summaries published annually in the National Mental Health Report.
This recommendation will be taken into account in further developing the indicators and targets.Recommendation 16

PARA.EMPHASIS: That training of GPs at undergraduate and graduate level involve raising awareness of services including psychology and psychiatric services available in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government supports this recommendation .

The NMHS recognises the importance of linkages between GPs and specialised mental health workers, such as psychiatrists and psychologists. The effectiveness of primary health care workers in dealing with people with mental health problems is improved when they have access to specialist support.

As referred to in the response to recommendation 8, the HFS is providing funding of $200,000 under the NMHS to enable the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP) and the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists (RANZCP) to improve education and training for GPs in the mental health area. This initiative will develop new mental health curricula for GPs undertaking vocational training and continuing medical education, which will assist GPs to adopt enhanced roles in mental health care.

An important part of this work will be to identify roles and "best practice" models for general practice in mental health care, including identifying how GPs can work in partnership with specialised mental health services and other support services. The project has a reference group which includes representatives of consumers, mental health nurses and psychologists.

While this work will focus on developing curricula for vocational and continuing medical education, there is the potential for aspects of this work to be incorporated into undergraduate medical curricula. The HFS will explore options for wider application of the mental health curricula in the future, in conjunction with the professional bodies and academic institutions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 17

That research undertaken into the prescription of psychotherapeutic medication should examine the relationship between education/information services and variations in the prescription of different groups of psychotherapeutic medications. The purpose of this additional work would be to monitor the effect of education of prescribers about adverse effects, and about the level of prescription of some substances.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government supports this recommendation .

The HFS is examining education issues related to prescribing by GPs. Psychotherapeutic prescribing has not been singled out for attention, but is part of an overall strategy to address unnecessary prescribing.

The Drug Utilisation Sub‐Committee (DUSC) database is currently being used to supply a number of research groups who are providing educational services to GPs. By analysing prescribing behaviour in study and control areas, the effect of these educational interventions can be evaluated. Funding for this type of research is available under the Pharmaceutical Education Program (PEP).
A number of projects have been funded under PEP addressing issues relating to psychotherapeutic medication. These include:
. an evaluation of the impact of the National Health and Medical Research Council's Guidelines for the Prevention and Management of Benzodiazepine Dependence;
. funding for TRANX to hold a National Conference on Benzodiazepines;
. funding for the Schizophrenia Fellowship of Victoria to develop and pilot a co-ordinated education program on the appropriate use of antipsychotic medications;
. a project to develop a Therapeutic Resource and Educational Network for Doctors (TREND), which provides feedback and education for doctors on drug and non-drug management;
. a project through the University of Queensland to optimise the quality of medicinal drug use in the elderly in long‐term care facilities;
. a project by Tony Wade and Associates on consumer, carer,
and prescriber strategies to enhance consumer compliance
with psychotropic medication;
. research by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners on the impact of peer education in the prescribing of sedatives and hypnotics by GPs; and
. a six month campaign by the Goldfields Women's Health Care Association, addressing minor tranquilliser use and abuse.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendations 18 and 25
18. That psychiatric health teams should be multi-disciplinary.

25. That any development of mental health care services ensure that community-based services include a range of staff to address effectively the extensive needs of communities for therapies other than medication.
Recommendations 18 and 25 both relate to the benefits of having a mix of staff (who can provide a range of skills and therapies) in addressing the complex needs of people with mental illness.
The Government supports these recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: The NMHS recognises that no single service or intervention is likely to achieve good outcomes for every person with a mental health problem. It is, therefore, essential that services are provided in a multi‐faceted and multi‐disciplinary manner. The Strategy recognises that psychiatrists, psychologists, mental health nurses, social workers, and occupational therapists are all key components of specialised mental health services. Collectively, these staff can offer a range of therapies (both medication and non-medication based) to assist people with mental illness.

Under the NMHS, states and territories are responsible for the planning and delivering of mental health services, which includes the way in which individual teams are organised. All states and territories are currently promote inter-disciplinary mental health teams, recognising that a mix of staff (and associated skills) is necessary for the effective treatment and care of people with mental illness.
The concept of inter-disciplinary mental health teams is also reflected in a number of national initiatives supported by the Commonwealth.

For example, the HFS is currently examining what kinds of education and training may be required for the mental health workforce to work in new models of mental health service delivery (which includes inter-disciplinary teams).
Several of the grants made under the innovative grants program of the NMHS also focus on integrated systems of mental health care and inter‐disciplinary teams, e.g.
. an on‐site training and placement program in integrated systems of mental health care.
. development of a inter‐disciplinary team for inner city homeless clients with mental health and/or drug and alcohol problems.
. development of a model for an integrated mental health service for Aboriginal people.
(The Commonwealth's innovative grants program is described in more detail in the response to recommendation 22).

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendations 19 and 20
19. That research be undertaken into both the rights and responsibilities of both service providers and service users.

20. That projects should address the psycho-social needs of the community, which identify key issues in the consumer rights area, especially in respect of community-based services, and which develop strategies to meet identified needs. In undertaking such research, due consideration should be given to research on related issues already undertaken in other countries, especially those such as Canada which has experience in the operation of multicultural services. Any funding allocated should be in accordance with clear priorities which recognise that substantial numbers of the population may be profoundly affected by psychiatric illness which does not have such obvious symptoms as do illnesses such as schizophrenia and bi-polar affective disorder.
The Government supports these recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the key documents underpinning the NMHS is the "Mental Health Statement of Rights and Responsibilities". This Statement, endorsed by all Australian health ministers in 1991, aims to ensure that consumers, carers, advocates, service providers and the community are aware of their rights and responsibilities and can be confident in exercising them. A number of research/development activities are currently underway under the NMHS to embody the principles contained in the Mental Health Statement of Rights and Responsibilities.
These include:
. development of model mental health legislation.
. development of national standards for mental health services.
. promotion of consumer and carer involvement in NMHS activities.
. promotion of mental health research.
Each of these initiatives is described below.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Development of model mental health legislation

SPEECH.PARA: The HFS has funded a project to assist states and territories to develop consistent mental health legislation. The work includes drafting model clauses to define and protect the rights and responsibilities for people with mental illness, identifying cross‐border anomalies, and developing legislative mechanisms for the transfer of people with a serious mental illness across borders.

The AHMAC National Mental Health Working Group has endorsed a set of principles to assist states and territories to develop consistent legislative arrangements for dealing with the transfer of patients to and from other states/territories.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Development of national standards for mental health services

SPEECH.PARA: The HFS is providing funding of $440,130 to a consortium of three organisations led by the Australian Council of Healthcare Standards (ACHS) for a project which focuses on identifying, developing and field trialling national standards for mental health services which have an outcomes orientation and a consumer focus.

The standards are intended to reflect the needs and interests of mental health consumers and serve the diverse needs of mental health services, including community‐based, hospital and integrated mental health services.
The project is being directed under the auspices of the AHMAC National Mental Health Working Group, with the consultants undertaking the following tasks under the project:
. conduct a thorough review of standards in Australia and internationally, and present summaries focusing on mental health and allied areas;
. develop and field trial service standards suitable for introduction on a national basis in mental health services;
. investigate approaches to ensure the implementation of standards nationally, incorporating an outcomes orientation; and

. present a final report and recommendations on national standards for mental health services. Recommendations will include strategies for implementation of the standards, approaches to assessment and accreditation, education programs about standards and ongoing review of standards.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Promotion of consumer and carer involvement in NMHS activities

SPEECH.PARA: Consumer advisory groups have been established at national and state and territory levels to provide advice on the implementation of the NMHS. These groups are representative of the range of mental health consumers and carers.
At the national level, the National Community Advisory Group (NCAG) has terms of reference mandating it to:
. provide advice on matters connected with mental health policy, programs and activities including their effect on people with mental illness;
. provide advice on the rights of consumers and carers;
. undertake education and awareness activities for mental health; and
. liaise with international, national and other bodies concerned with mental health consumer and carer issues.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Promotion of mental health research

SPEECH.PARA: Specific funding of $1.5 million, over three years, has been allocated under the Research and Development Grants Advisory Committee to support non-biomedical psycho-social research. The research projects funded are relevant to enhancing the provision of mental health and other services for people with a mental illness and/or their carers.

This supplements other research funding administered through the National Health and Medical Research Council's (NHMRC) Public Health Research and Development Committee (PHRDC), and the HFS administered Research and Development Grants Advisory Committee (RADGAC). Research of the type recommended by the Senate Committee could be supported through these programs subject to research proposals meeting standards of excellence required by a competitive system.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Other initiatives

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Consumers' Council has developed a draft national health consumers' charter covering public and private health services within the hospital and community environment with funding provided by the HFS. This follows consultations with consumer groups, clinicians, other health professionals and health administrators.

Key issues of concern to consumers are covered by the draft charter. These include planning for patients' continuing health or social care before discharge from hospital and the provision of information to patients about proposed health care treatments, including medication, before consent to treatment.
The draft charter is intended to encourage better partnership relationships between consumers and health service providers and contains both legal and humanitarian "rights".
The draft charter has been forwarded to the HFS to undertake consultations leading to its endorsement by major stakeholders and for the development of a complementary set of service standards.

In the context of consumers' rights to receive information and education about psychotherapeutic medication, it is relevant to note that under amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act, companies must now provide written patient information (Consumer Product Information or (CPI) for medications. CPI is required for all new prescription drugs and for variations to existing ones from January 1993, and all prescription drugs are to have CPI provided by January 2002. CPI requirements have also recently been introduced for Schedule 3 medications (non-prescription products sold only with advice from pharmacists).

This CPI must be consistent with the approved professional product information which is provided to doctors, and should be in a form that is useful and easily understood. The implementation of CPI has the potential to greatly enhance the quality use of medicines in the community. It will also assist consumers, in consultation with their professionals, to make better informed decisions about their health care.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 21
That research be continued on comparisons between the prescription by general practitioners and by psychiatrists of psychotherapeutic medications.
The Government supports this recommendation in‐principle.

SPEECH.PARA: The Drug Utilisation Sub‐Committee (DUSC) Secretariat now has access to the Commonwealth Register of Entitled Persons (CROMP) file which links the prescriber number on a prescription to the major specialty of practice of the doctor who has written the prescription. DUSC has conducted some pilot studies linking prescriber and provider numbers to determine the major specialty of the provider.
DUSC would consider future specific requests to undertake research in the area of psychotherapeutic medication.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 22
That both community and hospital/institutional services develop a range of therapies and services which meet the identified needs of the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government supports this recommendation .
The service reform objectives of the NMHS are focused on provision of a comprehensive range of mental health services responsive to the needs of regional or local populations.

While provision of public sector services is the responsibility of state and territory governments, the primary purpose of mental health reform and incentive funding (provided by the Commonwealth) is to assist states and territories to restructure services in line with the objectives of the NMHS.

In addition, the Commonwealth is providing NMHS funding (approximately $5.5 million) for a number of projects which contribute to the restructuring of mental health services in innovative ways. These initiatives were established as time‐limited demonstration projects only, and therefore, additional funding will not be available in the future.

Collectively, these innovative projects are promoting a range of therapies and services, which have been developed in response to identified community needs. Several projects are focusing on non‐medication based therapies, e.g. projects which aim to:
. develop, implement and evaluate a range of support and psycho‐social educational group programs targeting school age children who have a parent with a mental illness and their parents.
. develop a national model which will integrate people with psychiatric disabilities into their communities through community‐based arts projects.
. develop a peer counselling and support service for people who have experienced, are experiencing, or are at risk of experiencing a psychiatric disorder.
. encourage consumers who suffer from anxiety disorders and their carers to take an active part in their recovery through education and support.

A national demonstration program of "rooming‐in" models of mental health service delivery has recently been funded under the NMHS. 13 services are being funded at a cost of $1.27 million to enable comprehensive evaluation of this innovative approach to providing mental health services locally instead of admitting people to distant treatment facilities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 23

That the importance of the pharmacists' role be recognised and that the Commonwealth examine ways in which pharmacists can become more involved in the monitoring and review of psychotherapeutic medication prescribed for persons living in the community, for example, as part of psychiatric health care teams.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government supports this recommendation .

The Government actively supports pharmacists' professional role as part of the health care team. A number of the quality use of medicines projects funded under the Pharmaceutical Education Program (PEP) aim to enhance the professional role of pharmacists in counselling consumers and providing medication review services. Pharmacists will also be involved in providing Consumer Product Information (CPI) to consumers, along with professional counselling, which will strengthen their role in the health care team.

In April 1995, a new agreement was signed between the Commonwealth Government and community pharmacy, covering Government-pharmacy arrangements for the period to 30 June 2000. This agreement includes provision for supplementary allowances for additional professional services. Arrangements for using this professional allowance to remunerate pharmacists involved in medication management in residential care institutions are currently being developed.

The HFS, in liaison with the pharmacy profession and the Australian Pharmaceutical Advisory Council (APAC), will also explore the possibilities for using this allowance to assist pharmacists to become more involved in the monitoring and review of medications for people living in the community, including those on psychotherapeutic medications.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 24
That the Government examine ways in which access to clinical and counselling psychologists can be improved.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government supports this recommendation .
The Government recognises that clinical and counselling psychologists have an important role in mental health service delivery.

The proposed reforms of the health and community services system under the Council of Australian Government (COAG) will provide an opportunity to improve access to a range of medical and non‐medical services. In particular, the co‐ordinated care component of the system will assist people with longer term, intensive and/or complex needs to access the right mix of services required for their individual circumstances. Services to be provided could include community care, medical, allied health (which could include counselling and psychological services), pharmaceutical and hospital services, palliative care, long‐term rehabilitation, and residential care for the frail, aged and disabled.

In the meantime, the Commonwealth is continuing to work with the states and territories (through the AHMAC National Mental Health Working Group) on issues concerning the mental health workforce. However, employment of clinical and counselling psychologists in the public sector is the responsibility of state and territory governments.

PARA.EMPHASIS: ATTACHMENT A
Overview of the National Mental Health Strategy

SPEECH.PARA: Governments in Australia have acknowledged that many people with mental illness and psychiatric disability are amongst the most seriously disadvantaged groups in Australia.

In recognition of this, a framework to reform mental health services was endorsed by the Commonwealth and all state and territory health ministers in April 1992. Related documents are the National Mental Health Policy, the National Mental Health Plan, the Mental Health Statement of Rights and Responsibilities, and Schedule F of the Medicare Agreements. Together, these comprise the National Mental Health Strategy (NMHS).
The Coalition Government is committed to the continuation of the National Mental Health Strategy as the broad national framework for mental health policy and service provision.
The Strategy provides for the first time, a national framework to achieve mental health reform, and a commitment from all levels of government to work co-operatively in achieving this goal.
The aims of the Strategy are:
. to promote the mental health of the Australian community and, where possible, prevent the development of mental health problems and mental disorders;
. to reduce the impact of mental disorders on individuals,
families and the community; and
. to assure the rights of people with mental disorders.

The main principles of the Strategy are to move away from a mental health system based in large stand‐alone institutions, to place greater emphasis on integrated services relying extensively on community‐based services, and to advance the human rights of people with mental disorders.

Under the NMHS, the states and territories retain responsibility for the planning and delivery of specialised public sector mental health services, including both community and hospital-based services.

The Commonwealth's role includes encouraging a consistent approach to service delivery across the states and territories through the provision of substantial reform and incentive funds to the states and territories over the life of the Strategy, promoting reform in service delivery, and funding mental health research.

A proportion of the Commonwealth's funds supporting the implementation of the Strategy are retained by the Commonwealth to support national initiatives. Some of the key initiatives at the national level include:
. promotion of positive community attitudes towards people with mental illness;

. support for research and innovative services with a special emphasis on early intervention, strengthening provision of services in rural and remote Australia, and mental health promotion and illness prevention;
. workforce reform;
. development of consumer outcome measures;
. linking mental health services with other sectors;
. development of funding models and classification systems;
. improved mental health data;
. initiatives relevant to groups with special needs, e.g. people from non‐English speaking backgrounds, people from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander backgrounds, and rural and remote residents;
. development of national standards for mental health services;
. protection of human rights, including development of model mental health legislation; and
. the publication of annual reports on progress in implementing the Strategy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: ATTACHMENT B
Pharmaceutical Benefits Branch

SPEECH.PARA: Pharmaceutical Benefits Branch of the HFS encourages quality use of medicines through:
. the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC), which determines the clinical uses for products to be listed on the Schedule of Pharmaceutical Benefits;
. the Drug Utilisation Sub-Committee (DUSC) of the PBAC,
which monitors drugs usage patterns in Australia;

. administering the Pharmaceutical Education Program (PEP), which funds one-off projects focusing on the quality use of medicines by prescribers, pharmacists, nurses, consumers, industry and government;
. initiating and funding workshops and conferences involving consumers, health professionals and grantees, to promote networking on quality use of medicines issues;
. the Australian Pharmaceutical Advisory Council (APAC) and the Pharmaceutical Health And Rational use of Medicines (PHARM) Committee;
. publishing "Australian Prescriber", a therapeutic journal to assist health professionals with rational prescribing; and
. including cautions and notes in the Schedule of Pharmaceutical Benefits.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Advisory bodies

SPEECH.PARA: Various advisory bodies assist Pharmaceutical Benefits Branch of the HFS in implementing the quality use of medicines component of the National Medicinal Drug Policy.

The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) advises the Minister for Health and Family Services about the listing of new medicinal drug products, including the terms and conditions of each listing. The Drug Utilisation
Sub-Committee (DUSC) of the PBAC monitors the patterns and trends of drugs use and makes such utilisation data available publicly.

The Australian Pharmaceutical Advisory Council (APAC) is a major consultative forum representing health professionals, consumers, the pharmaceutical industry and the Commonwealth Government. APAC advises the Minister for Health and Family Services on all aspects of the National Medicinal Drug Policy. The recommendations of the "Psycho therapeutic Medication in Australia" Report have been brought to APAC's attention.

The Pharmaceutical Health And Rational use of Medicines (PHARM) Committee is an expert advisory body to the HFS on quality use of medicines issues. Its membership is drawn from general practice, pharmacy, health education and promotion, clinical pharmacology, the consumer movement, the pharmaceutical industry, nursing, behavioural science and government. The recommendations of the "Psychotherapeutic Medication in Australia" Report have also been brought to PHARM's attention.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Quality Use of Medicines Policy

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government is actively promoting the quality use of medicines. The Government has recognised the size and nature of the problems associated with inappropriate use of medicines and is committed to improving the situation.

The HFS and PHARM have jointly developed a policy on the quality use of medicines. This policy promotes the concept that members of the "medication team" (made up of doctors, pharmacists, nurses and consumers) each have a role to play in ensuring that Australians use medicines wisely.
The principles of the policy are:
. judicious use, ensuring that the best possible treatment plan is chosen;
. appropriate use, ensuring that when medicines are needed they are carefully selected, managed, monitored, and
reviewed; and
. safe use, minimising misuse, overuse, and under-use of medicines.
This is being achieved by:
. increasing understanding of the relative roles of both over-the-counter and prescription drug therapy, as well as natural and non-drug therapies in treating illness and maintaining health; and
. encouraging the appropriate choice of drug and dosage regimen when they are needed and providing people with the knowledge, skills and encouragement to use drugs wisely and safely.
Education is seen as the primary tool for achieving optimal use of medicines.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —In opening my comments I would remind everybody that the report on psychotherapeutic medication in Australia was the last report in which the late Senator Olive Zakharov had any involvement. As we all know, she had a major interest—like you, Madam Acting Deputy President Patterson—in the area of psychology, and it was an interest that was dear to her heart. Unfortunately, she died before the report was able to be presented. Today we have the tabling of the government response to this report.

SPEECH.PARA: When I look at the response to this report—the committee was given two copies under embargo—the first thing that strikes me is that on the front page is the date `July 1996'. I know the response has been a long time in coming, but I would ask: what the devil has the government been doing with a government response to a report dated July 1996? It is now December; four full months have elapsed. The government has presumably sat on this report doing nothing.

When I look inside the response document, I am quite heartened to see that the government has accepted most of our recommendations, but there are several that it does not accept. It does not support recommendation No. 15 and only partly supports recommendation No. 12. The government says:
While agreeing with the principles behind recommendation 15 the Government does not support the specific reporting and data collection activities associated with this recommendation.
Recommendation No. 15 is:
That reports be made available by the Department of Human Services and Health—
as it then was called—
to determine:
. the percentage of re‐admissions resulting primarily from a failure to take medication; and
. the percentage of re‐admissions resulting, primarily, from other factors such as shortage of required support services in the community.
The response document states:
The Government does not support this recommendation in its current form, but it will take into account re‐admission factors in developing indicators and targets for future reporting.

I would have thought that, when you are dealing with psychotherapeutic medication for people with mental illness, it would be an elementary necessity to have some indication, some quantifiable data, as to the level of non-compliance with medication taking, the readmission rate to hospital, and the other factors that are involved in this. This is elementary in the provision of a mental health scheme, in the use of psychotherapeutic medication. In fact, it should be elementary in the use of all medication. We know there are interactions between different drugs. We know that some drugs potentiate the action of others and that some drugs impede the action of others. This is elementary sort of material.

We frequently hear figures thrown around that such and such a percentage of people in hospital are there because of drug interactions or drug reactions or failure to take medication. We need to have those figures quantified. Somewhere along the line the government is going to have to bite the bullet and actually get some understanding of just how great this problem is. We know that there are a number of these sorts of drugs being used in nursing homes for people who have dementia and for the confused elderly. What we need to understand more is just what the interaction is with those drugs. We need to have a greater understanding of the fact that, as people get older, their requirements for the dose rate may well change, and we need to know about the drug interactions.

We also need to be conscious that in some areas we could have people using this heavy medication—or any medication—as opposed to an alternative therapy. There are a number of nursing homes and hostels dealing with confused elderly and people with dementia who are relying on a policy of hugs, not drugs, for the care of these people. It is vitally important that we make sure that health professionals of all types understand that, while drug use is very important on occasions, there are occasions when alternative therapies can very easily be tried and can have a very advantageous effect.

The government also only partly agreed with recommendation 12, which related to providing information in annual reports on measures undertaken to ensure that prescribed drugs are the most appropriate available for the individual and for the condition and details of procedures for monitoring patients on long-term medication. In the committee's travels to the Northern Territory, during the brief inquiry that they did have, they came across a gentleman who had been on lithium for a considerable number of years.

Lithium is an excellent drug for the treatment of the condition that this gentleman had, but nobody at any stage in those years that he had been on the drug had done a blood lithium level to monitor just what the drug level was in his system. All psychiatrists, who utilise this therapy a lot, will tell you that you should be monitoring the lithium levels in the blood regularly. But this gentleman had gone for years and years without having his blood lithium levels monitored. Fortunately, he was obviously on a reasonable dose because it was not having adverse effects. He was able to cope and was managing to live in society very well. But there could well have been occasions when this was not the case. It behoves everybody to be conscious of these types of problems that can come with the use of drugs.
I turn to one of the committee's earlier recommendations. Recommendation 3 stated:
That appropriate accommodation services be a priority for people with psychiatric disability. Such services must address the needs of people in all age groups.
The response reads:

The Government supports this recommendation in‐principle, although the provision of housing and accommodation support for people with psychiatric disability is primarily the responsibility of state and territory governments.

This comment is very interesting in light of the current budget. I would not be making these comments if this response had been tabled prior to the budget because I would not have known about them. In the budget we saw a tightening in a number of aspects of accommodation, such as rent assistance. There are a lot of people with psychiatric illnesses or other disabilities who are in the community sharing rented accommodation. They are single people who will be affected badly by the legislation that has been brought in to implement the budget.

I notice in this response that a review of disability services was being conducted by an independent consultant, Professor Anna Yeatman of Macquarie University, who will report to the Commonwealth, state and territory ministers for disability services. It states that an interim report was published in February 1996, with a final report due to ministers in mid‐1996. Because this response is so out of date, it is very hard to find the various reports and reviews that are spoken about here as occurring some time ago and to get them collated together. This is going to lead to a lot more questions being asked in the estimates committee hearings. If this had been a timely document, it would have greatly helped those of us who are involved in estimates. Recommendation 7 states:

That there be a specific program to facilitate the awareness of psychiatric illness in rural, regional and remote communities. This should include education and information packages on psychotherapeutic medication . . .

This is all very good. In the response, the government acknowledges the need for improved access. What the government does not tell us—if this had been out before the budget, we would have been happy about it—is that there has been a general attack on health funding to the states. That must impact negatively upon the health services available in rural and remote areas, especially mental health services.

Mental health is not seen in the medical and health fields as one of the `sexier' areas, for want of a better word. It is an area where people have a chronic illness which is recurrent in crises. It is an area that does not attract glamour. What are we going to see? Prior to this government's budget, mental health was already at the bottom of the pecking order. It is going to be further under attack by this government's attacks on health funding to people, particularly in the public health sector. This is a group of people who predominantly utilise the public health sector. They will be suffering very greatly from the attacks upon health. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fourth report of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties entitled Treaties tabled on 15 and 29 October 1996 , together with submissions, transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The document read as follows—
Today I table the committee's fourth report since September this year. It examines 17 non-controversial treaties which were tabled on 15 and 29 October 1996.

Two other treaties tabled on 15 October are not dealt with in this report: Protocol IV (dealing with blinding laser weapons) and the amended Protocol II (dealing with landmines) to the Inhumane Weapons Convention. The Minister for Foreign Affairs was advised soon after tabling that the committee would undertake a short inquiry into these important documents, and will report on them as early as practicable in 1997.

The committee supports ratification of all the treaties dealt with in this report. It makes only one formal recommendation: that Australia should press for the extension of the convention on nuclear safety to include research reactors of the type at Lucas Heights in New South Wales.

Today's tabling provides an opportunity to review our first few months' work, which I am sure all members would agree have been interesting and productive. In the four reports, we have covered a total of 50 treaties, commenting specifically on 28 of these. Productive as our first few months have been, we are still establishing our own processes as we aim towards a consistent approach.

We have found that certain types of treaties, such as investment protection agreements or air services agreements, are occurring in successive batches. Unless examples vary from model texts, we will not be commenting specifically on some of these in future reports.

Although the treaties dealt with in this report were all non‐controversial, they did raise some issues which deserve comment. We continue to have concerns about both the quantity and quality of consultation with the states and territories. As this report reiterates, the revised treaty-making process announced on May 2 by the Minister for Foreign Affairs was established in part to ensure inclusion of the views of the states and territories on treaties proposed for ratification. They have legal responsibilities for some of the matters on which the commonwealth enters into binding international obligations for Australia.

We have not made a recommendation on this matter, but we believe that national interest analyses should in future include information on the actual responses received from the states and territories about the texts of treaties proposed for accession.

For example, examination of one of the treaties in the group tabled on 15 October revealed that an important industry organisation had not been consulted. Although support was forthcoming from that organisation, as the result of the committee's review process, this oversight was a matter of concern.

Just as the committee has had to establish and adjust its own processes in a short time, so the coordinating activities of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade need a chance to settle down. This includes our suggestions for making further administrative improvements to the revised treaty-making process. However, we will be devoting some attention in future to assuring ourselves that, as far as possible, appropriate consultation has taken place with all the interested parties.

In its short existence, the committee has dealt with a wide range and large number of treaties. It might be said that we have not provided much time for an input by the community. To some extent, this is true. Under the revised procedures, we aim to table reports on treaties as close as possible to the end of the 15 sitting day period specified in the resolution of both houses.

So far, there have been six tablings of various numbers of treaties under the new arrangements, and the `15 sitting day' rule has made it difficult to seek and receive comments or submissions on these documents.

In the case of our 3rd report, two international agreements on tuna which was tabled two weeks ago, we were able to seek, and received, substantial community comments. We then held public hearings and inspections in Canberra, Hobart, Perth, Port Lincoln and Adelaide. Many organisations and individuals with an interest in the tuna industry gave us their knowledge and experience. We believe that the report has not only made a contribution to the treaty-making process, but also to the Australian tuna industry. We thank ordinary Australians for making that possible.

The level of response to this relatively simple inquiry demonstrated the genuine interest in the treaty-making process throughout Australia. It would be a mistake to assume that treaty-making can now be conducted in isolation from the Australian community.

Thus, we believe that we are already fulfilling the purpose for which we were established: to provide parliamentary scrutiny of the treaties Australia proposes to enter, before these documents are ratified. As the committee and its work becomes more widely known, we expect community interest in and responses to our work to grow. In 1997, we hope that the sitting pattern will allow us more time to seek the appropriate responses.

In particular, I would like to place on record the committee's appreciation for the cooperation and assistance it has received from all the ministers and their departments with whom and with which we have dealt.

I want to thank my deputy chair, the hon member for Barton, and all members of the committee for their interest and participation in the work of what was certainly the newest and arguably the busiest committee of the parliament in 1996.
A committee depends heavily on its secretariat, and I thank Peter Stephens and his team for their alacrity and professionalism under testing conditions.
I commend the report to the Senate.
