DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee: Joint

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Australia's relations with southern Africa , together with minutes of proceedings and transcript of evidence. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling speech in Hansard .
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The document read as follows—
I have great pleasure in tabling the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade's report on Australia's relations with Southern Africa.

SPEECH.PARA: The inquiry commenced in April 1995 under the very able chairmanship of Mr Colin Hollis, MP and had progressed to report stage when the election was called in January 1996. Following the re-establishment of the Committee we reviewed the evidence gathered and agreed to conclude the inquiry. The Minister for Foreign Affairs formally re-referred the inquiry in August 1996, updated evidence was sought, and the report is now before the Senate.

The inquiry focused on Australia's relations with those countries that make up the Southern African Development Community, or SADC. There are 12 member states: Angola, Zambia, Malawi, Zimbabwe, Namibia, Botswana, Mozambique, Lesotho, Swaziland, Tanzania, South Africa and Mauritius.

One of the difficulties facing the Committee during the inquiry was that submissions largely focused on South Africa, and to a lesser extent Zimbabwe and Mozambique. This may be due to the limited knowledge in Australia of many of the smaller African countries, but it is also a reflection of the dominant role of South Africa in the region. We took particular care, however, to stress in our hearings that we were not conducting an inquiry into just South Africa, but that we wanted more broadly to examine Australia's contacts with the region as a whole. As honourable senators would appreciate, looking at 12 countries was a fairly challenging task as there is enormous diversity among the SADC members.

As we note in the report, unfortunately many Australians still perceive Africa in terms of stereotypes. When the media reports on Africa, it tends to show the ethnic conflicts, such as we have seen recently in Rwanda and Zaire, or humanitarian emergencies arising from civil war or drought.

Contrary to this perception, there are many success stories still to be told, and Southern Africa has more than its share. The region has been described as a `beacon of hope' in Africa, and certainly there is much that we should applaud, particularly in the last five years.

Southern Africa is one of the most democratic regions in Africa, with successful multi-party elections having been held recently in Malawi, Mozambique and Namibia and complemented by South Africa's transition to a multi-racial democracy. While the successes to date have been encouraging, there is no reason to be complacent—much remains to be done, and the peace in both Mozambique and Angola remains fragile.
Madam President, for us all it is South Africa and the remarkable transformation that is occurring in that country that holds the key to the region's future.

Few commentators a decade ago would have believed that the South Africa of today was possible. Much of the successful transition to a multi-part democracy can be attributed to President Nelson Mandela. While he did not do it alone, President Mandela was crucial to the whole process, and remains a potent moral symbol for the new South Africa, and indeed for the whole African continent.

Some have expressed concern about South Africa after President Mandela, and it is true that South Africa will be at its most vulnerable in the lead up to the 1999 elections, in which President Mandela has indicated he will not stand. However, there is a depth of talent among the various political parties in South Africa that augers well for the future. The Committee was fortunate to meet both Deputy President Thabo Mbeki, and then Vice President F W de Klerk during their separate visits to Australia in the first half of 1995. Although from very different political backgrounds both men showed a commitment to peaceful reform in South Africa and the role Mr de Klerk played in achieving change should not be underestimated.

Negotiations on the draft South African Constitution have demonstrated a willingness by most participants to work within the system to achieve the best possible outcome. It is of concern that the Inkatha Freedom Party under Chief Buthelezi, while part of the Government of National Unity, did not participate in the constitutional reform process and is still seeking a high degree of autonomy for the KwaZulu/Natal province.

South Africa faces a number of significant economic problems, and its economic success is vital not only for its own population, but because of the central role the South African economy plays in Africa. To quote from Austrade's submission, South Africa:
produces 42% of Africa's industrial output
generates 60% of Africa's power
produces 75% of Africa's iron and steel
mines 40% of Africa's minerals
carries 65% of Africa's total freight
produces 40% of Africa's food
drives 40% of Africa's cars and
uses 40% of Africa's telephones.

South Africa is rich in natural resources, has a good infrastructure, and a well established corporate sector. However, it has a narrow export base, large sections of the population are unskilled and uneducated, unemployment is about 45% and a significant number of highly skilled South Africans have emigrated during the past 20 years. It is clear, therefore, that the challenge lies ahead for the leaders of South Africa.

After many years of comparative isolation, it is encouraging to note the positive role that South Africa is prepared in play in its immediate region. It is remarkable to see the former Front Line states, once the target of destabilisation by apartheid South Africa, now working closely with their old enemy to bring about greater economic integration and prosperity. Cooperation is well advanced in areas such as power generation, transport and communications, and environmental management. SADC is redefining itself, and South Africa is playing an important role in that process. The organisation is beginning to take on a regional security dimension, and the Committee has made a number of recommendations on assistance to SADC to encourage its development and strengthen its institutions.

There is much that I could speak on today—the business opportunities for Australian companies in southern Africa; the educational links that are being established between Australian universities and those in the SADC countries, the involvement of a number of the SADC states in the Indian Ocean Rim processes, both governmental and `second-track; Australia's development assistance program in Southern Africa and the real need that exists and will continue to exist for many years to come. However, time is too short to do more than refer honourable senators to the report.

Madam President, I conclude by thanking all of the individuals, NGOs, academics and business groups who assisted the Committee in its work. The Committee was particularly pleased to receive a number of submissions from Southern African countries and we hope the report reflects something of their concerns and viewpoint. I would also like to thank the honourable member for Groom who, as Chairman of the Foreign Affairs Sub‐Committee, saw this report through to its conclusion in this Parliament, and to all the members who participated in the inquiry.
I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The inquiry which resulted in this report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade was started under the previous government. A separate subcommittee was set up as part of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee. It was considered to be important enough to set up a subcommittee on Africa because southern Africa, and Africa in general, is one of those areas in relation to which there is a fairly large gap in the knowledge of many parliamentarians.

SPEECH.PARA: My remarks relate mainly to the issue of the original terms of reference. It was a concern which was shared by a number of the community groups who also wrote to the committee. The terms of reference were:
To investigate and report on Australia's political, security and trade interests in Southern Africa in the Post Apartheid era, in such areas as:
the role of Africa in Australia's global interests—
of course, these days, read `trade interests'—
Australia's bilateral interests in key African countries—
read `trade interests'—
how Australia might be in a position to contribute to the improving regional security environment;
trade and investment opportunities for Australia, including niche markets.

There are sub‐topics, but, largely, the irony in relation to Australia and Africa is that Australia's aid relationship, which has been of concern to a lot of community groups, is inversely proportional to the per capita income of many countries. It seems that aid is often used as a means of attracting trade or being involved with trade.

That is very sad, because we really have not had an opportunity to look at whether Australia's aid program is meeting the need of addressing poverty in Africa or southern Africa. By dealing simply with the SADC countries, we have probably avoided dealing with many of the countries which are suffering some of the biggest shifts and upheavals. The problems are economic and social, and they end up being ones that involve loss of life and also some very serious environmental problems.

The committee dealt with some of these problems, but unfortunately, because of cutbacks, we no longer have an Africa subcommittee; it ended up being sent to the foreign affairs subcommittee of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee. I think it is quite sad that we put less emphasis on that area due to cutbacks.

I also think it is important that at some time in the future we look at some of the issues relating to Australia's relationship with Africa. We should look at some of the political issues so that in the future Australia does not feel that it needs to support, or otherwise, an international military effort into parts of Africa, in order to try to sort out a huge social and military dilemma, when we have so very little understanding of the area.

I think it is time for the Australian parliament to look further into those areas. It is time for us also to look at the connections between economic policies and some of the other issues that eventuate from that, be they social upheaval or even environmental upheaval. I am pleased that, at my request, on page 143 of the report there is a small section on environmental issues. It was pointed out to the committee on a number of occasions that there seemed to be a connection between structural adjustment programs as a result of internationalism and the impact of World Bank and IMF programs. At page 143 of the report, the Australian Council for Overseas Aid is quoted as saying:

What has happened with the structural adjustment programs, by and large, is that they have tended to pressure countries to export more of their agricultural produce . . . It has also pushed agriculture into very marginal areas . . . and that has stressed the land . . . [It] has not been done in a way that is in any way environmentally sustainable.
The report also quotes from Marter and Gordon's `Emerging issues confronting the renewable natural resources sector in sub‐Saharan Africa' in Food Policy :

As a consequence of urbanisation, the proportion of population not producing its own food is rising fast and has profound implications for the region's food security. Urbanisation also raises major issues with regard to pollution. Air pollution associated with vehicle emissions and industry, solid waste, most of which is not collected or treated, contaminated water supplies, will all have serious implications for public health. The failure of many structural adjustment policies to date is attributable to the failure to address such issues effectively.

It is important that we start seeing those connections, whether in nearby regions or in Africa, and start building them into our support structures and looking beyond our base desire to make money out of a particular area of the world. We need to start looking at what kinds of decisions of a political or military nature Australia might be required to make in the future and try to understand what the issues are.

It is very rare in Africa that a drought is simply a drought. There is often some political and military story behind it which exacerbates the situation, leading to extra pressure on the land. There has been a history of people moving to areas or being forced to use areas that should not be used because of climatic conditions, and the creation of deserts where deserts did not exist before. It is important for us to understand such things.

We are still way short of that level of understanding. We, as a parliament, need to be able to make decisions in relation to these issues. I certainly hope that in the future we take the opportunity of going past the desire simply to make money from trade and look at what are the real issues affecting Africa which might spill over into decisions required to be made in this parliament. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO INDIA AND PAKISTAN

TALK.START.PARA: —By leave—At the request of Senator Minchin, I present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to India and Paki stan which took place between 25 August and 6 September 1996.

DEBATE.TITLE: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Carr had moved by way of amendment:
At the end of the motion, add ", but the Senate:
(a) is of the opinion that the vocational education and training system has an increasingly vital role in providing Australia's young people with skills appropriate to the changing workplace; and
(b) condemns the Government:

PARA.TAB: (i) for proposing substantial cuts in expenditure which will hamper the vocational education and training sector in fulfilling this role; and

(ii) for clearly failing to meet its election commitments to `continue to support a strong and effective TAFE sector' and to `ensure that the network of TAFE institutions, especially in rural areas and regional centres, will not be undermined'."

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, when the debate on the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1996 was adjourned last week I was explaining that the Australian Democrats support the immediate increase in funding to ANTA, an increase of around $13 million for 1996. But I was dismayed by the then budget changes to the 1997 and 1998 funding of ANTA, which will see ANTA lose funds of around $58 million—$57.5 million—over the next couple of years. I think that is very sad. It is an indictment of this government's commitment to vocational education and training.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we are set to debate further changes to the education sector—specifically, changes to the higher education sector—and last week we saw quite radical changes to schools policy and schools funding. That all sends a very warped message to the community about the commitment that this government has to the pursuit of academic excellence and to vocational education and training integrity and excellence. I find it hard to understand why, at this time in our history, when we have unemployment rates of around 8.7 per cent, we seek to cut the funding available to a sector that would allow people to develop the skills that would improve their employment prospects.

Last week I also mentioned my concern about the notion of efficiency dividends. A lot of funding cuts in this bill come in the guise of an efficiency dividend. Last week I pondered whether that was economic jargon to enable us to make quite drastic cuts in funding to a range of institutions in this country, or whether it honestly led to increased viability, efficiency or productivity in the TAFE and higher education sector.

I wonder why this government has chosen to apply a five per cent efficiency dividend to TAFE when all other Commonwealth own purpose outlays and specific purpose payments will be subject to only a three per cent efficiency dividend in the first year, with an additional one per cent efficiency dividend in each succeeding year. I wonder why TAFE has been singled out in this way. It is at odds with a government that talks about creating real jobs and getting Australians back into the work force. I wonder how we can expect people to get back into the work force by developing their skills when we are cutting the funds available to vocational education in this country.

Training has a crucial role to play. It is fundamental to ensuring that workers' skills are compatible with the jobs available. Anyone with an understanding of how labour markets work would agree that it is difficult to overstate the importance of vocational education and training and the creation of a highly skilled and highly employable work force. That is why the Democrats strongly voice their objection to the cuts proposed for ANTA and the funding cuts to the labour market program that have also been a part of this government's budget.

BREAK.PARA: The cuts to labour market programs run far deeper than any five per cent efficiency dividend. In fact, funding for labour market programs in this country will be slashed by $1.8 billion over the next four years, with $574.7 million being slashed from labour market programs in 1996-97 alone.

So the Democrats do not believe that the government is going to find its answers to solving the massive problem of unemployment in this country by slashing vocational and educational training funding as well as funding that is available to labour market programs. We believe that these government policies will fail to provide a lasting solution to unemployment because they are primarily driven by a theoretical economic model which does not make sense because it does not take into account the needs of real people.

What real people need in this country is access to skills development, and access to jobs and training programs which are linked to real jobs—something that Senator Vanstone talked about this afternoon in the chamber. However, the rhetoric that we have heard from government ministers and backbenchers is not met by any reality—certainly is not matched with any funding commitment. My understanding is that former Senator Robert Bell from the Australian Democrats was very much involved—

TALK.START.PARA: —A great man!

—Through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, I would like to acknowledge Senator Macdonald's suggestion that Senator Bell was—and is still—a great man. He was very involved in the Senate Employment, Education and Training committee report of the inquiry into the Australian National Training Authority which was tabled in November 1995. One of the recommendations put forward in the dissenting report, in the minority report, was that funding to ANTA and certainly to vocational education and training generally should be at least maintained, and certainly increased if that was available. I urge those members of the department and the government to read through and perhaps refresh themselves with the recommendations in that committee report.

BREAK.PARA: I am aware also of a recommendation to which I believe ALP and Democrat senators did agree, and that was the notion of increasing the composition of the ANTA board by two members, from the current five members to seven members. That, I understand, is an amendment that is being put forward today by the coalition. However, there are a few problems with the government's amendment. As I understand it—and I look forward to enlightenment on this if I have it wrong—the motivation behind this government amendment, that is, the intention of increasing the board by two members, is to put two more representatives from the business sector on the ANTA board. That is unfortunate because it runs contrary to a Democrat recommendation in the dissenting report. That is, the committee recommends that an independent education and training specialist be appointed to the board of ANTA.

The rationale behind the original recommendation of increasing the board from five to seven members was to ensure broad representation on that board, not to make it top heavy with business and industry representatives but to include independent educationalists and, as I understand it, trade union members and members with, in one case, regional and rural backgrounds. So I look forward to finding out progress on those recommendations. Generally I would be keen to find out how the recommendations from that Senate committee have been or are being implemented. Perhaps a report on their progress for the Senate would be appreciated.

So the Australian Democrats will not be supporting the government amendment as it currently stands. But I am happy to listen to the minister's statement and in the committee stage be swayed by argument if I have got it wrong. If the intent behind the amendment to increase the board's membership is to ensure that there is that kind of broad representation on the board then I will be happy to reconsider the Democrat position. But we stand by our recommendation.

PARA.BREAK: I hope that the government can ensure that independent educationalists and certainly people with broad backgrounds are appointed to the ANTA board. The Australian Demo crats again voice our concern that this government's agenda does not seem to include allowing people access to skills development and education—education on the basis of merit and brains and not bank balance—at a time when we have such high levels of unemployment and such high levels of youth unemployment specifically and when such massive and drastic cuts are being made to education and training in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has been trying its hardest in this bill to cover up the extent of its cuts to vocational education and training. They focus on the relative spending from year to year instead of facing up to the enormous cuts to projected spending. We do not know how deeply these cuts go beyond 1997 as the 1998 funding decisions have not yet been revealed. This bill is touted by the government to provide a $10.6 million increase in 1997 compared with the 1996 funding. However, the lies are exposed when one considers the projected funding for 1997 of $927.2 million, which has been cut by around $58 million to a new figure of $869.7 million. This perhaps is a further extension of the pattern by the previous government where they underspent in a number of portfolios to pretend that they were not cutting expenditure. They looked at the actual expenditure rather than projections. This seems to be a further creative accounting way of looking at or presenting figures so they do not look like cuts.

SPEECH.PARA: The government is also establishing a pattern of hiding behind these figures. We know that these are big cuts for ANTA and bodies in receipt of the funding. The government, however, is providing minimal detail and sticking to dollar terms that cannot articulate what the impact will be on the ground. The $57.5 million is actually $45 million in real cuts because there is a transfer of $12.5 million for workplace coordinators to another portfolio. Out of the real cuts $19 million is a cut of ANTA national projects from $42 million down to $23 million in 1997; $10 million is the abolition of the interstate cooperative projects; $27 million is a cut from capital funding from TAFE and the private provider training infrastructure such as industry based skills centres and $4.5 million is a so-called `efficiency dividend'—read `cut'—to the off-the-job training for traineeships state by state.

It has been calculated that the real figure is somewhere around cuts of $170 million over four years to ANTA. This is on top of the $1.8 billion cuts to the labour market programs and the TAFE efficiency dividends which are found in the appropriations bills alongside the cuts to industry training bodies or ITABs.

From the limited information available, I have tried to shed some light on who will actually be affected. It appears that the major cuts of $27 million for capital infrastructure will have a deleterious effect on TAFE's ability to provide courses to industry. This comes on top of the cuts in growth funding to TAFE and the five per cent so‐called efficiency dividend. Outside of the TAFE system, the cuts will also particularly affect industry based skill centres.

ANTA's national projects budget will be halved from $42 million to $23 million in 1997. This will cut many research and development projects such as those on how to implement equity measures for individual client groups, develop management and statistical information systems, develop quality curriculum, and provide incentives for best practice and a number of literacy and numeracy projects for the workplace and within schools. It is unfortunate to see the budget halved for projects which set standards and consistent models across states and provide the basis for equity and education projects which improve the accessibility and effectiveness of training to disadvantaged client groups.

Further major cuts include $10 million by abolishing the interstate cooperative projects. These are particularly alarming, because they not only facilitate interstate cooperation, but provide a lot of equity and proactive training projects in disadvantaged, rural, isolated and Aboriginal communities. The government's response to these cuts is that the states should pick up this kind of work. However, it obviously was not being done before, which is why the federal government had to step in in the first place. There is no guarantee that any of these projects will be picked up by the states. Has anyone seen extra money going to the states to allow them to pick these projects up?

In New South Wales, the cross‐border project on the Queensland‐New South Wales, Gold Coast‐Tweed Heads border was receiving $1.8 million to teach a range of office, hospitality, business and Aboriginal studies. Also in New South Wales, the wide area learning project was a joint New South Wales‐Queensland project delivering training to isolated and disadvantaged communities, by computer, to people without access to training at all.

There is also a range of projects to bring certain professions training through open learning, such as farm management, horticulture and modules for remote Aboriginal communities. I might add that people sourcing their training fromopen learning will be greatly affected and disadvantaged by the new up‐front fee regime proposed by the government for open learning in the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1966. It is double or triple jeopardy for some people. Optical dispensing and wine industry training are available through the Open Net.

Many of the projects to be cut are also targeted at Aboriginal people. These include pastoral training, Aboriginal rural training, Aboriginal community education, and the Gold Coast‐Tweed Heads cross‐border project already mentioned. In my electorate of Western Australia, the Central Western Desert Aboriginal people are particularly hard hit. They were receiving vocational education and training towards a certificate in remote community essential services work, with literacy and numeracy modules as well, but this will be abolished. Western Australia will lose the delivery of environmental management studies to students. It is hard to believe that this government believe in anything remotely associated with self‐determination when they are pulling the rug out from people fighting hard to try to establish that and to learn how to meet their own needs.

BREAK.PARA: In South Australia, Aboriginal communities who were being trained in the building industry to build their own homes in remote communities have had their funding taken away. The project was called Wali Palyantjaku. Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory were able to gain their applied science diplomas in horticulture, conservation and tourism training through a heritage and interpretive tourism course.

All of these cuts are cloaked in the rhetoric of economic rationalism and thenaive belief that the states will take over these programs when there is little reason for them to accept the Commonwealth cost shifting equity programs onto the states. I would like a guarantee from the minister that these programs will continue under the relevant state governments, because what is obvious to me is that anyone who lives in a rural, remote or Aboriginal community and is interested in self-determination and self-reliance or in studying about the environment or farming will be disadvantaged in terms of access to vocational education and training. This is an appalling indictment brought about by this bill and the Greens (WA) are fundamentally opposed to the cuts that will bring about this disadvantage.

I would like to add my voice in relation to the proposal for the proposed amendments to increase the representatives of the Business Council of Australia by two. I have nothing against the Business Council of Australia, but I do think it has a bias against community participation and a bias further in business favour. I do not think that is going to achieve the outcome that many people are hoping for and have been concerned about in relation to the current move to economic rationalism.

Unfortunately, the Greens (WA) are forced to vote for this bill to ensure that the funding that remains is able to be passed to the states. It is not a particularly happy picture and I would like some level of reassurance from the government that they will be addressing the serious concerns we believe will eventuate as a result of the cuts from this program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to indicate, on behalf of the opposition, our opposition to these amendments to the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1996. The government has belatedly placed these amendments before the chamber, and the effect of these amendments is to increase the size of the board of the Australian National Training Authority by two. That in itself is in line with the recommendations in the report of the review of the ANTA agreement, which was commissioned by a Labor government and conducted by R. M. Taylor, which reported in February.

PARA.BREAK: Our difficulty arises in that the amendments before the chamber do not reflect that review but in fact go some way to undermine it. The office of the Minister for Employment, Edu cation, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) has made it clear to the opposition in briefings that it has conducted that it intends to fill the two positions that are being proposed in this amendment with further representatives of the business interests, especially with representatives from the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. This is clearly not in line with the recommendations of the Taylor review.

SPEECH.PARA: This review recommended that the Secretary to the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, a senior state or territory official and, desirably, the chairperson of the Standards and Curriculum Council be added to the board. The purpose of these additions was to bring about:

. . . greater cohesion, ownership and shared values by the states and territories and the Commonwealth to the system and to add to the board's deliberation by bringing the expertise of two of the nation's top public sector managers to the consideration of resource allocation, Commonwealth‐state relations and government administration.

The government is ideologically committed to the business domination of training rather than to the provision of adequate and, through the government, appropriate public administration accountability. This is the same ideological underpinning which we see in their desire to replace the area consultative committees with more business dominated regional employment bodies and the general philosophy that is now running through the TAFE and the VET sectors more generally.

When speaking before the estimates committee about what industry domination of these bodies meant to this government, the minister said she meant specifically excluding workers' representatives from the vocational education and training sector. She understood business to mean the owners of business, the owners of capital, not the persons who made capital productive—that is, the workers in industry. She quite consciously and deliberately set forth the government's position to be one that was founded upon this very premise.

PARA.BREAK: Therefore, the opposition is clearly not going to support the proposition. The major policy reversal that this government is pursuing through this bill contradicts the gov ernment's push to put more employer representatives on ANTA and contradicts the various points that it made prior to the election about broader consultation in the area of education and training.

SPEECH.PARA: It was only fairly recently that a senior official of the ACCI, Mr Mark Paterson, was appointed to the ANTA board ex officio by virtue of his former association with the Standards and Curriculum Council. Representation from senior state and territory officials on ANTA would make far greater sense at this time, given that there was considerable resistance from the state training authorities and some state governments, especially the New South Wales government, to aspects of the MAATS program, which needs to be very carefully negotiated if this government is to pursue to any degree of success its proposals with regard to the modern apprenticeship and training scheme.

It is noted that when the ANTA board was first constituted there was general agreement, including by the coalition state governments, that members should be there for their expertise, their commitment and the contribution that they themselves would make rather than their being representatives of particular interest groups. These proposed changes turn that policy direction on its head as well.

We see more generally in the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill that the New South Wales government has recently exposed the harsh cuts that will occur in TAFE colleagues as a result of the budget cut to vocational education and training, which this bill gives effect to. We see, for instance, that TAFE institutes in areas of high unemployment in Sydney's south‐west face enrolment cuts of more than 1,000 and TAFE institutes in the Hunter region of New South Wales will lose more than 4,000 places. As I say, we will oppose this bill and the new amendments. We already sought to highlight our opposition through the second reading amendment, which was defeated, and we will be opposing these amendments.

It is not just the case of New South Wales that I want to highlight in terms of the draconian effects that these changes will have. The state systems will be adversely affected by these changes. We see, for instance, that in the case of Victoria there will be quite significant impacts in terms of the Commonwealth's withdrawal of funding from the vocational education and training sector.

You can see it at every level. The operating budget cut to ANTA head office of 25 per cent will see the removal of positions. The level of service invariably will have to fall. The abolition of pre‐vocational programs or their reduced funding for access will have an impact in Victoria. There will be a requirement that labour market programs themselves will decline as a result of this budget measure, which has an impact on all states, particularly Victoria.

For example, labour market programs will decline to the tune of some $80 million for Victorian TAFE institutes in 1997. There will be a significant reduction in residual labour market funds to support training for a number of apprentices as part of the new MAATS scheme. There will be new tendering arrangements for labour market programs which will also impact on the provision of services within Victorian TAFE institutions.

There will be ongoing price pressures, including the state's own 1.5 per cent saving dividends instituted through its budget, which will present real difficulties for small TAFE institutes by forcing many of them to reconsider their viability, especially given the continuing maintenance of efforts requirements which, I trust, will be pursued by this government. It will lead to pressures for mergers of institutes which can be expected as a result of the failure of the states to provide adequate moneys for the smaller TAFE institutes—and on top of these cuts that will be quite dramatic.Each of those expected mergers in Victoria could result in the loss of some 40 staff.

You will see reductions in labour market training programs having a significant impact on TAFE institutes and various other programs which currently employ up to 560 teachers, although that funding will be lost. There will be an introduction of user choice through the MAATS program which will result in the relocation of funds away from the TAFE institutes to the so‐called registered private providers.

For every 20 per cent shift away from TAFE on apprenticeship training in 1997, it is anticipated that up to 200 staff are likely to be made redundant. The pressures on allocating the growing proportion of vocational education and training funds on traineeship and apprenticeship under MAATS, or to respond to the increases in the HECS payments which are being pursued through the next bill we will look at today, will see added demands on local training priorities which must in fact reduce the level of services at a regional level. You will see reductions in Commonwealth capital expenditure which will see Commonwealth capital funding to local TAFE colleges equally reduced.

As a result of these measures, you are likely to see increasing reductions in support for industry training boards for staff professional development—the important process of statistic collection, the normal vocational education and training research. You are likely to see additional pressure right through vocational education and training as a result of these changes.

The bill ought to be looked at in its totality. Although the amendment before us today might look simple, it is about the expansion of the board—an expansion which runs quite contrary to the recommendations of the Taylor review and those of the Senate committee into ANTA which reported in November 1995. In this context, I would ask the minister: what is the progress towards the implementation of the recommendations of the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee report which was brought down in November 1995?

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked a number of questions during my second reading presentation and the minister said she would save any responses until the committee stage. Well, we are now here. The major questions focused on the kinds of guarantees we have that the states have the desire and the ability to provide the kinds of courses that may be cut. I gave examples of a range of courses and services provided by the current program. I would like some sort of feedback from the minister as to what the impact will be on those people who were receiving the benefits of those programs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, you did rightly ask about the contribution that you thought the states were going to make and whether there were any guarantees. Forgive me, I took that as a rhetorical question that was a bit of polemic on your part. I simply respond to you by saying that I do not have a view that there are states looking to make adverse funding decisions in the vocational education and training area more than they would be in any other.

SPEECH.PARA: The bottom line is a matter that Senator Carr probably well understands, Senator Stott Despoja seeks to avoid and on which I have yet to hear you, Senator Margetts, make much comment, although you may have when I have not been tuned into these debates. The bottom line is this: if we want to generate more real jobs, we have to be fiscally responsible. We have to demonstrate that we can actually run the nation's books as efficiently as any business is expected to do.

When members opposite were in government, they chose to keep running a deficit. They chose to tell the Australian people prior to the last election that everything was okay, that the budget would be in the black—by diminishing amounts, I admit. During the election campaign we said, `Let's open the books. Let's have a good look. Let everybody see the basis on which there will or will not be a change of government.' And the then government refused.

PARA.BREAK: We can argue at the edges about the size of the deficit but I do not think anybody disagrees that it is enormous. That needs to be repaired. If you want to generate real jobs, you have to be a fiscally responsibly government. I made the point in a debate last week, Senator Margetts—and I do not think you were here—that it is no politician's dream to come into government and have to put a budget back into the black. There is no joy whatsoever in telling people, whether they are states, training authorities or whatever that they will now get less from the Common wealth. There is no joy, no fun and no short‐term political gain in telling people that they will have to pay more for things that they otherwise would have paid less for.

SPEECH.PARA: These are the difficult decisions that this government is prepared to take. This is one of the reasons that we were elected. There was a sense in the community that the previous government was not prepared to take the difficult decisions; that it was not prepared to make decisions that people would criticise by saying, `People don't want to get less' or `People don't want to pay more'—the easy, short‐term catchcries that we hear from people with short‐term political vision.

People realised that it was about time we again had a government that was prepared to make the hard decisions. If you walk away from these hard decisions, you walk from those people who are already without jobs, those who are in jobs but the least skilled. Unskilled and semi‐skilled workers are the ones that are the most at risk when you have a further economic downturn.

You can all sit and pretend on the other side of this chamber, if you like, that everything else was okay and that we do not have to worry about a deficit reduction strategy, that that is not a problem, that somehow somewhere else this matter will be addressed by other people. The bad news for members opposite is that the matter has to be addressed by the federal parliament; it is our responsibility to fix this; it is our responsibility to put the budget back into black. You cannot walk away from it and just come in here when there are good decisions to make—easy decisions, decisions that give out money, that ask people to pay less. That is not what our jobs are about, either in government or in opposition.

Consequently, across portfolios there has been a requirement to contribute to the deficit reduction. As I say, it is not an easy task and not one in which any politician in a pick‐a‐box contest would say, `Oh, that is for me. Why don't I have the job of putting the budget back into black? That sounds like fun.' Nobody is going to say that. These are the difficult decisions that have to be made.

BREAK.PARA: I make these points because there were comments by Senator Stott Despoja, by you, Senator Margetts, and, I think, by you, Senator Carr, as to the fact that, against forward estimates, there is going to be a reduction. That is right: there is to be a reduction in the growth. And that is a function of having to contribute to the deficit reduction strategy. As each bill comes through, we can say, `But not in this area,' but sooner or later you have to find out where the reduction is to come from.

We have made what we think are the best decisions possible about how to spread this burden to pay off the Beazley bankcard. Members opposite may have different views about how they would go about doing it, but it would be a pleasure to hear what those views are, on some occasion perhaps other than today, about the difficult decisions they would be prepared to make—not the easy ones, not the ones in which you say, `We'll stop you having to pay more' or `We'll stop this cut here', the easy short‐term stuff, but some of the difficult decisions that would actually address this problem. It would be a pleasure to hear some of that.

Senator Margetts, you indicated that you still did not know the 1998 funding, I think, but that is in the bill and it is a total of $893.7 million. You referred to a real cut in 1997. As I have indicated to you, no‐one is denying that it is a reduction in forward estimates, but it is still an increase next year over this year. I do not think that is an inappropriate way to phrase that at all. You look at a reduction in student places, whereas in fact these reductions in funding are basically being sought from capital projects and we are looking to maintain places.

It is probably appropriate at this point to mention just a couple of other matters. There has been some reference made by all speakers to the two extra members it is sought to have on the board. Senator Carr seeks to make much of the fact that the Taylor review recommendations are not being accepted. Of course, I do not believe that Senator Carr would put a proposition that any government is bound to follow the recommendations of any review, because the government then would simply be a rubber stamp.

I think it is a perfectly appropriate question to ask. What it is not appropriate to do is to suggest that, because a review has been held and some recommendations have been made, a government should simply say,`Oh, good. Thanks.' That would mean that people would sit here in government and opposition and simply pass off the work to other people by way of review. The notion that the government would agree to accept all recommendations of a review on any particular matter or the notion that an opposition would agree to accept all recommendations on a particular matter is frankly laughable. One only has to look, for example, at the National Commission of Audit and ask whether Senator Carr would be happy to shift university funding to basically a scholarship basis, which might otherwise be described as vouchers. He would have lots of reasons why that was a bad idea—I am sure he would. He would not for one minute give up not so much his right but his obligation to offer an alternative view, if he had one.

In relation to this matter, the government is seeking to put two extra members on the board. I hear from people opposite that the Taylor review ought to be followed. With respect to the secretary of DEETYA, members opposite may not know that there is an ANTA—Australian National Training Authority—CEOs meeting, which the secretary attends with the other CEOs. You could easily argue the case that, to put the head of DEETYA, that is, a Commonwealth senior administrator, with one state administrator is dead set to cause further trouble in other ways by virtue of the fact that not all the states get represented. This is a difficult area. It is part of our federal system—where the Commonwealth has to work with the states and not all states get represented.

The states are sensitive about the numbers that they have. By increasing the numbers by one Commonwealth and one state member, you may well have a number of states saying, `Hold on. There are a lot more of us. We should have more space.' From mechanisms such as the fact that we have the National Training Authority chief executive officers meeting at the same time as the ANTA board—and as a consequence of the change of government, those people now get to meet much more fully with ANTA Minco as well, that is, the ministers meeting—we can improve the cooperation that is required when the Commonwealth is putting in some money, the states are putting in the rest and there is no unanimous agreement across the states as to how to proceed with any reforms. This is not ever going to be an easy area to administrate. The previous government clearly discovered that.

Why two extra members? I think there is general agreement that the board could be larger and more usefully structured, but there is disagreement between the government and the Taylor review—and, presumably, from what I hear, from members opposite—about how we ought to go about that. I hear pretty well all speakers saying, `Isn't this a shocking thing! This government wants industry training to be industry led, wants business to have a say.'

The sharp reality for everyone ought to be that one of the problems with any form of training if you want to get people jobs is: if you do not consult with industry, if you do not understand clearly what industry wants, if you do not develop mechanisms that industry not only can work with but wants to work with and is prepared to work with, and if you do not bring industry into the tent, then you can have the best laid plans but you will not get the cooperation or the implementation. So, far from being put off or embarrassed in any way at the prospect of putting on more business representatives—representatives who may well provide an adequate link into the broader business community—I think it is a very good thing.

Yes, people said in the beginning that they did not want the board to be a representative board. We could all point to boards like that where there are problems because of it. But this is not a suggestion to turn the ANTA board into that at all. It is a suggestion to quite wisely link the existing board members, such as Bill Mansfield from the ACTU, who is a recognised leader in the training area, with people who have been selected because of their own business contribution, like Stella Axarlis and others—to mix in those people who have this coalface industry experience themselves with others who may be an appropriate link into the broader business organisations.

Why is that? Is it any fun for people to come along and give time from their job to another board? No, it is not. That is not the reason. Why would you do it for that reason? It is because you want to provide industry led training that will be accepted by industry and will lead to people being taken on into real jobs. To suggest for one minute that you can do that in isolation from the broader business community is crazy. I really do not understand the criticism of this.

It is basically taking what was initially started: `Yes, there needs to be a broader scope.' But let us ensure that that scope further links the ANTA board with the broader business community, with the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Business Council of Australia. These are people we want involved in the training process. We want to bring them in; we want them to feel some ownership of the new training systems. Industry needs to recognise that training is an investment on which they will recoup. You cannot do that by shutting these people out. That is the reason. It is a very good reason. I am amazed that some people have indicated they will not be supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of what the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) has said is the kind of response we have been hearing in answers at question time, but it is not, I believe, what we should be expecting in the committee stage of the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1996. I asked questions about the impact of the effective cuts in the forward program and I got a lecture on why it is necessary to make slashes right across programs, no matter what the outcomes.

SPEECH.PARA: If the major goal of any government is `to run the books as efficiently as any business', the reality is, first of all, that the main role of any business is to make a profit. It is not about outcomes. I do not want to see any federal government running that as their prime motive. Secondly, we have a situation where the government say that their major motive is to get the budget back in the black. But there are two sides to any ledger. Apart from slashing programs, the second side is to look at your revenue options. Minister, I am very happy to say that we have some ideas for that and I am happy to offer them to you. In the next week or so you will see some of them. I would be pleased to see you lining up to support revenue options so we can fund the things which people are expecting—not of a business but of a government; the things that state governments currently are not offering.

If you believe that all we need to do is to put more business people on these boards, then you seem to have missed the reports that many of us are getting about the very low morale level, about people who have worked their hearts out in the TAFE sector, who believe in what they are doing and who believe in providing a good quality of education. This is across the training sector. Those people are becoming so disheartened because of this very narrow business and corporate focus. Putting a greater weighting on, say, the Business Council of Australia simply means that the focus will continue in that direction without addressing the outcomes or the community and social needs that this sector is trying to address.

We have heard the black hole argument, but yesterday there was a blow‐out in the balance of trade. That will have more of an effect on employment, interest rates and such things as the dollar than anything that is coming out of the budget. But there is this great big silence. That has affected previous government policies and current government polices. It is about our levels of imports compared with our levels of exports. It is about how much of what we consume is being produced overseas. It is about the change of our value adding in our industries. But we are not even looking at that.

If you are going to talk about responsibilities, I would like to hear a whole range of them. But that is not what we are hearing. We are hearing a very narrow argument about the budget; only one side of it—expenditure, not revenue. I would have preferred, Minister, to hear a committee stage response, not a question time response, to these kinds of serious issues about outcomes and levels of services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I asked a question specifically relating to the government's response to the report of inquiry into the Australian National Training Authority. Do you have an answer to that question?

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Carr, if you could help me here, are you talking about a response to the Senate committee report?
—Yes.

—I draw your attention to DEETYA question No. 209 in relation to the Senate legislation committee hearing on the budget. The question was put on notice in subprogram 3.2. The question was asked by Senator Stott Despoja. She asked about the report. I assume the answer she was given would have been circulated to you but, nonetheless, I will repeat it for you:

SPEECH.PARA: A response to the report of the Senate Employment Education and Training References Committee inquiry into the Australian National Training Authority has not been finalised, as many of the recommendations touch on issues being considered in a response to the review of ANTA commissioned by COAG. Several of the recommendations of the Senate report have already been implemented in part or in full and these include: the development of a reliable system for collecting national training statistics and access to vocational education funding by schools. A range of approaches have now been developed to approve data quality and system management and ensure a high level on key performance measures. The budget provided funding to government and non-government education authorities to ensure an adequate supply of appropriately trained teachers of vocational education. The ANTA ministerial council has also agreed to allocate $20 million for vocational education and training in schools for the next four calendar years.
I cannot give you the date on which that answer was provided. If you do not have a copy of that, it will now be in the Hansard record.

TALK.START.PARA: —You indicated to the committee that you felt it was the right of any government to reject any review recommendations. I would agree with you on that point. I did not understand you to explain why you were rejecting these specific recommendations of the Taylor review.
