TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I had fairly clearly outlined the recommendation vis-a-vis the board. I will run through it again for you quickly. The recommendation was for an increase in the number on the board and for nominated persons to fill those positions. We do not accept that. We accept an increase, but not the increase the review recommended. We are seeking to add two people instead of three to the board. The review recommended adding the Secretary to DEETYA, one of the state CEOs and another person. We are seeking to add two and we are not following those recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: The two we are looking at would give the board a link to the large business organisations that we think need to be brought in and tied into the training agenda and need to recognise that training is an investment in their future not a fringe benefit that they offer. I indicated that one of the reasons for not accepting the recommendations relating to the CEOs was the fact that we have the ANTA CEOs group which meets whenever the ANTA board and ANTA ministerial council meet.

I believe I indicated that, as a consequence of changed arrangements since the change of government, the linkages between the ANTA board, the ANTA ministerial council and ANTA CEOs have improved. We are not denying that it is obviously important to have good links with the ANTA CEOs, but we are simply making the point that it can be done by alternative means and that it is appropriate to take steps to involve industry to a greater extent than it is at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The difficulty though is that these administrative arrangements go to the issue of the maintenance of effort. One of the key issues for having the Secretary to the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs on the board was to improve the capacity of the Commonwealth government to have a window into the operations of ANTA. Are you now saying that the issues relating to the maintenance of effort are no longer as important as they once were?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we are not saying that. Frankly, I am surprised that you have suggested that. We are not saying that at all. The relationship between the ANTA ministerial council, the ANTA board and ANTA CEOs is such that the Commonwealth already has that capacity. Perhaps you might like to spell out something you think we have missed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we could go on at considerable length about these issues. It is not our intention to spend any more time on this particular matter. We have made it very clear that we are strongly opposed to the position being taken by the government with regard to these measures. We are particularly concerned about the way in which you are seeking to administer cuts to the national training agenda. As I read the documents, we would see national training programs reduced by $70 million, national projects reduced by $44 million and capital projects reduced by $225 million in 1996. This would have a detrimental effect on the capacity of this country to respond effectively to the training and vocational educational needs of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: We are very concerned about the manner in which these budget cuts are being implemented as part of your general strategy to secure savings of $4.3 billion from the department over the forward estimates period and to reduce the whole of government percentage outlays going to DEETYA from 11.1 per cent to 9.1 per cent over that same period. To us, this is wrong. It is wrong that you should be inflicting these sorts of cuts upon future generations of Australians. We believe this will have detrimental effects on our economy and on our social development.

BREAK.PARA: Having made those points, I do not believe that we can pursue this matter any further. I make it clear that we oppose the amendments that the government is moving on the grounds that I have outlined and for the general philosophical reasons that I have outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, would you clarify the starting date for the additional members to the ANTA board?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not possible. Obviously, for starters, the legislation needs to be passed, then it needs to go back to ANTA Minco for appointments to be made. I cannot tell you whether the legislation is going to be passed, and we do have the date of the next ANTA Minco meeting, but it is not in my head.

—Thank you, minister. I just wanted clarification as to whether it would be contingent on royal assent as opposed to a date being determined. There was not necessarily a starting date that you had in mind, so it is contingent upon royal assent.
—Senator, this may be of some assistance. Clause 25, `Appointment of members', at page 9 of the ANTA Act 1992, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The members of the authority are to be appointed by the Governor-General on the nomination of the ministerial council.

So when there would be a start up would depend on the passage of the legislation, nomination by Minco, presumably at the next ANTA Minco meeting, but I do not have that date in my head. That meeting, for whatever reason, could be cancelled. A MCEETYA meeting was cancelled recently. COAG was called off the day before. Who knows? Following that, it then has to go to the Governor-General. So I cannot help you with a specific date.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not mean to ask for a specific date for that next ministerial council meeting, but can you give me an approximate time when they are likely to make the appointments?
—It is expected to be in about April or May next year.

PARA.TAB: That the amendments (Senator Vanstone's ) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

BREAK.PARA: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Vanstone) read a third time.
[COGNATE BILL:]
HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996
Debate resumed from 28 November, on motion by Senator Tambling:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was speaking on this piece of legislation the other day I had made the point that it had taken the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) and the Howard budget to get students, staff and vice-chancellors to unite in public protest against reduced funding to universities, increased costs for students and reduced places. It is a litany of broken promises and very family unfriendly.

SPEECH.PARA: I had said that the families of Australia are now concerned about the costs of education and are anticipating that they will have to start saving now to cover the costs that their children will face in years to come, to which Minister Vanstone said, `rubbish.' She then tried to explain that she was only saying `rubbish' to me and not to the families of Australia. But Minister Vanstone is saying `rubbish' to the families of Australia. She is saying that these protests are really nothing to fuss about; they are just people protecting their own territory; they are not serious; and they are not family unfriendly.

They are not only very family unfriendly but are also very unfriendly to our society. When the Labor government came into office in 1983, it took over from Malcolm Fraser's very low record in education. Retention rates at schools were about 37 per cent and the number of university places was some 200,000‐plus less than they are now. It has taken a decade or more of commitment by the former Labor government to turn this society around into valuing education.

I well remember objections from those opposite when we talked about students being retained at school. They wanted to argue, `You're just doing it to get the unemployment numbers down.' No, we were not. We were doing it because we were committed to education.

That commitment to education is something that clearly makes a difference not only to individuals and to their families but also to society. Australia has a much better prospect if we have a very large education base on which to build our businesses, our jobs, our research and development, our hospitality industry and our sporting facilities—everything. Based on education, our society is only going to do better.

We see a very negative step being taken in the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill. One of the most amazing arguments being put by both the minister and Senator Tierney is that if we allow people to pay then we will increase their choices. Under the previous system there was an option of going to university and paying back a HECS charge when and if you earned sufficient income. Nobody was denied access. But now that they have the pleasure of paying to be able to go to university, it is extraordinary to argue that this is somehow an increase in choice. Most people do not see the option of paying for what previously they did not have to pay for as being an increase in choice. They see it as a setback, as an increased liability and as a very big negative. When families talk about the challenges of job insecurity and making their money go further, they are already citing increased costs of child care and education as two very big outlays that are causing them grave concern.

Increasing the so‐called choice by allowing people to pay means that those people have not been able to get into university on merit—on the figures as a result of their higher education, mature age entry or whatever. In other words, it is clearly for the cream of society—the thick and the rich. Poor people will not be able to get in.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is misleading and you know it.

—I say to Senator Vanstone that the poor people are not going to be able to find the money. It is clearly only for those who will be able to afford to get in, the people who have not been able to get in as a result of a sufficient matriculation score or tertiary entry score—only those who did not achieve their place under those results and those who can afford to pay. It is not a way to increase representation in our universities of the broad scale or people from the poorest income end.

SPEECH.PARA: If that is not obvious to the government, it certainly is obvious to the community. They know full well that to be able to pay for a place means you have got to have sufficient income. That is not the way you define the poor or the lowest income end of our society. It is an absolute nonsense to say that you increase choice by allowing people the option to pay for what previously they did not have to pay for. If you believe that argument, then most people in our society would be laughing themselves sick at your logic.

TALK.START.PARA: —A disgraceful contribution from you.
—No, it is a very important point, minister. People who previously did not have to pay—
—It is a disgraceful, misleading contribution.

—It is not a misleading contribution. It seems pretty obvious to my colleagues on this side and it is obvious to people in the community. It is no increase in choice to now be able to pay for what previously you did not have to pay for. The reason that you would be exercising that choice is because you did not rate a place under a sufficient tertiary entrance score. If that is not obvious to you, then you are being sold a pup, minister. I actually think you know full well what you are doing and you are actually selling the pup. The community is not going to cop it.

BREAK.PARA: Another special message that you have for people under this bill is that they can start repaying their higher education charge on an income of $20,000 instead of $28,000, as was previously the case. What is more, they will pay at three per cent, which is about $12 a week. To quote the minister, `That's not much, just a night at the cinema,' I think you said, but it might have been a night at the pictures.

In the other place, the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, wants to boast that an $8 a week increase in wages to those at the lowest income end is a great contribution from this government. Tell me: who is going to get the $8 a week? By and large, people on such low incomes as $20,000. Those are your low income earners—well below AWE, which is about $28,000. So here are these people, whose income is well below average weekly earnings, being asked to pay $12 a week—just a night at the pictures—and at the same time Mr Howard wants to tell us that giving those same people $8 a week means that those people are now in clover.

The increase will not even pay for their HECS repayment. If it is just a night at the pictures, then ring up Mr Howard and tell him not to make a song and dance about $8. If it is just a night at the pictures to pay back $12, then $8 a week is no great contribution. The idea of giving battlers a great gift of an increase of $8 a week in their wages but whacking $12 out—just a night at the pictures—to make their HECS repayment is very, very contradictory.
Senator Vanstone interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You may laugh, minister, but the battlers on $20,000 won't. Why do you want to do this? It is because you want to manipulate the equation and try to disguise just how much you are cutting out of the higher education sector.
—Out of the sector, you say.

—Out of the higher education sector—a mass of cuts under this bill. As I say, they are already broken promises. Operational grants to universities have been significantly cut. If you think that is not the case, you might ring the vice‐chancellors and ask them why they are already laying off significant numbers of staff and already cutting significant numbers of courses.

BREAK.PARA: Choice, if you talk about options at a tertiary college, is now being dramatically reined in. It is not choice to say that previously you could do a certain course at the Adelaide University and as of next year you will not be able to do it. Most people see that, very clearly, as a significant reduction in choice, to say nothing of the loss of jobs of the people who taught those courses or helped to administer those courses.

Indeed, your own colleague in South Australia, Minister Such, knows full well the impact of these cuts in terms of the economy of South Australia, which is not exactly rippling along. You could call Mr Olsen on this matter. You certainly called in a lot of your Liberal colleagues to dump the premier who was mismanaging the economy of South Australia. Flat, dull—and what are you proposing? To help them even further by taking more money out of this considerable education contribution to the economy in South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the economy your mob gutted $4 billion out of.

—You can talk about whatever you like, minister, regarding what happened in the past, but we are here today to talk about what you are proposing to do right now. You are shameless in challenging people, with a significant increase in costs, to go to university, and at a significant rate of repayment.

BREAK.PARA: The last point I want to raise is one on which I will put a question to you, minister: you have already allowed, with the differential HECS, that people, particularly in science, will perhaps be turned off from applying to participate in that area of tertiary study. We have already seen a 13 to 20 per cent drop in some institutions in applications to do this. You have said, particularly after the challenge from your colleague Mr McGauran, that you would take note of this, you would be watching it closely and you would want to adjust it if that seemed necessary. On what criteria will you judge that you would have to act? That is my question, minister. At some stage I would be very pleased if you would like to give us some measure of some criteria.

TALK.START.PARA: —A 20 per cent drop in enrolments, perhaps.
—You might think that is a significant figure. But it is important for the minister to tell us what she judges to be a significant figure. I ask the minister: how will she know and when will she act?

BREAK.PARA: Secondly, can she give us her response to the point made very well by Senator Carr in his contribution about two teachers in a school, one teaching science and one teaching history, both earning the same income but with a very significant difference in HECS debt and rate of repayment? Does that not cause the minister to worry? It does not, the minister indicates with a shake of her head—it does not give her any cause for concern at all. That is an important point for the families of Australia to note, particularly any prospective science teachers. Don't worry, the minister does not care at all. She is not the slightest bit concerned that you might have a bigger debt than the teacher in the next room on the same income.

A lot of people are concerned. The minister has indicated some concern, but is her concern only about the rate of applications to do science? We need to hear an answer on that because it is a grave concern. This country has been slow to appreciate the importance of investment in science and engineering—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are voting against it, anyway.
—I do not know whether I should be listening to your contribution at this time. You might like to give it to us in your summing up on this debate.
—Since you are voting against it, why are you asking the questions?
—I want to know the answers, but not now, not on my time. I would like the minister to give us her criteria. She said she would take it into account but she is not going to give us the criteria.

BREAK.PARA: There are many points that need to be made in the course of this debate on the second reading of this bill. Other people have made a number of the points that I would like to make. I just note the point made on page 38 of the dissenting report from the Senate Employment Education and Training Legislation Committee:

The Government's stated intention is to limit the number of fee paying places available to Australian students to 25 per cent of domestic undergraduates in any course. By refraining from enshrining this limit in legislation, the Government is very clearly reserving the option to change the proportions at any time in the future. The point warrants repetition. If this amendment is passed, there will be no legislative impediment to prevent the Minister from so acting.
When the minister was asked whether that was the case and why the 25 per cent ceiling was not specified in the bill, her response was:
The proposal was put and accepted that this is a clean way to do this. It is neat.
It might be neat in legislative design, but it is very dangerous that there is an opportunity for the percentage to be arbitrarily changed.

Finally, I would like to say that the minister has taken some 17,000 places out of the higher education sector, and most of those are in postgraduate programs. This will have a very backward effect on education in this country. It will be one way in which we will positively encourage a brain drain.

Also significant is the number of people turning to postgraduate course work—people who have only that option or people who prefer that option. That is not a kind change to tertiary education. This is not a way in which we are expanding the number of places or the number of options for students. It is a way of introducing significant cutbacks, significant loss of choice, and a significant increase in the contribution students or their families make to the cost of tertiary education.

One of the things that seems to have escaped the minister's attention is that most of the students in our universities are anything but flush. In 10 or 20 years time they might finish up on reasonable incomes. As students, they are doing it tough. This bill will not help them. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. This bill should be seen in the context of this government's commitment to quality, diversity and innovative change in higher education. Firstly, contrary to some of the claims being made, this bill and some of the issues now being debated are not a bolt out of the blue, as is claimed by the opposition. Issues such as differential HECS were being debated as far back as the 1980s. In fact, the report of the Senate committee notes the report of former Premier Neville Wran on this issue when he headed a 1989 committee on higher education funding. The provision for undergraduate fees has also been an issue of public debate for some years.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee's report deals with the issue of the bill's effect on the low socio‐economic status groups. Again, there has been a great deal of misinformation put out by our colleagues on the other side of the chamber. The committee report states:
. . . there is no conclusive evidence to prove that fees and participation rates by equity groups are inversely related.

As the report shows, both the department and Professor Bruce Chapman concurred that the introduction of HECS did not deter student participation in higher education. The department went further, stating that there has been:

. . . minimal change in relative numbers of different socio‐economic groups participating in higher education over the last twenty years, despite the changes to tertiary fees and introduction of HECS during this period.

I would like to move to the issue of fee paying for domestic students, something that was mentioned by Senator Crowley. Before I do, I would like to detail the way in which this bill provides for the introduction of 4,000 merit equity scholarships between 1997 and 2000, the maintenance of the existing higher education equity program at an annual cost of $5.8 million, and the maintenance of the regional disability liaison officer initiative for another year at a cost of $750,000 to coordinate the provision of services for students with disabilities.

BREAK.PARA: I move to the issue of fee paying domestic students. The key point here is that the fee paying places are additional to the number of government funded places made available for Australian students. There is no sense in which fee paying places will replace government funded places. There is a ceiling on the proportion of full fee paying positions that universities can make available. That will act as a check to ensure that privately funded enrolments do not crowd out publicly funded enrolments in universities.

This bill will be an opportunity for the higher education sector to respond more closely to market forces. Revenue from privately funded students is expected not only to increase the supply of places in higher education but also it should expose the sector to a greater degree of demand pressure because students will have increased scope to choose among universities. This bill deserves the chamber's full support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Troeth summed it up: `This bill will give higher education an opportunity to respond more closely to market forces.' It is a `let's leave it to the stock exchange' bill. It is a `let's divest government of its responsibility and hand it across to the private sector' bill. Increasingly universities are forced to act more like corporations than as centres for the extension of education and wellbeing to the whole community. As previous speakers on this side have put it so clearly, this is a device for giving favoured treatment to those with money in their pockets as against those without. Government members opposite, including the minister, can shake their heads as much as they like but that is exactly what it is about.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to relay to the Senate some of the lobbying that has come from people who represent those who are concerned about this issue, that is, the students. I quote from the release put out by the National Union of Students last week:

The bill seeks to introduce up-front fees for Australian undergraduate students, increase the level of HECS by between 35 and 125 per cent, introduce a system of HECS whereby different fees are charged for different courses, and lower the thres hold at which HECS repayments must begin to just $20,701 per annum.
The National President of NUS, Lori Faraone, said today:

There has never been a more blatant attack on access to higher education in Australia's history. If successful, this Government will be remembered as the one which removed the hopes of virtually all people from disadvantaged backgrounds of ever getting into university.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish!
—The government member opposite says, `What rubbish' but maybe he is in his halcyon post‐student days where he can afford to sit back and, on a big salary, say that.
—No. I chaired the inquiry. I heard all the evidence. It's opening up choice.

—For the chair of an inquiry, having heard the evidence, to be dismissive of those who disagree with his point of view as `rubbish' is one of the problems the government has. So I will continue with the alternative point of view, which I do not class as rubbish. Ms Faraone went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: NUS calls on all non-
Government Senators—
that is us on this side and around the bend on the cross‐benches—
to act in the interests of those people who will never make it to university if this bill is passed and to decline to support the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be more government funded undergraduate places next year.
—We will get on to your assertions about more government funded places which are cheaper for people in the future than they are now. Ms Faraone went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: No matter what the Coalition threatens to do, it is vital that this bill is stopped—the future of access to education in Australia depends on it being stopped.
From the same union David Taylor said:

Senator Vanstone is trying to convince the public of the merits of her proposal by highlighting the fact that disadvantaged people remain largely excluded from higher education. This is remarkably poor logic and history on the part of the Minister. The period in which access to education has improved most was between 1974 and 1986 when there were no tuition fees and student financial support was set at a livable level. Senator Vanstone's comparison of participation of access between 1980 and 1989 in the Senate yesterday—
this is last week—
shows that she either does not understand the history or she is wilfully attempting to mislead the public. The figures which she presents are quite damning to her own position.
He went on to say:

If disadvantaged people are not gaining access to higher education under the current system of deferred fees of $2,400 per annum then the situation will only get much, much worse if these fees are increased to between $3,300 and $5,500 per annum and up-front fees are allowed to be charged.
It seems pretty logical to me. He went on:
The Coalition is giving up on the idea of disadvantaged people going to university—they have decided it is just too hard, so they are not even trying to fix the problem.

As a Tasmanian senator I am particularly concerned about these bills. I want to read again from a letter by University of Tasmania Branch President Paula Baron of the National Tertiary Education Industry Union. Here is what she had to say in this letter, which has gone to everybody in the Senate and which represents not my point of view but the lobbying from the students themselves:

I write to convey to you my complete opposition to the government's proposed changes to the Higher Education Funding Act, and to urge you to oppose the particular provisions which will result in Tasmanians being denied the opportunity of participating in higher education because of its prohibitive cost.

The particular provisions to which I refer will result in significant changes to the higher education contributions scheme, will allow the charging of up-front fees to over-quota undergraduate students, and will allow the charging of additional fees to undergraduate students in publicly funded places.
She goes on to say:

For the University of Tasmania, the Federal Government's operating grant reductions, a clear breach of their election promise to `at least maintain higher education funding in real terms', mean that 500 less Tasmanian students will be able to study in 1988, and according to University management about 160 jobs will be lost over the next three years.

This alone will have a dramatic and negative effect on Tasmania. The proposed amendments to the Higher Education Funding Act will further damage higher education in this State. Because of Tasmania's lower than national average weekly earnings and depressed economy the proposed cost increases for study, ranging from 40 to 125 per cent for publicly funded places, and up‐front fees which currently average around $8,000 a year, will significantly reduce access to higher education, particularly for low to middle income earning families.

The Government's amendments will have a disproportionately large effect on Tasmania because it has only one university, because its people generally earn less than elsewhere in Australia and because Tasmania already has a poor record of attracting students to higher education.

For all these reasons I urge you most strongly to block the Government's proposals relating to changes to HECS and the charging of up-front fees for undergraduate places. These proposals will be nothing less than an unmitigated disaster for the people of Tasmania, and for the future of higher education in this State.

I only hope that, although he is not listed and has not spoken, Senator Harradine is going to respond to that sort of lobbying from Tasmanians, who are totally alarmed by the cuts to education at all levels that this government is bringing before the Senate. His is a pivotal vote in determining whether Tasmanians will or will not lose out in this matter. The electorate would expect that he would be here to explain his defence of the Tasmanian interests as he votes on this side or why he simply allows Tasmania to be opened up to the disproportionate disadvantage that we have just heard about and that will come from these cuts. They effectively mean that if you are rich you can get in, if you are poor you cannot and if you are in the middle you will have to make up your mind.

Senator Vanstone and other government members can argue as they will. There is independent and very authoritative opinion, which I will not go into now, which clearly puts the thumb on the way in which this is going to distress students. It is going to deter them. We have already seen the turn‐off in numbers of people applying for important courses in tertiary education. It is going to simply see hundreds of people in this country, who ought to be getting an incentive to go on to tertiary education and therefore their rightful opportunity to work and fulfilment in our society in the next century, not getting there at all.

It is muddle‐headed. It is market economics. It is not thought out. It is doctrinaire. It is going to be very damaging to education in this country and very divisive in the long run to a society that has been well known for its fair go and egalitarian approach.

I think even Bob Menzies would roll his eyes if he could hear that here we have a Liberal government in the 1990s going in the opposite direction to his ideal—that everybody should have access to and be afforded the opportunity of tertiary education. It is a pretty backward day for education in this country. I just hope that when Senator Harradine and fellow Independent Senator Colston cast their votes, they will be on the side—if not of the angels—of kids and all people getting a fair access to tertiary education, which is a right no less than that to primary and secondary education in this day and age in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to commence by referring to another of what has become a litany of broken promises by the coalition government. In its pre‐election higher education policy statement `Quality, diversity and choice' the coalition stated that it would:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . at least maintain the level of Commonwealth funding for universities in terms of operating grants and research grants.
The coalition also undertook to:
. . . maintain higher education funding in real terms
However, once again we have seen a massive turnaround. In the 1996 budget statement, the minister announced cuts of five per cent to operating grants to 1998.

The government, in their proposed legislation, intend significant changes to the higher education contribution scheme, to allow the charging of up‐front fees to over quota undergraduate students, and to allow the charging of additional fees to undergraduate students in publicly funded places. These proposed changes and cuts to operating grants will have a disastrous effect on low income communities such as Tasmania.

Like Senator Brown, I would like to take a moment to explain to senators the situation of university education in Tasmania. Tasmania has only one university. Students have no alternative institutions within the state. The university is divided into two campuses at each end of the state, so any cuts to services and course availability will have a severe impact on Tasmanian families. A five per cent cut to operating grants to 1998, based on current forward estimates, will mean that in 1998 the University of Tasmania will receive 2.9 per cent less in government funding than it actually received for 1996. In dollar terms, we are talking about $3 million less.

As Senator Brown has indicated, we are talking about 500 fewer student places than had been allocated previously for 1998. Again, as Senator Brown has said, we are talking about 160 jobs which will disappear in that institution over three years. I do not think I need to tell the Senate that with Tasmania having one of the highest—if not the highest—levels of unemployment of any state in Australia, a loss of 160 jobs is devastating.

According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures on household expenditure and characteristics by state, the average income for Tasmanian families is the lowest in the country. And, as I said, Tasmania has the highest unemployment of any state. It also has difficulty attracting students to higher education. Tasmania has the highest proportion of young graduates who leave the state to look for employment elsewhere. An increase in charges to students in Tasmania may well mean that they decide to leave the state before commencing their course, because other metropolitan universities can offer more choice. In fact, now more than 50 per cent of all young graduates leave the state of Tasmania.

The state cannot afford any reduction in the level of service provided by the University of Tasmania. The university council so far has already endorsed the following cost cutting measures in response to the budget: firstly, the relocation of the urban design course to Launceston—previously this course was accessed by students in both Launceston and Hobart; secondly, the closure of the Italian department; thirdly, the closure of the Asian studies department in Launceston; fourthly, a reduction in access and services provided by the four libraries at the Hobart campus; and, fifthly, a review of the physics and engineering departments with a view to closing or substantially cutting their operations. There is also a question over the future of the medical school.

Many Tasmanian students will have to relocate within the state, attempt to study by distance mode or leave the state in order to access the course that they chose to do. What kind of choice is that? According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures that I quoted earlier, the average weekly income for a Tasmanian family is $620. An increase in the cost of attending university will put the relocation option out of reach of many Tasmanian families. People on low incomes will not be able to seek a higher education if the cost is prohibitive. I ask the government again: where is the choice in these circumstances?

The government shift to full fee paying students will, in fact, disadvantage the University of Tasmania. In Tasmania, there are only 115 full fee paying postgraduates enrolled out of a national total of 16,000. There just is not a market for fee paying students in many disciplines, so the University of Tasmania cannot hope to capture a big proportion of that market. I fail to understand how the government can believe that the University of Tasmania could be expected to benefit from this measure. It cannot offer the course variety in a low income state as it is not in the same market. The university is not going to be in as good a position to attract fee paying students as the large metropolitan universities in the mainland states. This is in fact a reduction of choice for Tasmanians and a reduction in access to higher education for Tasmanian families.

The coalition government also intends to charge full fees to over quota students. The proposed cost increases for study—ranging from 40 per cent to 125 per cent for publicly funded places and up‐front fees which currently average around $8,000 per year and could escalate to $15,000 per year—will spell the death knell to the dreams of many low income earning families of a university education. A university education, which is a reality for all at the moment, will once again be a privilege that only the wealthy can afford. Is this offering choice?

This is a policy which reduces quality, diversity and choice. Yet Senator Robert Hill, in his role as shadow spokesperson for higher education, in a speech to the third annual meeting of deputy and pro‐ vice chancellors at the ANU in November last year, stated:
We will . . . continue the HECS structure as an appropriate students' contribution to the cost of a student's education. Undergraduate degrees will continue to be funded as at present.

That is yet another broken election promise, demonstrated by the coalition's decision to lower the threshold for the HECS repayment to $20,700 per annum, or less than $400 per week, and increase the rate of repayment.
Page 12 of the coalition document `Quality, diversity and choice' states:

Commonwealth funding of undergraduate degrees, subject to the current HECS, will remain the principal contribution to access. The coalition consistently has opposed changes to HECS rules after a student has begun study and will maintain this position in government.

The Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill, however, will change the HECS rules for current students by immediately lowering the threshold at which payments would begin and by increasing the rates of repayment.

Currently, HECS is not payable for those with an income below $28,495. Some students, such as part-time mature age students, who may be supporting a family, will find themselves repaying HECS before they have finished their study. This is despite the assurances of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on Sydney Radio 2UE on 15 August of this year when he said:
. . . the HECS charge does not start until you have left university . . . you don't pay anything until you've gone through university.

For a student or a recent graduate earning $20,700 per year, this will amount to over $12 per week. For students or graduates with dependants already struggling to survive on less than $400 per week, and that is obviously before tax, this could be a serious financial hardship.

Given the low rate of average weekly earnings in Tasmania, many graduates may have to make the decision to move interstate in the hope of earning a higher income in order to meet the requirement to pay their HECS debt faster. The loss of talented and qualified Tasmanians to other states is detrimental to Tasmania's future.

Among bachelor degree graduates aged less than 25 in their first full‐time employment, nearly 30 per cent already leave the state to find employment. Of other graduates in full‐time employment, nearly 22 per cent leave to pursue work. That is a figure which exceeds that of every state in Australia except the ACT. Already more than 50 per cent of graduates leave Tasmania, and this is a terrible loss to a small state.

I now want to touch upon the issue of differential HECS charges. Over 50 per cent of current students enrolled in the University of Tasmania are enrolled in discipline areas which fall into the middle or top band for new HECS charges. Those students will be paying greatly increased charges, amounting to between 30 per cent and 80 per cent of the real cost of their education. It is quite possible that these increased charges could deter students from entering disciplines in higher cost areas.

The faculties of science and law could be undermined in Tasmania to the point of having to close down. Already the Department of Physics is under review, and the law department has concerns for its future. The equity of this situation leaves me at a loss. There appears to be a blind assumption that students in these middle or top bands of disciplines will always earn middle or top range salaries. This, to me, seems to be inherently unfair.

The most commonly used example to demonstrate this flaw is that of a law graduate. According to the graduate destination survey of 1995 produced by the Graduate Careers Council of Australia, 32.3 per cent of law graduates are not working as lawyers. Of those that are working as lawyers, not all work in high paying corporate law offices. Some may choose to work in the area of legal aid, reduced though those services will be by the coalition's attack on legal aid funding. These people make a decision to work in an area of law which is not as lucrative as others but is essential for our community, and for this they should be admired. Instead, the government chooses to charge them an inflated HECS debt.

Graduates in medicine will be required to pay very high HECS fees whilst, on the other hand, the coalition government is commencing a system whereby they may not even be able to access a Medicare provider number. People with degrees who decide to work in lower paying disciplines—such as youth workers or counsellors—could be subject to grossly inflated charges based on what the coalition believes they might earn as opposed to what they will earn in the real world.

I refer senators again to the findings of the graduate destination survey of 1995 conducted by the Graduate Careers Council of Australia. This survey clearly shows that, of those students who graduate in computer science—a band 2 course attracting a HECS contribution of $4,700 per annum—54.2 per cent have gone to full-time employment in the education sector, a career which will not afford them the high rate of remuneration that apparently the government has determined.

The survey also shows that 11.9 per cent of economics graduates are working in clerical positions. Over 20 per cent of aeronautical engineering graduates are not working in the traditional occupations of this industry. Also, 16.4 per cent of civil engineering graduates are not working in engineering. What about those graduates who work part time and earn more than $400 per week? They will still have to pay the higher HECS band debt, without the fulfilment of the earnings that the coalition has determined they will earn.

PARA.BREAK: The coalition must recognise that prospective students will be discouraged from undertaking a course of studies such as civil engi neering, which attracts a band 2 HECS debt, when there is a 16 per cent chance they will not find employment in the industry, yet they will have to pay the debt for working in that industry. In architecture, which is a band 2 course, 20 per cent of graduates do not find work in that field. Only 3.7 per cent of psychology graduates found work as psychologists. I refer senators to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on Thursday, 28 November, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that applications for science related courses have dropped by an average of 13% nationally.
The University of Western Sydney has already seen a reduction in enrolments for engineering `of over 40 per cent'. The Hobart Mercury of Saturday, 30 November states:
A total of 5,057 applications have been received for 1997 compared with 5,412 in 1996.
That refers to enrolments at the University of Tasmania. The article continues:
Releasing the figures in Hobart yesterday, Deputy Vice Chancellor Rudi Lidl blamed the drop on uncertainty surrounding Higher Education Contribution Schemes increases.

Students are making decisions on their careers and their lives based on the increased level of HECS. Many people from disadvantaged communities will not be able to afford to study in courses that attract higher fees. We will be doing a disservice not only to the students but also to this country as a whole by limiting access to talented students for purely economic reasons.

Let us think again about the threshold of $20,700. What of the people who are earning that rate of pay? What work might they be doing? What sort of award classification might apply to them? On what criteria has the coalition pulled this figure from the air? It has obviously not been done with any understanding of the lifestyle of someone on that income.

Let us look at this scenario. A young person leaves university with a law degree. Their differential HECS rate falls into the top band. This person is unable to find work in the discipline of law because of the ever increasing levels of unemployment. So the person finds a job in a restaurant and, as a grade 3 attendant under the award, earns $409.50 per week—$21,294 per annum. You deduct tax of $71.70. He or she could pay about $100 a week for rent, $80 for food, $10 for power and $10 for phone. The cost of petrol and repayments on, say, a car could be $80 per week. Insurance, clothing, consumables could be another $50 per week. In fact, total expenditure with tax out of that $409.50 would be around $401.70, which does not leave them enough to pay the HECS. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which sets out those figures. I have not shown it to the whip, but it is basically the figures I was talking about.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I challenge the government to show how this person can afford to pay HECS on this salary. The question I have for the coalition, which claims to be for the battlers of this country, is: are these people not the battlers? Should you not be honouring your commitment of 16 May 1995 to demonstrate a commitment to the Australian battlers, or is that just another non-core promise to add to the growing list?

SPEECH.PARA: I ask senators opposite if they have a commitment to the future of this country and if they believe that people of the same ability should be discriminated against on the basis of wealth, because, effectively, that is what this bill is saying. By these bills, the coalition seeks to deny future generations of young Australians potentially an opportunity to be the best that they can be simply because they cannot afford to pay.

It appears to me that this government is not committed to the battlers and is not committed to the future of this country in this regard. The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) in the budget papers has promised a review of higher education funding. If the outcome of this bill is so uncertain that the minister has to promise a review, surely the minister admits that she lacks the confidence in the efficacy of this measure.

What controls will parliament have of the process of the review and changes to the legislation once it is in place? The cynics amongst us would say that in many cases government reviews only find what governments want them to. Even if the review finds against aspects of this bill, what rock solid guarantees are we being given that this government will backtrack on this issue? Given the government's performance on other rock solid guarantees, what would they be worth?

If this government had any integrity, it would withdraw this bill and allow a full review now before progressing down a path which will have damaging effects on the future of higher education in this country. These are bad bills. If the majority of the Senate is minded to pass them, perhaps they should be subject to sunset clauses and the Senate should establish its own mechanism to review the effects of the bill over the next 12 months.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 7.00 to 8.00 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak out against the privatisation by stealth of higher education in this country. We have seen this government move to take vital funds out of community based child care. We have seen them devastate regional Australia through cuts to regional programs, the closure of Medicare and tax offices and closure of essential Family Court facilities. We have seen them slash labour market programs and take away the employment hopes of tens of thousands of Australians. No doubt very soon we will see the long‐term unemployed `exit case management'—a euphemism for dropping them off the books and relegating them to lifelong unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: Now we are here to debate changes to higher education in this country which will see thousands of young Australians denied fair access to quality tertiary education. Over the 13 years of Labor government the participation rate for Australians in higher education grew to produce thousands of extra university places. A well educated population forms the basis of hope for the future of a progressive nation. A fair and equitable higher education contribution system extended that access to all Australians.

This government cannot see the social and economic importance of this. All they can see is a balance sheet and they do not like the total. Their answer is to pour money out of universities, reduce their quality and deny access to our young people. This is the mind‐set of the archetypal bookkeeper with the half‐moon glasses and the fingertips cut from the gloves poring over rows of numbers looking for a dollar to save.
There is no vision in these bills. It is not only the young who are disheartened by the proposed changes. Let me quote from yesterday's Australian:

The proposed higher education contribution scheme increases soon to be debated in the Senate are being blamed for the national slump in demand for university places for mature‐age students. The drop in mature‐aged student demand will be devastating for universities. . . where preliminary figures have already shown applications from school‐leavers are down. Universities were hoping mature‐aged students would help make up the short‐fall.
This bill is irrational and it is sending the wrong message.

The Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill will: allow universities to charge full fees to undergraduate students, subject to ministerial guidelines—for example, the percentage of students who are to be on HECS. These guidelines are subject to the minister's whim, and do not even need to be approved by parliament. They will allow universities to charge fees to students in government‐funded places, again, subject only to ministerial guidelines; will completely deregulate open learning, allowing the Open Learning Agency unlimited power to charge fees—until now of course the cost per unit has been matched to the HECS charge, and payable through a deferred payment scheme—and will dramatically increase the level of fees payable through the higher education contribution scheme, reduce the threshold at which payments commence, and increase rates of payment.

This government is breaking yet another election promise—adding to what is already a long list. This government, as other senators said before me, promised not to cut university funding and make no changes to HECS arrangements that would affect existing students. This bill will require current students earning above the new low repayment threshold to immediately commence HECS repayments.

All current and future students will commence repayments when they are earning $20,700 per annum—well below average weekly earnings—and will be required to pay at an accelerated rate. This constitutes the worst type of breach of trust. This government has no mandate to make these devastating cuts to higher education.

The government went to the election, as other senators have already indicated, promising to redress the problems caused by so‐called `underfunding'. Let me repeat that. This government went to the people of Australia and promised to redress the problems caused by the so‐called `underfunding' of education. Not only are they planning to cut funding but they are planning to deregulate open learning, increase HECS and permit universities to charge up‐front fees to undergraduates. The government has no mandate for this.

Places for students with fat wallets have been created at the expense of students without the dollars to buy a place. In the higher education budget statement, the minister states that full fees can only be charged for undergraduate places over the government funded quota and that only 25 per cent of places in any course could be filled by full‐fee‐paying students. However, there are no such safeguards in the legislation. The percentage of fee‐paying places is up to ministerial guidelines—which can be changed at any time.

Universities may well be forced to compete for students who can afford to pay up‐front fees. Universities may be forced to put more resources into those disciplines which provide them with the greatest return. What will we see? The return of medicine and law to family dynasties?

Funding cuts mean fewer places overall full stop. Access will be reduced for those who cannot afford to pay up‐front fees. By changing the threshold for HECS repayment many low income earners will be put off entering study.

Already, Senator Vanstone, the minister responsible for this bill, and the Minister for Science and Technology, Peter McGauran, have agreed to `revisit' the increases to HECS if necessary. They plan to wait and watch things go wrong and then they will try and repair the damage.

If you have managed to overcome the barriers, decided to put yourself into debt and enter a higher education institution, now you have to start repaying the debt sooner. This is a direct breach of the promise to oppose changes to HECS rules after a student has begun to study.

A family with two children would commence repaying HECS while living below the poverty line. Some incentive! Part‐time students will be the hardest hit. Many of these people are working to pay their way through university, and these students may now have to start paying HECS immediately.

Students in publicly funded places will be paying up to 80 per cent of the cost of their education under the new proposed HECS arrangements. Law and legal studies students will pay back 80.5 per cent of the cost of their course administration and business studies students will pay back 68.8 per cent of the cost of their course. Education students will repay 37.5 per cent. Science teachers will have to pay back more HECS than English teachers, even though they earn the same salary. This is clearly a farcical situation. That is, of course, if we have any science teachers left over the next few years.

By introducing differential fees for education, the government is supporting differential access to education. Differential fees mean differential access. This bill also allows universities to charge additional fees to HECS liable students. From next year, students will be liable for a range of additional charges, without any fixed restrictions.

New HECS and fee paying arrangements will create an administrative nightmare for universities. Each student will now have their HECS liability calculated on an individual basis, semester by semester—according to which subject they undertake and which band payment it fits into. With regard to fees, universities will have to institute new systems to charge fees and ensure that they fit within the yet unspecified guidelines.

The changes to HECS will impact dramatically on my home state of Tasmania—and I would like to acknowledge the contribution of other Tasmanian senators so far in this debate. Tasmania's average student age is 27. Some areas like the north‐west coast of the state have an average student age of 34. Many of these people have families, and family income levels will clearly be adversely affected.

The whole disaster for higher education in Tasmania contained in these bills is compounded by the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill. This bill reduces operating grants to universities. What are the estimated reductions to outlays over the next few years? They are: $23.4 million in 1996‐97, $118.5 million in 1997‐98, $215.5 million in 1998‐99 and $266.2 million in 1999 to the year 2000.

The University of Tasmania has already implemented its first stage of budget cutting. The university administration is trying desperately to cover the reduction in operating grants forced on it by the federal government in the August budget. They are talented, dedicated people, faced with the most unpleasant of tasks.
The reduction to operating grants is a clear breach of the government's promise made in its policy document Quality, diversity and choice, which says:
The government will at least maintain the level of Commonwealth funding for universities in terms of operating grants and research grants.

This quote has been stated over and over again in this place. The University of Tasmania, the only university in Tasmania, has already begun to make some very tough decisions. The university has begun to rationalise programs between the two main campuses in Launceston and Hobart. They are attempting to negotiate shared resources with mainland universities. The university is being forced to outsource functions such as administration as far as it possibly can. It is increasing the number of full fee paying students and prioritising its capital works program. Three hundred and eighty student places are to go.

The university is reducing staff levels and axing courses. For example, as I think Senator O'Brien mentioned, students in Tasmania will no longer be able to study Italian. Tasmanian students will no longer be able to study Asian studies on the Launceston campus. Tasmanian students will no longer be able to study architecture in Hobart and they will be offered a significantly reduced range of science subjects. The education course is to close in Hobart and staff are to move to other areas in the south or to Launceston or take a redundancy.

Departmental amalgamations are to occur within humanities: the department of classics is to be absorbed into the history area. Engineering in Launceston is under threat. Staffing at the university is being reduced by 160 full‐time equivalent positions. This will obviously result in a reduction in research capability and teaching quality. Five staff positions are to go from the faculties of law and commerce. Staff reductions are occurring in aboriginal studies and physics. Class sizes will increase. Individual units in courses will be—and are already being—cut. Fewer tutorials will be held. Library staff are to be reduced. There will be reduced book and serial purchases and so on.

Even with these changes, the university will not have met its reduction target and it is looking at further cuts within areas such as health, science, engineering and fine arts. As I said before, the University of Tasmania is our only university. Students cannot choose between different universities offering different course mixes—this is it. You go to the University of Tasmania or you go to the mainland to university. Where would Tasmanian students go to study Italian, for example? They would have to go to the mainland.

The Howard government won the last election on votes from regional Australia—the very areas this government is now discriminating against. Tasmania is one of those. In Tasmania, 87.9 nine per cent of students remain in their own region while they are studying because they cannot afford the cost involved in travelling to study. Tasmanian students stay at home to study.
In its Tasmania package the Liberal government promised to:
support higher education funding for student places based on other than just population growth—
that is, participation rates, regional and historical factors—
ensuring Tasmania receives fair consideration for higher education places.
That is as clear as a bell. You could not misinterpret that.

North and north-west Tasmania are well below the national average for tertiary participation rates and southern Tasmania barely makes the national average. Despite this, and despite the university's commitment to a state‐wide institution with campuses in all regions, there has been no growth in places allocated.

As other Tasmanian senators have said before me, because of Tasmania's lower than average weekly earnings and depressed economy, because of the proposed cost increases for study, ranging from 40 per cent to 125 per cent for publicly funded places, and because of up-front fees which currently average $8,000 per year, access to higher education will be significantly reduced, particularly—and this is no surprise—for low to middle income earners. It is extremely unlikely that up-front fees for over quota courses will generate much additional income for the university. One university council member said:

BREAK.PARA: The argument about up‐front fees is one that this university is likely to abstain from. The only certainty in it is that the reputation of the university will suffer.

The combined effect of these higher education bills is to risk turning the University of Tasmania into a third‐rate university and as such, to us as Tasmanian senators and to this side of politics in general, they are completely unacceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Around the country at the moment, there are thousands upon thousands of students who have just finished, or are finishing, their higher school certificate and who are looking anxiously to next year when many of them would hope to be able to attend a university or a higher education institution. Equally, there are in excess of 600,000 students in universities or higher education institutions in the country who have probably just completed their university exams. They, too, are now anxiously looking to next year to see what is in store for them as a result of this government's legislative changes that it hopes to implement in higher education. In both those cases, the news is grim.

SPEECH.PARA: There is already enough stress on students these days, whether they be finishing their school or completing their higher education studies, without them coming to the end of the year and wondering whether they will be able to afford these increased HECS charges next year; whether, despite their results in the HSC, there will be a place for them at university next year; whether the principles of equity based upon merit—rather than on wealth or socioeconomic standing—that have long characterised the approach to higher education in this country will be abandoned; and whether there will actually be sufficient teachers, other academic staff and university staff in the future.

Over the months since the government was elected, we have seen deep concern expressed right across the education sector. It commenced with the ill-advised, flippant remarks of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone). It is one of the most important portfolios in terms of social policy in this country and in the delivery of one of the two most important sectors that the government is involved in: health and education. This minister for eduction responded to criticism from vice‐chancellors, students, academics, unions and people involved in the education sector by saying, `It's just a nick. We're not really doing much damage to education. We're just ripping out a few hundred million.' As people have watched the performance of the minister, the news gets progressively worse and her performance gets progressively worse.

Let us look at some of the concerns that have been expressed by people in positions such as vice‐chancellor and other senior positions in education. One concern is that this government has not actually included funding for 1999 within its proposals—that is, it has abandoned the previous practice of incorporating forward estimates for the last year of the rolling triennium—thereby creating uncertainty about what is likely to be the case down the track. That concern has been specifically raised by the Vice‐Chancellors Committee and other organisations which are deeply concerned that funding will be eroded further on top of what is proposed in this legislation. What is proposed in this legislation are substantial reductions in government funding in the years 1997 and 1998.

We also have had the response from the minister whose attitude when she spoke to the vice-chancellors earlier in the year was, `Why don't they go out and think of a figure? Why don't they put a price upon what they think their universities should suffer in funding cuts?' She was conducting her portfolio like an auction—pick a figure, whether it be 10 per cent or five per cent. That was her approach when she first flagged these changes. We then had the official announcements some 10 days before the budget. What were those announcements? Cuts across the board within the vicinity of 10 per cent or more; substantial reductions in university places.

On top of that, we had the announcement of a review. It seems to be the attitude of this government that you announce substantial cuts and then you say, `On top of that, we will have a review and see what is really required.' In other words, they put the cart before the horse. That is what they did with the bill relating to government expenditure on school education which we were debating last week. As was pointed out on numerous occasions during that debate, this government has introduced changes which will reduce funding for government schools and abolish the new schools policy. They then said, `We will have a review to see how it all really works.'

The minister has shown the same degree of arrogance with respect to higher education. It is clear, as previous speakers have pointed out—particularly Senator Mackay who told us about the position in her home state of Tasmania—that regional and rural areas of Australia will be hardest hit. A lot of universities in major cities will be hit hard, but universities in rural and regional areas will suffer the most.

It was the previous Labor government that substantially expanded the availability to university higher education for rural and regional students. In my home state of New South Wales, we established universities in places like Coffs Harbour, Lismore, Bathurst /Orange. This provided an opportunity for students in those country towns and nearby rural areas to attend a university nearby. This meant less expense with them not having to move to Sydney, Newcastle, Canberra or wherever to get a place at university. We also recognised the importance and the economic benefits to be gained from expanding the availability to higher education for those in rural and regional Australia. We are now seeing that policy gradually reversed. The cuts that are going to come will be felt particularly hard in rural and regional Australia.

The record of the previous government in higher education and school education is one of undoubted success. This is recognised by participants throughout the spectrum. The number of university students almost doubled from 350,000 to 630,000 in the period of the previous Labor government. Funding was increased in the order of 70 per cent. As I have said, we had policies which resulted in the expansion of universities into regional areas across the country.

BREAK.PARA: That achievement is going to be put at risk because of the changes in this legislation. Let us look at the specific changes. I will firstly look at the direct cuts in higher education funding. The minister says that the cuts will be of the order of $600 million. She calls this a nick. She says, `Nobody should really complain about this because it is just a small amount.' If that is just a nick, I would hate to see the full operation. In any event, this nick will have a permanent negative impact.

That is not a real figure. As Senator Carr pointed out when making the opening speech for the opposition in this second reading debate, the net effect of these changes will be of the order of $1.8 billion. That is what we are looking at over the four‐year period. Those details were provided to the Senate estimates committee. They have not been refuted. Despite all of the wishy-washy attempts to juggle the figures and play with the statistics, that is what we are talking about.

What does that mean? It means for a start that there will be approximately 17,000 fewer Commonwealth funded places over the remaining two years of the current triennium. Members of the government and other senators should think for a moment what that means. Some 17,000 students, who could quite confidently have looked forward to a place at university, will no longer have that opportunity. It means that of the order of 1,500 teaching jobs in universities will go. Predictions are that the figure will be higher than that.

These are not just nicks to the system. These cuts cannot be ridden out. These are substantial cuts. We should think about the effect these changes would have on the students who have just left school, finished their HSC and quite confidently, based on their marks, looked forward to a place at university over the next year or two. That opportunity will go. If you implement these changes this year those people who have just left school will get caught. Where is the planning and where is the consideration that students actually spend three, four or five years at university. These decisions will affect their lives, career opportunities, employment opportunities and so on. Why not have the review first? If you are intent upon having the review, do that first, rather than impose these massive changes, these massive cuts, and then try to put a bandaid over the results.

We also have the changes relating to the introduction of full fees for undergraduate courses. Once again this is opening up the opportunity to get into university for those who happen to be wealthy enough but not necessarily smart enough to get in. No doubt, again, this will impact upon regional areas.

What is it that drives this government, that makes it want to return to the era where an elitist view of university education prevailed? Prior to the early 1970s, when fees were abolished, if you were not smart enough to get into university or you did not work hard enough at school to get the results to get into university through a scholarship system, which obviously provided for the vast bulk of students, you could pay your way in, you could buy yourself a degree. As Senator Mackay quite correctly pointed out, certain professions were the preserve of the wealthy because of that attitude. In the 1970s we got rid of that elitist view and I understood—I hoped, at least—that we had a bipartisan approach, whereby education was now about equity, about recognising merit and about giving opportunity to all kids, regardless of whether they had come from a wealthy background. But that does not seem to be the attitude of this government, not only in this area of policy but in a range of other policy areas. They simply want to turn back the clock.

What do we get in response? We get people like Senator Tierney saying, `Well, we are going to provide 4,000 scholarships. In case anyone is worried about introducing full paying fees for undergraduate courses, we are going to introduce scholarships—1,000 a year for four years.' Seventeen thousand places go over two years, and you bring in 1,000 scholarships a year. What a joke. The other response is, `If any university does the wrong thing—if it does not first fill its quota of HECS paying students but actually enrols students on full fees—we will fine them $9,000. Senator Tierney made great play of this. This is your approach to equity, Senator Kemp. This is your government's approach to equity: `We will impose a penalty.'

It seems that this government cannot look at any area of policy, whether it be industrial relations or health or education, without taking a negative approach. The negative approach is, `Let's take something away.' It will be the dental health scheme if you are a pensioner. It will be some entitlements to social security if you are a newly arrived migrant. It will be some government funding if you happen to be a student in a government school. In this case it will be places at universities. That is all negative stuff; it is all about imposing penalties. Your whole rationale about guaranteeing equity is: `We are going to fine a university.' What a joke. Universities do not exist to pay fines, they exist to educate students, to make this country a more clever country.

Finally we have the increases to the higher education contribution scheme. That is a clear breach of promise. The coalition went to the election guaranteeing no changes in these areas. What do we get? We get this double whammy on students. Firstly, the fees will increase from a single rate of $2,442 a year to three variable rates commencing at $3,300 and increasing to $5,500 per year, depending upon the course studied.

It is hard enough for students as it is, working their way through the various options for courses at university. Anyone who has been to university knows that it is a pretty trying time when you first enrol. These new HECS arrangements are complicated to the extreme and will impact very heavily on students' financial wellbeing—both as students and in their future careers. It is an inequitable system because it targets students based upon some assumptions that they will have higher incomes in the future. They may have higher incomes if they are doctors or lawyers, but one would assume they will also be paying higher contributions through the tax system. Then we have the reduction in the threshold from $28,000 to approximately $20,000. Clearly that will have an impact upon students from low income families as well as part-time and mature age students.

This government did get elected on 2 March, but it did not get elected to introduce these sorts of policies, which will lead to a serious reduction in the opportunity for students right across the country to have access to a higher education in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. These bills reflect a myriad of broken promises to the higher education sector. Before the election, the coalition's higher education policy stated that the coalition would address the chronic underfunding of our universities and that they understood the stresses and strains of underfunded and overcrowded universities. That is a very worthy objective.

SPEECH.PARA: What do we find after the election? That the coalition not only did nothing about their promise but also made it worse. Let me put a human face on these cuts. I will just tell the Senate one story from 1993 when I was the chaplain and counsellor at the Queensland University of Technology. I actually have many stories but I will tell you just one.

A desperate female student came to see me, not very long before I came into this place, desperate and in tears. She had spent one year in the university and then, because she had no family support, she had deferred for 12 months to work and to raise enough funds to come back and continue her course. So she went back home to a fairly famous rural town in Queensland, Kingaroy, where famous politicians come from. She worked in hairdressing for 12 months and raised enough money so that she could come back to the university and set herself up in a residence.

However, she discovered after the first few months back at university at the beginning of 1993 that rent and food had taken more than the Austudy that she received, so she had cut into her savings. When she spoke to me, she had reached a stage where there was nothing left for textbooks. She could not get into the library because of the overcrowding that was there. So here she was in the middle of the year, having given up so much of her life and having saved to try to educate herself, finding that all of her effort had virtually been to no avail.
That was in 1993. It was bad enough then. The situation today in 1996 is worse. After we put in place the cuts which are proposed by this government, she would not even bother trying.

Let me run through some of the election promises that have been broken. Before the federal election, the coalition promised universities, their staff and students many things. They promised that they would maintain university operating grants and that they would maintain HECS. They promised they would not lower the repayment threshold. Indeed, they put out a pamphlet crowing about how they had protected students from that dreadful Labor government's attempts to lower the payment threshold. If that is what Australian students thought of the Labor government, what does the coalition government think Australian students think of them? One of their promises was that they would not introduce a voucher system; yet this is exactly what they are doing for open learning students. They are doing this without Senate approval at all.

They promised not to raise taxes. When in opposition they insisted that HECS was a tax. They have now chosen to break that very public promise. Some calculations made by the Democrats on the level of increased tax which the HECS increases entail demonstrate clearly that any gains made by the living wage are negated by the HECS increases. This bill raises taxes for young graduates. If the changes to HECS are passed in this legislation, it will mean that a first year nurse will be paying an extra $24 a week in tax, that a graduate first year scientist will be paying an extra $25 a week in tax and that teachers and interns will be paying an extra $6 to $10 a week in tax.

The coalition pledged—and I am sure many people voted for them because of it—that they would support higher education, maintain operating grants and enhance regional universities. They said that they understood the problems of the expansion of the higher education system without, as they stated in their policy, `a commensurate expansion in the level of funding to the system'.
