The legislation before us shows very little understanding of these problems of chronic underfunding and chronic overcrowding, despite all the promises made before the election.

The problems created by the constant erosion of funding and staff and student morale—these problems have not created a sense of hope for the clever country. Certainly, any idea of a compassionate country has gone out the window. The clever country rhetoric was never backed up with cold hard cash. It has come with the almost annual—even predictable—HECS hikes and other fees and charges, and with the increasing experience of overcrowded lecture theatres and even larger tutorials which are now the norm.

The Democrats firmly believe that it is the obligation of the government to the society to provide education as an investment in our young people. This government, it appears, does not believe in its young people. They say to them, `Yes, we want you to get work. We want you to get a degree so you can get a better job but we are going to make sure that, having taken your first job, you will immediately be saddled with a very large debt.' Fancy saying to the young people of any nation that, as soon as you start work, you will have to start repaying this massive debt with which we have saddled you.

It has been said that universities are simply afraid of change. But change is not something that is a stranger to universities or their students. The adage that the only constant is change has rung particularly true for universities. The role of the 1990s university is markedly different from that of the university in previous generations, or even the university of a decade ago.

The role of the Australian university was the focus of some of the Hawke-Keating government's major policy pronouncements with the overhaul of the binary system and its replacement with a unified national system and the push towards mass education and the clever country. The Dawkins reforms of the mid-1980s took the former binary system of universities and colleges and merged them to create the university system we have today—a national system of large universities and a vast increase in student numbers. I give credit to the Labor Party for the incredible expansion in the number of the university places during their term in government.

But let us not say to universities that they are afraid of change. That is about all they have lived with over the last decade or so. Universities know what it is to change but they cannot change when the only changes they experience are cuts and more cuts. Universities have changed and the fear that has been engendered by the changes foreshadowed in this legislation are not fears of change or fear of the unknown; it is fear of the known, fear of more of the same—more underfunding, more debt, more broken promises. This government has the cheek to say that universities are just afraid of change.

There is much more I could say, but let me finish by saying that, disturbingly, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) has continually invited the sector to break ranks and suggest to her the most appropriate cuts, which sounds fair enough. She has also threatened the Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee that they will face further cuts if they do not kowtow to her legislation.

Let me describe to you what is really happening. It is as though somebody had a group of disadvantaged people, put them in a ring, threw a few crusts into the middle of the ring and then said to them, `Alright, you scrabble, and the one who can scrabble the best will get the most.' That is an appalling way to suggest to universities that they must compete with one another for the very few, meagre crusts that this government is prepared to throw them. The President of the NTEU, Carolyn Allport, said:
The Minister not only wants us to die from the sword of cuts, she wants us to manufacture the sword for her.

The role of the university in Australian society as a place of inquiry, as the cutting edge of social opinion, as the key to the future for many thousands of people, as the only institution which regularly challenges the status quo and so provides some of the checks and balances vital to our democracy, is too important to be treated as a sectoral interest. The fate of our universities is the fate of our society, and the fate of our universities is in our hands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise at this late stage of the debate to put on record once again the position of the opposition in respect of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. As has been expressed quite eloquently during the debate by a number of speakers, there are some quite fundamental problems with this legislation. For that reason, the opposition will be moving amendments to try to overcome some of those problems.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are talking about here are problems in a system of education which has, over recent years, been enhanced in such a way that there has been a revolution of participation in education and a major redressing of equity concerns in education.

No‐one has claimed that what has been achieved over the last 13 years of Labor government, for instance, is perfect. But we do maintain that from 1983 to 1996 there was an increase in student numbers from 350,000 to 630,000; participation of 17‐ to 19‐year‐olds in higher education increased by 60 per cent as a percentage of the age cohort; total Commonwealth funding for universities rose by 70 per cent in real terms during the term of the previous government; and, contrary to claims from some quarters, we succeeded in maintaining and slightly increasing real levels of funding per student.

Capital funding went up by 400 per cent in real terms; research funding went up by 200 per cent in real terms. A number of studies have consistently shown that we succeeded in achieving one of the most accessible higher education systems in the world. We wanted equity. We wanted to ensure, particularly, that disadvantaged groups shared in growth in places, so equity plans were developed. Participation by the disadvantaged was encouraged. In fact, there were some important achievements in this regard. Aboriginal participation went up by 50 per cent between 1990 and 1995 alone. There were substantial gains for people from non‐English speaking backgrounds and, for women, participation in non‐traditional areas. The numbers from low socioeconomic backgrounds and from rural and isolated areas were up significantly, but unfortunately not their share of total enrolments.

When we compare ourselves in this respect, we should compare ourselves in a world where there has been increasing difficulty for people to maintain equity ratios in tertiary education. We have managed to at least achieve increased numbers when the rest of the world has gone backwards.

Our major problems with this legislation are twofold. This legislation, in a broad sense, will transform Australia's higher education system, and transform it for the worse. There are problems, for instance, in terms of the Higher Education Funding Act and the implementation of full up‐front fees for Australian undergraduates. We find a particular problem with that.

We find a particular problem with legislation which introduces a greatly increased and differential scale of HECS charges. We also find problems with legislation which reduces the income at which people with HECS debts are required to start making repayments. We also find substantial problems with legislation which deregulates the charging of fees under the open learning scheme.

In respect of some aspects of the legislation with which we agree—and there are some of those—we do support a number of routine measures which adjust various grant payments to institutions to take account of price movements. We find particularly perplexing—but we find no reason to oppose—the proposition in this legislation which raises maximum grant levels for the calendar years 1997 and 1998, contained in the Higher Education Funding Bill but, somewhat farcically, it comes at a time when the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) has announced an intention to make determinations to pay less than the maximum amounts specified in the bill.

PARA.BREAK: Other problems stem from the fact that this government was elected on a commitment to maintain triennial funding, a commitment that has also been broken by this proposed legisla tion. Under normal rolling triennial funding arrangements, we would expect this legislation to contain the funding level for the final year of the new triennium, which is calendar year 1999. This is a broken promise which will be of particular concern to the Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, there are other aspects with which we agree—the proposal to increase funding for research infrastructure, collaborative grants, and postgraduate awards. But while we support those measures, we also know that they do not go anywhere near offsetting the damaging impact of the government's cuts to university operating grants and the abolition of discretionary funds.

We also will not be opposing the introduction of the new merit scholarships. But I note here that we are talking about scholarships, the number of which will peak at 4,000 after four years in a system with some 630,000 students enrolled this year. It is minuscule.

We are concerned because this legislation represents a major dismantling of the way tertiary education has been run in this country for some time. It comes from a government which came in on the promise of not making such changes. We are seeing here the full extent of the government's surgery.

The government is proposing to make major cuts to universities, thereby reducing opportunities and the quality of the learning environment while at the same time making students pay more for the privilege. The combined impact of cuts to public funding, higher education charges, and the introduction of full fees for undergraduates, in combination, will have a profound impact, not just on the individuals involved but also on the equity of the system. Bruce Chapman, the designer of HECS, summed up the impacts in this way:

There will be an inevitable increase in the composition of enrolments towards students from rich backgrounds as the currently universal HECS arrangements are moved towards a system in which a significant minority of students are paying up‐front fees.

This government is ditching equity. Equity is not a core commitment. No matter how the minister tries to approach it, no matter how extensive her rhetoric is, she is trying to sell us a pup here. Unfortunately, she has support from her backbenchers.

The funding cuts are of major proportions. It is not good enough for the minister to call them a `nick', as she has. There are elements of the cuts which, in all, amount to a massive reduction in the funding capacity of universities. Operating grants are to be cut by $624 million over four years. Discretionary funds are to be cut by $214 million over four years. There is a failure to provide supplementation for university salary increases at a time when the previous government was to provide some $250 million per annum for that purpose.

The minister has made some vague statements about funding assistance to ensure agreements, expecting people to be able to bring forward cash flows and so on. But the reality is that we are talking about more than a nick; we are talking about an effective cut that the Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee estimates to be 10 to 12 per cent by the year 2000. Professor Gavin Brown, the Vice‐Chancellor of the University of Sydney—a mathematician by training—estimates an effective cut of 15 per cent to his university by the year 2000.

Already we are seeing the impact across the country. We are seeing reports of cuts to courses, loss of diversity, closure of campuses, staff reductions, and postgraduate works being devastated at many institutions, all as a result of this government's insistence that this area take the brunt of the cuts. This will have grave implications for professional development in many areas, including teacher education.

What is the minister's response to this? The response is one of bluster and blackmail—blackmailing universities to come in behind her proposal, otherwise she will make sure that the cuts are felt even more savagely.

PARA.BREAK: The HECS increases are in marked contrast with the way HECS was introduced under the previous government. It was introduced after analysis and detailed study of the impact of HECS on participation decisions, particularly regarding the disadvantaged. We also legislated to ensure that the Higher Education Coun cil, the government's independent advisory body, would be able to report regularly to the parliament on the impact of HECS.

SPEECH.PARA: What has preceded these measures? What analysis has preceded this government's changes to HECS? What assessment has there been? There has been absolutely none, just a decision by the minister and by the government that it would be fair enough to raise a certain amount of money from the students. As the minister said at the time, it would represent the cost of a movie ticket a week. But we are talking about hundreds of millions of dollars which will have to be paid by young people who cannot afford it.

I have a son who is going through Year 12. I have spent some time with him and his mates over recent months and I have seen them disturbed by all the debate about reduced funding levels to universities. I have seen them watch and analyse results over recent weeks. I have seen them read newspaper reports very keenly to see if the courses they want to choose are going to be there next year, whether the science courses will get the funding, whether the law courses will get the funding, and whether they will be able to go to the university of their choice. A lot of them have made substantial and radical decisions over recent weeks because of the impact of this government's cuts.

I say to the government: you could not have discussed this; you could not have done this in a worse way, particularly for the kids involved. Enough is the pressure of Year 12 without all this debate about reduced places and reduced opportunities, and a greater demand on them and their parents to pay HECS. Obviously, in my case, things are a bit different. But so many young kids are now being forced to make decisions about where they can go to study based on a fair degree of indecision and the fear that they will have to incur higher fees, higher charges, and have to pay them back in quicker time.

We are seeing this already from the enrolment data across the country. It paints a worrying picture. It is not good enough for the minister to shrug her shoulders and say that it will be okay. It will not be okay, and we can see that already. Applications are an indicator which need to be treated with a degree of caution. We are already seeing, particularly in disadvantaged areas such as western Sydney, that overall enrolment applications are down by some seven per cent. Specifically, engineering is down by 41 per cent, and science and technology are down by 14 per cent. There have been major declines in non‐school leaver applications in some states. In Victoria they are down by 12 per cent. In my state—the minister's state—South Australia, they are down by 20 per cent. If South Australia needs anything, it needs continuation of postgraduate work, particularly in the sciences area, in engineering, and in areas related to the mining industry.

But the minister does not care. The minister is taking a Marie Antoinette approach to all this. Basically she is saying: `They can like it or lump it.' That is not the way to run government or to develop policy in Australia. We have not been used to this `like it or lump it' approach over recent years, nor should we accept it. For that reason I find this government's approach most offensive.

There is a particularly worrying trend with respect to science and technology courses. It is not just the opposition saying that; Dr John Rice, President of the Australian Council of Deans of Science, has expressed grave concerns, pointing to drops of some 20 per cent in some institutions in science applications for enrolment. There is a looming crisis in the supply of maths and science schoolteachers. Studies have shown that there will be a shortfall of around 9,000 by the year 2003. This decision will just make it worse. As Senator Woodley said, it is very much the end of the clever country when you are dissecting, when you are undermining, when you are attacking in a discriminate way, as this minister has, non-graduate students and courses across the country.

We have always rejected up-front fees for undergraduates. This objection is based on the central tenet that access to various professions and career options for young people should be defined and determined by ability and motivation, not by financial means. This initiative raises some pretty massive equity considerations. Not only is it equity in terms of the individuals involved but it also raises some pretty severe national interest questions. For the minister to draw an analogy with overseas fee paying students is spurious. It is in our national interest as a country to ensure equity and participation in education. For that reason, if not for that reason alone, we should ensure that we continue to reject up-front fees for Australian undergraduates.

There are some other concerns about this proposal. The minister is not game enough or sufficiently competent to tell us how it is going to work. For a start, she is not prepared to put into legislation, into regulation, the guidelines, the provisions, the regulations that would govern this particular aspect of her initiatives. She says that she will attach strict conditions to universities providing fee paying places but she has not explained how the universities or the institutions or the sector will fill all HECS paying places first.

Who is to say that many of those HECS places that the universities would have offered in future years will be available? Who is to say that these places will be filled first before the full fee paying places are provided? How is the 25 per cent rule to be interpreted, for instance? How is it going to operate? Is it going to be applied institution wide, faculty wide or sector wide? How are we going to ensure that the most popular courses are not quarantined off for fee paying arrangements? They are complex problems but they are problems that the minister has not been able to address or to satisfy the Senate on, and they are problems that are left outstanding at the end of the day.

We also have problems in respect of the open learning changes. We introduced the open learning scheme as a way of broadening access to higher education, of taking advantage of the strengths of those universities specialising in distance education and also of taking maximum advantage of new learning media and technologies, be it TV, computer mediated learning, the Internet or whatever. This government now chooses to turn open learning into a Trojan Horse. That is obviously this government's preferred bundle of education funding—fully deregulated, fee paying, and with minimal assistance for disadvantaged students.

We required that open learning charges, for instance, be set at no more than the standard HECS fee for the same year offered by conventional means and we provided a funding mechanism, the open learning deferred payments scheme, to help students defer this expense with a HECS type loan. This government is choosing in this legislation to remove all constraints and fee charging through the measures contained in this bill. It will be severely limiting access to open learning deferred payment system loans as well.

The opposition has some pretty fundamental problems with this legislation, not the least of which was the approach taken by the government in announcing it and also in developing the policy that is reflected in this legislation. This government is fundamentally undermining one of the world's most accessible systems of higher education. It is diminishing the quality of the educational experience of Australian students. It is damaging this country's prospects of educating a technologically sophisticated and adaptable work force. Essentially what we are doing here is taking a step back down the road to when many key professions were bastions of privilege with access largely restricted to those with significant financial means.

Let us remember also that this is a government that came to these decisions without any open review, without any open policy analysis or debate. It was the minister late one night announcing to a group of stunned academics that the cuts would be as high as 11, 12, 13 per cent. That is the analysis now of the leaders of the tertiary sector. The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee estimates that the cuts embodied in this legislation, no matter what statements the minister makes, translate into a 10 to 12 per cent effective cut by the year 2000. Professor Gavin Brown says to his university that it is a 15 per cent cut by the year 2000.

We have witnessed over the last seven months what I think most commentators would agree is a pretty dismal performance by a minister who was out of her depth at the start and a minister who has taken absolutely no opportunity over recent months to try to come to grips with the policy embodied in this. She does not care that so many young Australians will be denied access to the system. She does not care, nor does her colleague Dr Kemp, about so many targeted programs being washed away by this government's deregulatory approach. She does not care about the pressures she is putting on the tertiary system, pressure which already has led to a substantial number of courses being abolished or curtailed. She does not care, unfortunately, that Australia's future and future prospects are premised on our capacity to produce more highly skilled persons from universities and other aspects of the education system.

Our future is based on the extent to which we can develop those skills and compete with those skills in a pretty fluid and open global economy. To the extent that we do not put the investment in through these programs through research and development, unfortunately this government is taking us down the road that the Menzies government took us in the 1950s—essentially, no vision for the future, a future hidden behind an isolationist policy and mentality and a future which really did not recognise Australia's capacity to interact and pick up enormous opportunities through the rest of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —With the amendments that are proposed to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988, I wonder if there has not been an oversight and whether or not section 2A of that act—
—We are not in committee yet.

—should not be amended. As Senator Bolkus said, we are not in committee, but I am giving the parliamentary secretary advance notice of something that may be raised. As you well know, section 2A sets out the objects of the act:

SPEECH.PARA: The objects of this Act are:
(a) to support a higher education system that:

PARA.TAB: (i) is characterised by quality, diversity and equity of access; and
(ii) contributes to the development of cultural and intellectual life in Australia; and
(iii) is appropriate to meet Australia's social and economic needs for a more highly educated and skilled population; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) to strengthen Australia's knowledge base and enhance the contribution of Australia's research capabilities to national economic development and international competitiveness and the attainment of social goals.

That is an exhaustive list of the objects of the act. The amendments do not purport to change that in any way. Yet, if the second reading speech is perused, it will be seen that there is a turning away in philosophy from the objects that are set out in the act. If you look at the second reading speech that was delivered with the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, it refers to 4,000 merit scholarships that are going to be created between 1997 and 2000. That is the only mention of merit that I can find in the second reading speech.

If we as a nation want to achieve the objects of the act, I would have thought that what we must do is concentrate on merit and not the ability to obtain tertiary education by means which include factors other than merit. This bill is a major shift in the approach that has been taken until now. To use the words of the act, the purpose of the act is to contribute to the cultural, intellectual, social and economic life and needs of Australia. As I say, the only way that is going to be achieved is to get the very best of the people coming through the education system and make sure that they receive the education to which they are entitled.

From now on, one in four Australian students—25 per cent—will be able to enter tertiary education institutions by means which include factors other than merit. That does present a most dramatic change in the approach that we have and is something that is not accommodated in the objects of the act. Clearly, to encompass the changes made by the amendments we are looking at now, there ought to be changes made to section 2A of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988; otherwise the objects of the act are inconsistent with the other provisions contained in the act. That is the first thing I want to say about the shift away from the philosophy of the act.

BREAK.PARA: The second thing is that it concentrates people's minds on the money they might make and the personal advantage they might obtain through education. Evidence of that comes from the second reading speech. It says:

The bill introduces differential HECS contributions from 1997. This measure strikes a better balance between public and private funding of higher education. Students will now be required to make a contribution to the cost of their education which is more closely linked to both the actual cost of the course undertaken and the likely future benefits to the individual in terms of increased life‐time earnings.

That is a factor that is not encompassed in the objects of the act. There ought to be another provision in the objects of the act which says that the purpose of this act is to enable certain people to make a lot of money and to give themselves a much more comfortable life by getting qualifications at a tertiary level. When we come to consider this in the committee stage, I will ask why that has not been included in the amending legislation.

If you want to advance Australia and if you want to see contributions made to the cultural and intellectual life of Australia to meet the social and economic needs of Australia, you need people with altruism. You need people who are skilled with tertiary education and who want to use those skills to further the good and the health of their country.

That is not the thrust of the second reading speech. In fact, I do not think that the second reading speech talks in terms of Australia's future. I do not think it talks at all in terms of the contribution that students might make to the cultural and intellectual life of Australia. It does not talk in terms of what education can do for the social and economic needs of Australia. Its whole thrust—its whole philosophy—is directed towards ensuring that some people who get into education, either through merit or through merit and wealth, can make themselves a better living, and that is a great pity.

Say somebody has studied medicine, law, engineering, or indeed anything, and would like to use those skills and that education not to make money for himself or herself but to contribute to the future of Australia. Of course, that might mean that they get a lot less in terms of remuneration than those who go ahead to gather unto themselves—and justifiably so—riches and wealth. Those who go to lesser paid jobs—this point has been made tonight—those who might want to work in a poorer area where the returns as a doctor are not as much as they might be elsewhere, and those who want to go and work in legal aid, are the people who are going to be punished for doing that because they will have to contribute just as much in HECS payments as those who go into the more remunerative sections of the various professions. It is a pity that this bill and this second reading speech send that message.
The second reading speech says:
The lowering of the minimum threshold to $20,701 means that the current discount for voluntary payment at this income level will be discontinued.
That is obvious. It continues:
The repayment required at this income level will be less than $12 per week.

That is a sentence which again sends a message, and the message is this: that the people—the department, the government—who are introducing this legislation do not know what the effects of paying $12 a week are to some people. If you are on $20,701 per year and you have responsibilities to take care of yourself and, perhaps, others, then $12 a week—that is over $600 a year—is a very significant issue. But this second reading speech states:
The repayment required at this income level will be less than $12 per week.
It makes that point as if $12 was insignificant. The next sentence confirms what I am saying:
The existing discounts of twenty five per cent for up‐front payments and fifteen per cent for voluntary payments of $500 at any time, will remain.
So it is again the person who has got not wealth but a considerable amount in the way of assets and a considerable amount in the way of income who is going to be better off under these amendments.

Another little thing in passing is this: under the amendments the concept of semester is to be taken from the act and is to be replaced by study period. For an old romantic like me this is a little tragic. Semester had that sense of obtaining not only knowledge but culture, of sitting down and discussing things like Senator Brownhill and I used to do in the old days across the passage of the old House. Senator Brownhill, that aspect will be gone and what we will have now will be study periods. It is a bit like Hansard. All the Hansard reporters can do when they are in here is take down the golden words of wisdom. They cannot exchange words and talk about how they can better improve the culture and the social wellbeing of Hansard, until they get back to their office. What you are really doing is introducing a situation where we will all be sitting down taking Hansard notes the whole time.

The concept that education should be more than, as it were, shovelling knowledge into the head has gone. Again, I keep coming back to the objectives of the act. With that has gone a higher education system which, according to the objects of the act, should be characterised by quality, diversity and equity of access, which contributes to the cultural and intellectual life of Australia and which is appropriate to meet Australia's social needs.
It is intended that the new act meet Australia's economic needs, but the economic needs are only one of the factors that are looked for in the objects of the act. Object 2A(b) of the act states:

. . . to strengthen Australia's knowledge base and enhance the contribution of Australia's research capabilities to national economic development and international competitiveness and the attainment of social goals.

When you read the second reading speech, it is very difficult to see where those objects of the act have even been turned to. Why do we not simply change the objects of the act, as I have been suggesting, and say that the idea of this act and these amendments is to enable people to enrich themselves, to get on in life and to flourish as individuals. According to the way this second reading speech seems to read, we can put aside all this nonsense about quality, diversity, equity of access and the development of cultural and intellectual life in Australia and instead put in the objects, which is exactly what these amendments are attempting to do.

It is also at times a little contradictory. One of the first paragraphs talks about the need for merit and, if you have merit, you get the scholarship. But, if you skip the next paragraph, the third paragraph says that as long as you have money—and no doubt you would have to have some merit as well; surely you are not going to be able to get into the university simply on the grounds of money—you can take the place that would otherwise have gone to 25 per cent of the people who would be applying who have more merit than you but less money. The last paragraph reads:

This measure will enable Australian students to have a greater chance of obtaining the higher education course of their first preference, freeing up government funded places they would have otherwise accepted with their second or third preference. It will also generate additional income for the universities and will provide an extra incentive for diversity among institutions.

I am not sure what is meant by `freeing up government funded places they would have otherwise accepted with their second or third preference'. I am not quite sure how that fits in with the general scheme of things or with the objects of the act. Perhaps that can be explained when we get to the committee stage.

It also talks about generating additional income for the universities and providing an extra incentive for diversity amongst institutions. That seems to be a message to the universities that they have to get out there and make the money they need to exist by charging fees to at least one in four of their students. It would be more than that because they would hope to get students from overseas.

They are the thoughts that I have on this legislation. I think they are thoughts that have been well argued during the evening. It is a pity, as has been said, that there has been this major shift in the philosophy that should guide our education sector, particularly the tertiary education sector. I could venture the thought that this is not going to lead to the great and clever country that could have been achieved to the extent had we persisted with the old scheme.

PARA.BREAK: It is an unfortunate piece of legislation. Perhaps the Minister for Employment, Educa tion, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) could tell us in her concluding speech before the committee stage, if not in the committee stage, how those objects set out in 2A are going to be enhanced by the latest piece of legislation in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to now enter this debate on higher education funding and acknowledge some of the things that have been said by the previous speaker, Senator Cooney. I agree with him to a great extent that, unfortunately, in the area of university education, the question of excellence and quality and the pursuit of truth and knowledge very often come second place to the pursuit of money.

SPEECH.PARA: In that context, I would like to remind the Senate that it was almost 150 years ago that William Charles Wentworth persuaded the Legislative Council of New South Wales in 1850 to provide a perpetual endowment to fund the University of Sydney. The motto of that university, as Senator Cooney no doubt knows, is: `Sidere mens eadem mutato'—that is, `the same spirit under a new sky'. Professor F.A. Todd translated it, I think, from memory as: `Heart to heart, though poles apart'.

That reflects the long traditions of university education which span the centuries since universities such as Bologna, Oxford and Cambridge were founded in the Middle Ages. Much has been said about the history of the establishment of university education in this country, but I invite senators to read the report from the Illustrated London News of 29 January 1853 on the actual establishment of the University of Sydney. I seek leave to incorporate a portion of that report in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The report read as follows—
THE INAUGURATION OF THE UNIVERSITY OF SYDNEY

PARA.EMPHASIS: The following account and the engraving reproduced in the frontispiece are taken with kind permission from `The Illustrated London News' of January 29, 1853. The account was based on a full report in `The Sydney Morning Herald' of October 12, 1852.

SPEECH.PARA: The opening of an University in the capital of New South Wales is an event greatly significant of the progress of the social and intellectual growth of the colony. Accordingly, the ceremony, which took place on the 11th of October last, in the Great Hall, College-buildings, Hyde-park, was attended by a very numerous audience. Soon after eleven o'clock the doors at the western entrance were opened, and every part of the hall appropriated to the general company was densely crowded before half-past twelve, when the doors were closed, and the ceremony of registering the names of the matriculated students was gone through. Professor Smith presented each of the young gentlemen to the Registrar, by whom their names were entered in the matriculation book, the first name upon the list being Fitzwilliam Wentworth. The matriculation entries having been made, the procession of those who were to take part in the official proceedings of the day was formed in the apartments of the principal, and entered the hall, the band of Her Majesty's 11th Regiment playing the National Anthem.

The Vice-Provost, Sir Charles Nicholson, conducted his Excellency the Governor-General to the state-chair placed for him in the centre of the dais, at the north end of the hall; and the scene at this moment was of the most animated character. On either side of his Excellency were seated the Fellows of the Senate. Before them again sat clergymen of all denominations, amongst whom we observed the Rev. Messrs. Allwood, Grylls, Walsh, Walker, Turner, Priddle, Stephen, Smith, Dr. Steele, etc. On the left was a numerous body of military and naval officers of the garrison and port. Near them were the French and other foreign Consuls, their glittering uniforms contrasting with the black gowns of the Solicitor-General and other leading members of the Bar, and of the young Alumni, who occupied the front seats. The Vice-Provost occupied a state chair on the right, a little in advance of his Excellency, and was supported by Professors Pell and Smith. On the extreme right of the reserved space was the Principal's chair, on the left, the Registrar's. A large portion of the area was reserved for the ladies. Over the Governor‐General's chair was a shield bearing the Royal arms of England, and on his right and left two others with the arms of the Universities of Oxford and Cambridge. Over Dr. Woolley's chair was a shield bearing the arms of his own college, University College, Oxford. Immediately opposite, over the Registrar's chair, was the pure white shield of Sydney University; no arms yet emblazoned thereupon, but bearing the motto, "I will achieve".

Sir Charles Nicholson then rose and delivered an eloquent address, wherein he characterized the University as an institution founded for the promotion of all the higher branches of learning—an institution whose comprehensive design and ample endowment must enlist in its favour the sympathies of every generous mind, and afford a promise that the advantages which it holds forth may continue to be dispensed to the future generations of this colony, to the remotest period. In the year 1850 (continued Sir Charles) the Legislative Council passed an act to incorporate and endow the University of Sydney. The preamble to the Bill declares it expedient for the better advancement of religion and morality, and the promotion of useful knowledge, to hold forth to all classes and denominations of her Majesty's subjects resident in the colony of New South Wales, without any distinction whatever, an encouragement for pursuing a regular and liberal course of education. To carry out these intentions, provision is made for the appointment of a Senate, consisting of sixteen fellows, to whom are confided the granting of degrees, honours, and rewards of merit, and the general conduct and management of the institution. If any further argument were required illustrative of the necessity of such a foundation as our University, it is afforded in the partial, if not entire, failure of every attempt hitherto made for the establishment of collegiate institutions throughout the Australian colonies.

The learned Provost then glanced at the cause of this failure, which he referred partly to the limitation of some particular religious communion: where the University of Sydney had been placed upon a more comprehensive foundation. The second feature to which Sir Charles adverted to as characteristic of Sydney University is the high privilege accorded to it by the Local Legislature, ratified and confirmed by a most marked expression of the Royal will, of granting degrees in the several faculties of arts, law and medicine. A third auspicious attribute is the comprehensive design and character. Limited to no sect and confined to no class, its sphere of action is calculated to embrace men of every creed and of all ranks. Dispensing more secular instruction, and leaving the inculcation of religious truth to the spiritual guardians of each denomination of religionists, the University presents the widest possible area for all who are willing to come within her precincts.

Sir Charles then referred to the liberal provision made for the endowment of eighteen scholarships to the annual value of 50 each, tenable for three years; these being open to the competition of the youth of the whole colony. Sir Charles then explained the steps taken for securing able and accomplished teachers, recommended by a committee of gentlemen in England, consisting of Sir John Herschel, Bart.; Professor Airy, Astronomer Royal; Professor Maiden, of University College, London; and Henry Denison, Esq., formerly Fellow of All Souls, Oxford. Simultaneously with the means adopted for the selection and appointment of the professors, steps were taken for obtaining books and apparatus from England, for the foundation of a library, and for the necessary illustration of the lectures in physical science. The philosophical apparatus, selected by professor Smith, had already reached the colony; and our first consignment of books, of the value of 500, was daily expected. In conclusion, Sir Charles addressed himself to those for whose special benefit the University had been established.
Loud applause followed, and Sir Charles having resumed his seat, the Alumni were introduced by Professor Smith to the Vice‐Provost and Senate, and took the prescribed oath.
The Principal, the Rev. John Woolley, D.C.L., then delivered the inauguaration address . . . The number of matriculated students was twenty‐three.1

1The names of the matriculants were the following: Fitzwilliam Wentworth, George Leary, Joseph Leary, James William Johnson, Charles Allen, Alexander Raby Riley, William Charles Windeyer, James Affriate Wilson, William A. Abbott Hirst, William B. Forshall, William Andrew Moore, John Kinlock, William Cyprian Curtis, Robert Sealy, Robert Marsden Fitzgerald, Alexander Oliver, Rodney Riddell, Marshall Burdekin, Robert Speir Willis, Edward Lee, David Scott Mitchell, Henry Wyatt Radford, Thomas B. Clarke, Thomas Henry Coulson.—Editors.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do so because it shows the spirit of enlightened liberality which motivated the young colony to embark on such an undertaking. And I do so particularly as I think it would interest the whole of the Senate especially particularly, I would expect, the minister. It is most enlightening to see what was in fact said in the speech by Sir Charles Nicholson who indicated that:

SPEECH.PARA: In the year 1850 the Legislative Council passed an act to incorporate and endow the University of Sydney.

The preamble to the Bill declares it expedient for the better advancement of religion and morality, and the promotion of useful knowledge, to hold forth to all classes and denominations of her Majesty's subjects resident in the colony of New South Wales, without any distinction whatever, an encouragement for pursuing a regular and liberal course of education.

I have had that incorporated in Hansard for it shows the enlightenment which motivated that young colony. We value universities because we value knowledge. Knowledge of course without love is fruitless. We expect universities to be committed to the pursuit of truth.

BREAK.PARA: In considering this legislation I have been deeply concerned that university funding should not be prejudiced and particularly in a serious manner. The government has made it very clear that if it does not achieve the revenue sought to be achieved by changes to the higher education contribution scheme, it will be obliged to consider the level of university funding in next year's budget.

I am concerned about the increases in HECS. In response to a number of concerns similarly expressed around the chamber and outside the chamber, the minister has indicated that if the government's objective is not achieved as described in this bill, it will mean cuts will be required in funding to universities and especially significant cuts in operational subsidies. In that event, the smaller universities—including the university in my state, the University of Tasmania, which needs to cater for students from all over the state and needs campuses in three and four parts of the state—will be affected considerably more than the mainland universities; not least of course because it does not enjoy economies of scale.

Unfortunately, the government seems to be lacking the liberal spirit of Sir Robert Menzies who did so much for universities with funding increases and Commonwealth scholarships in the post‐war period. Senators, colleagues, you will be interested to read Sir Robert Menzies' account of his efforts for universities in The Measure of the Years. You will read in there his reasons for promoting Commonwealth scholarships. I refer to chapter 9. I do so because I am sure the government will be most interested in this and I expect other honourable senators will be as well. But Sir Robert Menzies, in chapter 9 page 84 of The Measure of the Years says this, and you can almost hear him saying it:

One of the significant things about this long period of office, one that I recall with great pride and satisfaction, is the dramatic development of the universities and of some aspects of secondary education. Since my own student days at Melbourne, I had maintained my interest in university education. As time went on, particularly after I entered politics, I saw its growing community importance and occasionally chided many of my business and banking friends for not giving it greater encouragement and recognition.
I want to finish with this quote:

Before the Second World War, a university training had been regarded as a kind of privilege to be enjoyed by students of unusual talent or of well‐to‐do or self‐sacrificing parents, or of both. Scholarships were very scarce, and hotly contested.

I turn to the present piece of legislation because I notice that half my time has gone. Given the current fiscal constraints that the government has indicated, what we might be able to achieve and particularly what we would hope to have achieved in this Senate may be very limited.

The role of the Senate is set out in the constitution. The Senate is not—nor in particular am I—the government. We do have a responsibility, however, to ensure thorough review of legislation. The government is entitled to make the initial policy decisions and carry them through against the framework and the broad background of what it was elected to do. In general, elected governments should have to live with the consequences of their decisions. My concern, as I expressed before, is about what might occur in the operational subsidies and other funding for universities, particularly those in the regions. I am also concerned about a further burden being placed on the shoulders of battlers whose children do not go to universities.

I have a number of concerns, apart from the increase in HECS: the lowering of the thresholds for payments of HECS that affects graduates supporting families; the introduction of differential higher education charges for different courses; and the failure of the tax system to recognise properly the cost of investing in education.

On the first matter of concern, I can understand the government's wish not to leave HECS liabilities outstanding. Some HECS debts will never be repaid—whether by reason of death, emigration or failure of graduates to earn income. To require graduates to start paying HECS debts earlier, in some cases may turn out not to be such a bad thing if they are repaying debts while single, without dependants and with the capacity to repay.

However, there are graduates whose incomes are not high and who are supporting families. Lowering the repayment threshold to $20,700 may—I say `may'—be reasonable for single graduates without dependants. It is not so if that graduate has a dependent spouse and children. That is a point that I believe the government should accept. I think the bill should be amended so that the repayment threshold takes account of family circumstances, and I will be moving accordingly.

My second concern, apart from the level of the HECS increases, is the differential rates proposed. Already concerns are emerging that different charges for different courses are not justified. For example, law courses are not more expensive to provide than most courses and the level of cost recovery seems excessive. The need to charge differential fees for each subject raises all sorts of odd questions. I do not intend—and unfortunately I do not have time—to go into those at this point. I will be referring to them in the committee stage.

One thing which certainly concerns many people is that the differential charges are being based on supposed future income prospects. Is it logical to charge a person on the basis not of what it costs to provide something, not of what that person's income is, but merely on statistical expectations of what the person's future income may turn out to be? If we are talking about private sector practices, we might note that sellers of goods and services normally charge all customers the same price and do not base their charges on the incomes of their customers.

We do not charge doctors, lawyers, engineers or teachers more to use the roads or take the train. Where we do get a larger contribution out of higher income earners is through the graduated income tax scales. Those scales, unlike the differentiated HECS charges, are based on actual incomes people earn, not putative or expected incomes. To make graduates pay both higher fees and higher taxes through higher marginal income tax rates might seem by many to be a Treasury double‐dipping.

In talking about taxes, we should also examine the argument that students are being subsidised by taxpayers. What does that mean? Who pays the taxes? Is Treasury forgetting that students and their families are taxpayers? Bureau of Statistics figures on fiscal incidence have shown that, on average, families with children are net taxpayers, not net beneficiaries from the tax transfer system, even ignoring the future taxes the children will pay. If students and their families are being told how much money it is costing the Treasury to provide university education, it at least ought to be acknowledged how much they are paying the Treasury in direct and indirect taxes both now and in the future.

I want to point out another inconsistency in Treasury—and, no doubt, Finance—arguments on higher education. If the argument is made that higher education is relevant to gaining incomes, then we should be honest about it and repeal sections 51(6) and 82A of the Income Tax Assessment Act. These sections exclude in a quite unfair and discriminatory manner the deductions that would otherwise be available to many students in respect of HECS.

I might also point out that it was the McMahon Liberal government which introduced deductibility in 1972 for the first $400 of self‐education expenses to avoid the many legal debates about when and whether an education expense was income related. Given where the debate is now on education and training in relation to income generation, I think we should pick up that precedent and liberalise it.

Treasury and Finance cannot have it both ways. If they are going to argue that charges or fees for university students are justified because they are related to income, then they must accept the logical result that these fees and charges should be tax deductible. I hope that honourable senators give this some consideration.

In many areas we are seeing moves by government to privatise their spending or income support functions whether it be in income support for migrants, for child care, for students or for health and education funding. I understand the fiscal reasons advanced by the government—not just by this government but by a previous government—in wishing to devolve these functions. However, changes must be fairly implemented. To the extent that taxpayers are being expected to take over government expenditure, it is only fair that the tax system should recognise through deductions the amount of income that taxpayers are being made to spend on these formerly government funded functions.

The whole area of the tax treatment of education needs review. In the United States there is a much more generous attitude to education expenses and charitable gifts or trusts for education. Yet we penalise private funding of education. There is the explicit denial of deductibility of self‐education expenses that I have just referred to.

I also remind the Senate that the Industry Commission recommended abolition of capital gains tax on gifts of property to tax exempt charities such as universities. If we wish to encourage greater graduate support for universities, we need to reverse these sorts of tax disincentives. Wasn't that what Sir Robert Menzies suggested?

I might point out that I am not alone in raising questions about some of the logical economic implications of charging more for tertiary education. Mr Stephen Koukoulas, an economist with Citibank Australia, observed in the bank's Money Market Week newsletter of 22 November 1996:
While the decision was great for the short‐term bottom line of the Budget, over the longer run, it means that there will be a reduction in the skill level of the work force.

In conclusion, I recognise that, yes, the government is the government and that the Senate has a role: one of audit, control and review. That role we must discharge in accordance with our constitutional duties.

I do not want to see the universities run down. I have taken note of what the minister has said publicly about that and that, in effect, action will be required in the next budget to make up the difference if we defeat this legislation regarding increases to HECS and repayment arrangements. As I understand it, and as the minister has said, a serious action will be required in respect of operational subsidies. However, I do think there are a number of reasonable amendments that the Senate might consider in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all senators for the contribution they have made to the second reading debate of this very important package of bills: the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 and the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. I would like to take a minute to basically put the government's position in a very short, summary form.

SPEECH.PARA: Yes, the package seeks Senate approval to ask future students—not existing students—to make a higher HECS contribution, and it is a significantly higher HECS contribution. No-one has ever made any bones about that. Yes, the package seeks to change the HECS contribution from being a flat one for all students to a differentiated HECS which reflects the different cost of the courses and also bears in mind the differing expected income potential from each of these courses. This is a recognition by the government that there is a very public benefit in higher education institutions; we all benefit from that.

There is also a private benefit received by each person who has the opportunity to participate in higher education, and that private benefit is acknowledged by the HECS contribution, introduced by Labor and supported by us at the time—if it was not supported by us, it should have been. The HECS contribution has one very essential characteristic that we would seek to retain: it is not pay as you learn; it is pay as you earn. Labor satisfactorily removed from the higher education system the need for you to have money to get there in the first place. If you had the merit, you could get in and you did not have to pay back until you were earning. By far, that is one of the better policy contributions from Labor in the last 13 years of its government and we seek to retain that.

PARA.BREAK: But we make no bones about the fact that we say graduates are very substantial private beneficiaries of higher education. They inevitably have higher incomes—yes, there are always exceptions to this, but on average they have higher incomes—they have much more sustainable employment, they have better status in the community and they have roughly half the unemployment rate of people who do not have that opportunity. The unemploy ment rate of people with an undergraduate degree is around four per cent. It is closer to 8.6 per cent or 8.7 per cent for all other Australians. We make no bones about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite particularly, this package has very small cuts to higher education institutions themselves—a one per cent cut next year against forward estimates. They were, by and large, growth forward estimates—in total, they certainly were and for many others they were. I am sure you, Mr Deputy President, understand the differences around Australia in higher education institutions in that institutions in your state and in Western Australia were to be the beneficiaries of very significant growth—places they should have been provided with in the past but were not. I congratulate the previous government on redressing that imbalance. It is a balance we would like to retain. The only difference is that we have returned to Victoria some places that we thought were inappropriately taken from it.

The first element of this package is the recognition that students gain a very substantial benefit from higher education. We are asking them to pay a higher contribution while maintaining the essential element of HECS—that is, you do not pay until you earn. Secondly, there will be very small cuts in operating grants to institutions—one per cent against growth estimates next year. That means that universities will get more money—not much more, but it is still more—next year than this year. They will receive three per cent the year after and one per cent the year after that.

Coupled with that, there will be an opportunity for universities to earn higher income—that is, to broaden the funding base for the universities and make them more secure. It will put them in a position where, when we have a government that has not run things properly for the previous 13 years and a savings target is being sought, the savings do not have to come straight out of operating grants. This will give universities a more secure base by giving them more funding through the HECS contributions.

I am sure students do not welcome this measure, but I have never met anybody who welcomes paying more for anything. This is of no surprise to me. Nonetheless, this will give universities a broader funding base. Yes, it is true that there will be a greater contribution in HECS.

This measure will also allow them to sell places to Australian students once they have filled their government funded places. I have indicated in the past that a limitation will be put on universities that they have to fill their government funded places first. Contrary to the protestations of non‐government senators there will be an increase in funded undergraduate places next year. There will be an increase in government funded undergraduate places the year after and the year after that.

Any pretence about this issue should now be stopped since we are at the serious part of the debate where it really counts. It is not the polemic that one runs out to a lobby with. We are debating the detail of what we are going to do or not do. There will be more government funded undergraduate places next year, the year after and the year after that. We have never made any bones about the fact that we have said to universities, `We do not expect you to teach the same number of people for less dollars, but we do expect you to find savings—that is, to reduce load—in postgraduate course work which the previous government introduced the opportunity to charge fees for years ago.'

There should be no misconception that this government is offering fewer opportunities for young Australians to get into higher education. The opposite is the case. There are more government funded places at the undergraduate level being offered by this government than were to be offered by the previous government in each of the following three years.

Universities will have to fill those places by course. I did hear one of the senators on the other side say that they did not know how that was going to work. That question has been answered in this place on a number of occasions. Universities will have to fill their government funded places by course before they can sell places to domestic students. We have also indicated that we will put a 25 per cent cap on that so that under no circumstances could a university seek to fill the more expensive courses with fee paying students at the expense of government funded students. In any course, fee paying students would not be able to form more than 25 per cent of the majority. We think they are appropriate protections.

I had in mind, as has been mentioned in the debate, that the appropriate way to introduce that protection was through guidelines. It is clear to me that a number of senators are not happy with that and there is some suspicion about the government's intention in that respect. To that end, I have asked for an amendment to be circulated. I have indicated in the past that we are quite happy to put the limitation of 25 per cent and the filling of government funded places first into legislation. If the Senate is of the mind to accept that amendment we would be very happy. I do not mind if the Senate is not because I know what we believe in and I am happy to do it by regulation. I clearly understand that other senators are concerned about this and I would be happy to change it for that reason.

That does give universities a significant income earning capacity which we would hope they would use for developing better infrastructure and for teaching. They do have a legitimate salary claim that needs to be addressed. Without the flexibility to earn extra income, they will not be able to do that unless they get more money from the government on any occasion they require higher salaries to be paid. The cost of some of those salary claims can be met by productivity gains. I am quite satisfied about that. I am yet to speak to anyone who thinks there are no productivity gains to be made in universities. Equally, a higher income earning capacity will add to the capacity of universities to meet those claims which are justified to a certain extent. The extent to which they are justified might vary from institution to institution.

PARA.BREAK: Equally, this government is prepared to return to universities the HECS contribution from over load students. The previous government simply said, `You have taken students over load. That is bad luck. Thanks very much. We will keep the HECS contribution.' We think that is inappropriate and we are happy to return that contribution to universi ties who take students over load. Some will be happy to do that and some will not. Where there is the capacity to take extra students without adding substantial costs, the return of that HECS contribution is again another source of revenue available to universities.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe we are clarifying the capacity of universities to make ancillary charges. We do not want to change that in substance. They must not be able to charge for things that one is required to do to complete a degree. There has been some messiness surrounding ancillary charges and we think they should have that flexibility. Let me put it another way. Students should be able to pay for extra things they want. We are happy to provide that opportunity.

We are looking at a very substantial ask from students. We recognise that they are by far the luckier ones leaving school. Much more is given to university students than is given to students at TAFE. Much more is given to university students than is given to those people who are asked to simply go and get a job and those who are looking for jobs. It is not only in terms of cash benefits but what in the end, for the rest of their lives, these students get.

I will mention briefly the total load arrangements as they have been advised to me by the department. The total load reductions are in fact a plus next year across Australia of just over two and a half thousand—2,675 places—with, yes, a reduction in total load of just over 4,000 in 1998 and just over 4,000 in 1999. That is nothing like the 17,000 and the 30,000 and any number of other figures that I have heard loosely bandied about by those seeking to get a headline.

As to the undergraduate load places, the places that are very important to this government, because we do believe there should be an increase in access to higher education—your first foot in the door—I am advised by my department that between 1996 and 1997 there will be an increase of just over 6,000 places next year. Cumulatively that increases to 10,000 in 1998 and in 13,000 in 1999.

I turn to some of the specific contributions made in this debate. I noticed my old colleague Senator Crowley saying, `There is no increase in choice here. What is the increase in choice if you pay for something that in the past you did not have to pay for?' She is referring to the opportunity for Australian students to buy places. What she is forgetting to say is that all those who have to pay now will not have to pay in any up-front sense. In fact, there will be more opportunities for government funded places. These are additional opportunities.

Senator Crowley refuses to recognise that there will be students who get a government funded place, who do not get it at the university of their choice or in the course of their choice and, as a consequence, will be happy to pay extra to get the university or the course of their choice. They will move out of a government funded place to get that. What will that leave? It will leave an unfilled government funded place. If that particular university wants to sell places in that course, it will have to fill that government funded place. What will that mean? It will mean an additional spot for someone who otherwise would not have got a spot.

It was with some dismay that I heard Senator Crowley, who has had a longstanding interest in education, refer to the rich and thick as being the people who will get in. That is failing to recognise two things. Firstly, there will be people who have got into government funded places who will give them up, and other students will take those places. Secondly, TER scores have got very little to do with the intellectual skill required to complete a course; they have got everything to do with the number of places available and the number of people who want them. The number of people who want them is largely to do with the degree of income one can earn if one completes a particular course.

With a very small reduction in the TER score for law, for example, you could easily fill a further 25 per cent of places with people who got not much less in their TER score, who are clearly intellectually capable of completing the course. The opposition would have us refuse this opportunity. They would have us say, `If you want to invest in yourself, if you want to take that chance, if you are prepared to put your money at risk: bad luck, we don't want it.'

From so many people opposite, I have heard the chant in the past, `Make the rich pay.' Now we want to let them pay, it seems that some people opposite are unwilling to do that. They are unwilling to let universities take money from people who are prepared to pay, to give themselves that extra chance, that extra choice. These are kids that, for some reason or another, did not do what they should have done in year 12, and did not get the appropriate TER scores. These are kids who are happy to take the chance that, perhaps with a bit more discipline and application, they could pass, and you will not let them. You want to put the be all and end all of whether you get through that gate on year 12, and you will shut others out. In doing so you will deprive universities of that income earning capacity.

You will allow universities to sell places to overseas students. You presumably recognise the enormous value to universities, both the enrichment of the undergraduate experience in having a range of cultures on the campus and in the funding that is provided to universities, but you will not allow that opportunity to Australian students. As far as you are concerned, because government funding is limited, students can be limited and there can be no other way to fund it. You will not hear of any more people getting in than the government can afford to pay. I think it is very narrow minded, with respect.

Senator Bolkus queries any previous analysis of our changes vis-a-vis HECS. I simply refer him to the Wran committee's report, clearly outlining the better equity of having a differentiated HECS, of not charging a teacher the same as you charge a doctor on a per annum basis. That should be indication enough to Senator Bolkus that these matters have been considered in the past.

There are a few other points I would like to refer to. Senator Woodley, Senator Bolkus and others say, `This is the end of the clever country.' That is the most smug and self‐ satisfied remark that I have heard from people involved in the higher education sector. It is as though, because one was born with greater intellectual skills, the future of the nation rests on one's shoulders and no-one else's, that somehow a clever country is associated purely with the wealth of the higher education sector, and forget everybody else. It is the most selfish and self‐indulgent claim to come from the sector, and I have heard quite a few. Without a doubt that takes the cake.

A really clever country, a truly clever country, seeks to bring out the best in all its citizens—not just the brightest. It will focus on the fact that even the lowest cost degree involves something like a $20,000 contribution, which we do not give to someone who leaves year 12 and goes straight into the work force, and which we certainly do not give to someone who goes into TAFE. That contribution towards degrees goes from $20,000 up to something like $200,000. Plenty of students want to talk about equity between students, but not between TAFE and people who do not even get that opportunity. Some in the higher education sector—not most, I might add, just some—would like the notion of a clever country to rest purely on the government funding of a higher education sector, not on what happens to TAFE students or apprentices who have to pay for their tools; they are other people. In these instances, `We the few are the ones on whom the responsibility for a clever country rests.' Clearly, this government has a different view.

Yes, we want universities to prosper—that is why we want to give them greater income earning opportunities; that is why we want to allow Australian students to buy places—and to increase the competition between universities. But we also recognise the enormous private benefit that goes to students through participating in a university education. We think it is reasonable to ask them to pay more on Labor's HECS system; that is, do not pay until you earn.

Let me refer briefly to the proposed reduction of the HECS repayment point from just over $28,000 to just over $20,000. Many of you will have heard of Mr Potter, a man whom I met during the campaign, whose income is about $25,000. He has a wife and two children. The children are at school. The wife chooses to stay at home. He gets a very substantial proportion of that income from a punctuality bonus by virtue of being on time—or no more than two minutes late—for work every day. We did not give him a higher education at all.

What you are saying, if you are telling me that students cannot pay back until they earn $28,000 plus, is that they should not pay back until they are earning more than the Mr Potters of the world and that it is too much for students to pay any contribution back until they are earning more than 60 per cent of income earners in Australia. I personally feel that is a peculiarly selfish view.

I have had some discussions with Senator Harradine. He has raised with me the notion of an amendment he wants to move that might provide appropriate protection for students with families. I make no bones about that being an option that is available, and one the government would seek to support if it is appropriate. I am particularly thinking of sole parents—I previously referred to them as deserted wives—who want to go back and upgrade their skills and for whom that might be difficult. But let us not pretend they are in the same category as a student who is still living at home and earning $21,000 with hardly much in the way of other expenses, and that that student cannot afford to pay back.

We would be happy to have a look at what Senator Harradine has to propose by way of amendment. It is probably better to deal with some of the other points that have been made as we go through the bills in the committee stage. I conclude by thanking senators for their contribution.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: At the end of the motion, add: ", but the Senate notes that this legislation seeks to undermine the principles of equitable, merit‐based access for all Australians to higher education by deregulating undergraduate degrees, increasing the HECS burden, restricting access to Open Learning and reducing funding to university operating grants".

This amendment, quite rightly, condemns the government for the measures contained in the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill, particularly attempts by this government to end, as we know it, a system of publicly funded and accessible higher education in this country. I say that because the measures contained in that bill introduce a system of differential HECS which will see overall HECS increases and a fundamental and drastic decrease in the threshold at which graduates begin to repay their debts, and which will also allow institutions to charge up‐front and full cost fees for certain courses.

The impact of these measures, as I outlined in my speech on the second reading—comments endorsed by my colleague Senator Woodley and others in this chamber—is to lock poor kids out of higher education. Contrary to the comments the minister made in her wrap‐up of the second reading debate, I have heard nothing which proves that the measures in this bill will not serve as financial or psychological disincentives to enter into and pursue higher education in this country. I speak specifically of traditionally disadvantaged groups.

We find the measures contained in the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill regressive. They will take us back 20 years at least in higher education policy in this country. The extent and pace of the changes are unprecedented. They are extraordinary changes, especially when contrasted with the pre‐Whitlam period. I might add that the fees and charges in this bill are higher than in the pre‐Whitlam period.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Stott Despoja, if I could just interrupt you for a moment, we have already had the second reading debate cognately with debate on the other bill. In moving your amendment, just explain the content of your amendment at this point because the second reading debate has been had. Then we will move to address the question of your amendment.

—Given that this bill makes mention of most of those measures and condemns the government accordingly, I thought I was sticking to the content of, the purpose of and the motive behind my second reading amendment. I will not repeat my second reading remarks because I think most people have heard them and are aware of my views on this matter.
—I rise also to indicate support. I presume this is the time we debate the second reading amendment, Mr Acting Deputy President?

—On a point of order: I queried whether we should have proceeded with the amendment at the earlier stage. We were told to come back at this stage. I think that is what has happened now. —My advice, Senator Bolkus, if I interpret it correctly, is that the second reading debate was had, that that was agreed to and that Senator Stott Despoja foreshadowed the amendment. I hope I am explaining this correctly. So the amendment has been moved and the question should now be put.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

(2) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 9), after item 2, insert:

PARA.TAB: (3) Guidelines issued under subsection (1) must ensure that, on an equivalent full‐time student unit basis, the number of domestic students who may be charged fees for a particular undergraduate course does not exceed 25% of the total number of places available for domestic students in that course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question of the minister. My understanding of the amendments circulated by her was that amendment 1 was to `insert new 2A' and that that new 2A is to refer to guidelines issued under subsection 1. SPEECH.PARA: I ask the minister if that is, in essence, what she is doing by these amendments, or is she doing what she indicated she was doing, by bringing in the full charging regime?
