If it is just machinery to issue guidelines for the proportion of fee paying, as opposed to non‐fee paying, undergraduate students, then we would have a lot of questions to ask before we finally agreed to that particular amendment. I do not know if the minister can help us at this stage or whether she needs time out again to get some clear instructions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, I have a list of things I would like to do. First off, if I may, I would like to table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government requests and amendments to be moved to this bill. For the information of honourable senators, this memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 2 December 1996.
—That's today.
—Yes, it was circulated today.
—We haven't got it.
—Some of us have it but I suspect some of us don't.

—Copies are coming for those who do not have it. Request No. 1 proposes to amend item 20 of schedule 1 of the principal bill. The item currently sets a statutory component of the basic charge at $326 for 1997. The proposed amendment to the principal bill sets the statutory amount at the new rate of $332.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. This is becoming difficult enough as it is for us on this side. Just a few seconds ago the minister moved particular amendments. Now she is telling us that amendment No. 1 is another amendment No. 1 which has been circulated on another sheet.
—It is request No. 1, I am sorry.
—Are you moving on the requests or are you moving on the amendments?
—I think it might be best at this stage if we consider government amendments Nos 1 and 2.
—What about 3?
—On the working list it does not come in at the start; it comes in later down the track. My understanding is that it is different from government amendments Nos 1 and 2.

—There is a running sheet which has been circulated. If we follow the running sheet, I do not think we will have any problem. Item 1 on the running sheet suggests that we look at government amendments Nos 1 and 2, and government amendments Nos 1 and 2 have been circulated.
—I am sorry for that intervention of a request, after amendments Nos 1 and 2. We will come back to the request later. Amendment No 1 states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 2, page 2 (line 3), after "2,", insert "2A,".
Amendment No. 2 states:
(2) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 9), after item 2, insert:

Senators will be able to read paragraphs (3) and (4), with the latter consisting of parts (a) and (b). This is the amendment that I referred to in summing up, indicating that the government has a clear intention that it does want to ensure that the number of fee paying domestic places will not exceed 25 per cent of the domestic student load and that universities would have to fill all their government funded places first.

I indicated that that was going to be done by guidelines. Senators opposite were less than charitable about that, suggesting there was a wicked plan—that somehow, in a very short space of time, I was suddenly going to say, `Ho, ho, ho, with the approval to do this, I will change the guidelines,' and, the guidelines not being disallowable, I would yet again be painted as the wicked witch. Not just to avoid that, but as an indication simply of the government's good faith in this matter, I said at the time that if someone wanted to move an amendment to put it into the legislation, I would be happy. I did not see it being forthcoming. We are happy to move the amendment. It is just an indication of the government's bona fides that we want to limit the number of fee paying domestic places to 25 per cent of the total load. That is contained in paragraph (3). Secondly, in paragraph (4), you see the limitations. Paragraph (3) says:

PARA.TAB: (3) Guidelines issued under subsection (1) must ensure that, on an equivalent full‐time student unit basis, the number of domestic students who may be charged fees for a particular undergraduate course does not exceed 25% of the total number of places available for domestic students . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph (4) says:

TAB.TAB: (a) require an institution not to charge a domestic student any fees for any undergraduate course in a year unless the institution meets the undergraduate target that applies for the purpose of calculating grants to the institution under section 15 or 16 for that year; and
(b) specify the amount that is applicable for the purposes of section 108 in respect of a breach of the requirement referred to in paragraph (a) of this subsection.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, it is clearly spelt out that you have to fill your places, the guidelines have to say what the penalty is going to be and the guidelines cannot allow the sale of more than 25 per cent. That is what we are seeking to put in legislation, what we have told you we want to do by regulation. People were unhappy with that. They wanted it in regulation, so that is what we are seeking to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, will those guidelines be disallowable?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the guidelines are not disallowable. I think that is the reason Senator Carr and Senator Stott Despoja were most unhappy with the 25 per cent limit being put in those guidelines. With the guidelines not being disallowable, it is not possible for the Senate to say, `You've changed your mind later and changed the percentage.' So, if the limit is put in legislation, the guidelines must comply with that limit.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the very purpose of the fuss that was created by my saying that we would simply follow the previous government's—your government's—experience in setting fees for postgraduate courses. We would do it by virtue of the same sorts of guidelines, that would be the clean and neat legislative way to do it, but people on the opposite side were unhappy about that. Why? It was because the guidelines are not disallowable.

So we are seeking now to legislate to give parliament the opportunity that it would otherwise have if the guidelines were disallowable to set the limit and to say, `You've said it's 25 per cent. If we put this in legislation, you won't be able to go higher than that unless you come back and get approval of the parliament.' I think that is perfectly appropriate. I am not unhappy with doing that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason I asked that question was that you came in here and rejected that self-claimed mantle of the wicked witch by saying that parliament would have control over how this 25 per cent applies. I put it to you, Minister, that the amendment is so general there are many questions left unanswered. There are questions that will have to be decided upon in the guidelines that you issued that basically parliament may have a limited degree of authority in terms of those guide lines by this particular amendment, but so much of what you are going to do, so much of the implementation of the mechanisms, which we would normally expect on something as crucial as this to be in regulations, in disallowable instruments, is not going to be in disallowable instruments.

SPEECH.PARA: We will go some extent down the road in terms of this amendment. But, for instance, in developing this amendment, what consultation has there been with the tertiary education sector in terms of how your clause 2A will operate in practice? Has clause 2A been circulated? Has there been any feedback from the tertiary sector on it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —That has not been done, and I do not believe it is necessary for it to be done because what we are seeking to put in legislation is perfectly clear: the 25 per cent limit. If you have a suggestion that somehow clause 2A subparagraph 3 does not provide that 25 per cent limit, we are happy to look at an amendment you might want to make to the amendment in order to put it in legislation. Equally, I say the same with respect to subparagraph 4.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons we set this limit was, I believe, that without such a limit institutions would—as I think you suggested in your speech in the second reading debate we were happy to let them do—shift the loads around so that full fee paying students would be in the most expensive courses and the government funded students would be squashed out of other courses. It is precisely because of the very sharp minds of the university sector when dollars come before them, and the focus they have on how to get those dollars, that we believe these limits need to be put in.

If I went and asked them whether they were satisfied with this, it would not surprise me if a number of them said, `No, why don't you make it 33 per cent or 50 per cent?' They would seek a lot more flexibility because giving them that flexibility allows them to obviously get more. That is what they are primarily interested in.

We said in the very beginning, on 9 August, that we want Australian students to have the opportunity to invest in themselves, to take that chance if they want, and that these conditions would be there. All you are looking at now is, if you like, a concession on our part. I think it has been properly raised that people say, `You might say that now, but you might say differently next year.' It is nothing more than an acknowledgment of the intention of the government that we seek to put those critical aspects into legislation. The rest of the guidelines will stay as the guidelines that were the same under your government. The guidelines of setting fees vis‐a‐vis postgraduate courses were not disallowed. I did not notice your complaining then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats are quite happy to complain about the guidelines that existed under the former Labor government.
—But you're always having a complain.

—We have to keep both of you accountable. I will resist the temptation to play Dorothy in this debate but, Minister, when you state that people like me are saying, `Ho, ho, you're going to come in here and change it for the worst,' let us look at the former government.

SPEECH.PARA: When it was talking about postgraduate fee paying guidelines, it did change them in 1992, 1993 and 1994. That is why we would seek some assurance that these guidelines are in legislation. I ask you, Minister, if you seek to enshrine the 25 per cent figure in legislation, why not also include a range of guidelines determining the conditions under which fees may be changed for undergraduate places?

TALK.START.PARA: —I must admit that I was one of the senators who asked that this figure of 25 per cent be included in the legislation. I was one of the senators who asked that the 25 per cent actually be placed in legislation, and it was not because I thought there was a wicked witch around. Who knows, in four or five years time there might be a wicked wizard around who might use the fact that it is not in legislation to put something in the guidelines, which at this stage are not disallowable.

BREAK.PARA: There was another way around the issue and that was to put a clause into the legislation to say that the guidelines would be disallowable. There would be so many things in the guidelines that I am not actually sure that this would be a proper—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight in the adjournment debate to discuss two quite disparate measures. The first is a concern raised with me by members of the Western Australian community regarding a remote Aboriginal community called Mulan in the Great Sandy Desert of Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had a number of representations concerning a decision by ATSIC to suspend CDEP funding for at least three months from 1 January 1997 in this community of Mulan. The concern raised with me is that, via this action, the community may face collapse. CDEP funds are used to provide the essential resources and infrastructure within the community of Mulan which, as I say, is an extremely isolated Aboriginal community some hours from Halls Creek.

The concern is that with the withdrawal of CDEP funds some of the essential services like power, water, sewerage and rubbish collection may break down and that no provision would exist for them to be repaired or maintained. The human consequence of such action is obvious to all. I have reports that the primary school is already being forced to help feed children at Mulan because of a mix‐up in the payment of CDEP funding in the last fortnight and that a number of families are without money that they had expected and are therefore experiencing extreme hardship.

BREAK.PARA: In addition, the wet season is approaching and communities like Mulan are often cut off from other centres as the roads become flooded at this time of the year. So there are real concerns about the future of the community at Mulan and it seems that the removal of CDEP funding puts at risk the essential functioning of this community of a couple of hundred people. As I understand it, over 100 of those people are receiving CDEP funding which is essential to the maintenance of that community.

I am sure ATSIC have their reasons for taking this action and I know they have a number of serious concerns about the administration of the community. From what I have read, that community has a chequered history. I do not doubt for one moment that ATSIC have some justification for the action they are taking. I have seen the correspondence they have sent to the community which outlines their concerns. They are very serious concerns which go to questions of violence, unauthorised expenditure and the failure of some young men to work in accordance with the CDEP guidelines. So they are obviously very real problems. ATSIC have seen fit, as a result of trying to resolve these problems, or having seen these problems in their view remain unresolved, to take the action to suspend CDEP funding.

I have some concern with that action because it seems that the suspension of CDEP funding in this community does nothing to help those people. It does nothing to advance the resolution of those problems in the community. I do not pretend to be an expert on those problems. I do not doubt for one moment that they have existed for some time and that they are deep‐seated difficulties. But what does the removal of CDEP funding do to assist these people to work through those problems? Nothing. What does it do to assist the people in this community survive in their very harsh environment in some of the most difficult circumstances one can imagine?

How does ATSIC's decision to suspend CDEP funding leave the community in finding the resources they need to manage their community, to administer the basic needs that I have spoken about, such as water, sewerage, rubbish collection et cetera? Clearly, without the CDEP funds there is a real danger that the infrastructure in the community will collapse and that the community itself might collapse, resulting in severe hardship to those people living in the community. They may be forced to leave the community. Some might think that a good thing—but it clearly is not a solution to the problems of this community.

We really have to address the needs of the young children, the old people and the others who actually live there. Those who are trying to survive and who need the support of the CDEP funding to ensure that the infrastructure and the basic services in that community are maintained. So today I wrote to ATSIC asking them to reconsider the decision to suspend the CDEP funding. I asked them to remove the suspension and allow all those of goodwill who can offer assistance to the community to try to work through what ATSIC believe are very serious problems.

I note that the 1996‐96 annual report of the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations provides a positive view of the progress of the Mulan Aboriginal Corporation and of achievements that the registrar was able to make during their period of involvement with the community. In fact, the major criticism in the report seems to be of the role of ATSIC within the community and in particular its relationship with the corporation. So if in 1996 we had the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations having some positive views about prospects at Mulan, the removal of CDEP funding now seems very drastic action indeed.

I have sought ATSIC's cooperation in seeking to find other solutions to their concerns, to work through with the community the real problems that exist in that community rather than merely remove funding that is essential to maintaining the basic services. Services that meet the basic needs of health, housing and infrastructure that these people at Mulan require. I would hope that, with the cooperation of ATSIC, we are able to do something positive to help this community address its problems, ensure that the community development that is at the centre of the CDEP program really occurs, make this community more self‐sufficient and improve the lifestyle for its people.

In the time left to me, I want to make a few remarks in paying tribute to David Ian Campese. David Campese is the great Australian rugby union winger who played his 101st and last test match for Australia at the Cardiff Arms Park ground in Wales last night. A Queanbeyan boy, David Campese has become a legend in the game of rugby union and, I think, in sport generally. It was fitting that he played his last test at Cardiff Arms Park, a ground I consider to be the finest rugby union ground in the world and home of the largest Welsh choir in the world. I have had the pleasure of seeing England beaten by Wales there, but was never selected to play there myself which is one of my great disappointments.

In the great victory over Wales, Campese played his last test, and he will be a tremendous loss to the game. Campese was a brilliant and elusive winger and full‐back, and scored 64 test tries for Australia. His goosestep has become his trademark and is known around the world. He is regarded by some of the greatest players as the greatest attacking player in rugby union history.

David Campese has brought great joy to spectators the world over. He has brought a great number of new converts to rugby and has helped transform the game into a much better attacking spectacle than the dour sport that I started playing as a very young man.

Campese has been somewhat of a controversial figure both for his public comments and also for the fact that he took risks in playing the game—some of which, of course, did not come off. Sometimes when things did not come off, Campese received a great deal of criticism in Australia. Perhaps he did not receive as much credit as he should have for the skills and the attributes that he brought to the game.

PARA.BREAK: His own unique style will be remembered by all rugby union followers and lovers of sport generally—even though at times we had our hearts in our mouths. David Campese has been a great credit to the game and to Australian rugby. I think it is a sign of his stand ing in the game that an old forward like me can speak so well of a winger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with those remarks about David Campese. I watched him this morning live at half past one and enjoyed every moment of the game, especially since the Wallabies did win.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I will be reflecting on an often elusive concept in politics, and that is on truth. Prime Minister Paul Keating's highly publicised promise not to raise taxes as l-a-w law generated enormous public criticism. Despite public debate and the use of Keating's broken promises in the Howard government's election campaign, no attempt has been made by this government to establish legislation which prohibits false, untrue or misleading government advertising.

WA state and Commonwealth legislation should parallel South Australian legislation, which has prohibited misleading political advertising since 1985. Paul Keating's government failed to pass similar legislation introduced by the Democrats in the Senate. Now John Howard is the beneficiary of that failure.

In 1995, the Senate passed amendments proposed by the Democrats, which were based on the South Australian legislation, in the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1995. This legislation was to contribute to better standards. However, the amendments were not accepted by the then ALP government in the House of Representatives and consequently were defeated.

South Australia is the only state where legislation requiring truth in political advertising is in place. Misleading political advertising has been prohibited in the Electoral Act since 1985. This legislation has been tested in the Full Court of the Supreme Court of South Australia, where it was held to be constitutionally valid and, further, that it did not impede the implied freedom of speech right in the Commonwealth constitution.

There is no good reason for governments to drag their feet on this issue. The legislation in South Australia is effective and has been held not to impede freedom of speech. There are however, a number of good reasons for governments to take action and implement similar legislation in the Commonwealth and states.

A politician's reputation is one of those reasons. Public opinion of politicians in Australia places them well below other professions—including lawyers—but just above used-car sales representatives. This is indicative of the mistrust that the electorate holds for politicians and their general reputation as dishonest and unaccountable. That is not a reputation that any of us in this chamber enjoys.

It is in our interests then to implement legislation which would not only serve to raise the debate among politicians at election time but which would improve the reputation of politicians. We need to pass legislation which will serve as a strong reminder to all politicians that false, untrue or misleading campaign advertising is not only unacceptable but would be illegal.

This issue is particularly relevant in my home state of Western Australian at this time. As you will be aware, the state election is set for 14 December. Government advertising and election promises have been flooding the media and the electorate is being pressured to make their choice. The electorate's choice between candidates, however, is hollow, unless it is based on adequate, accurate information. If the electorate is to rely on the politician's word, that word must be a representation of the truth and the politician must be held accountable if it is not.

Truth in political advertising has not been part of the grab bag of promises that Richard Court and his people—or Dr Gallop and his people—have been on about at this election. While many welcome the fact that the Court government have opened their books—and I welcome that fact—we must ask why they have not passed truth in advertising legislation and why they have not established a complementary charter of political honesty.

Premier Richard Court has had nearly four years to amend state legislation which the previous ALP government passed but did not proclaim and which was designed to regulate government advertising. The electorate must question why Mr Court went to the trouble to amend and proclaim other sections of that same act at the exclusion of sections on the issue of government advertising and government travel allowances.

Both the Commonwealth and Western Australian governments must follow the South Australian example and legislate for truth in political advertising. False, untrue and misleading electoral advertising must be made illegal. In this way, politicians may be held accountable for election promises designed to win over the electorate and which they know they cannot keep and will not keep.

The passing of legislation similar to that in South Australia would advance political standards, ensure accountability and promote fairness. If Mr Court and other politicians want to be taken seriously by the electorate, truth in government advertising legislation and other accountability measures must be implemented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to congratulate the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for honouring his commitment to the small business community. In his election campaign, he reached out to the small business community. They responded by getting behind the campaign and by actively campaigning and soliciting votes for the coalition.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week, Mr Howard made a submission to the ACCC honouring an election promise to give newsagents an exemption that would allow them to continue their zonal territory. In his submission, Mr Howard pointed out the significant public benefit that newsagents provide to the community. That was another promise honoured; another promise to the electorate that he has delivered on.

PARA.BREAK: I believe a government has the right to go to the community, to make election promises and, if it is elected, to honour the promises it made to the community. Today I am concerned because Professor Fels, the Chairman of the ACCC, has pointed out that even if the ACCC were to honour Mr Howard's commit ment to newsagents and give the exemption Mr Howard has asked for—I point out that Mr Howard is a very popularly elected Prime Minister with a huge mandate and an overwhelming number of seats to his advantage—he would have to take note of the Competition Tribunal. On the Competition Tribunal there is Mr Justice John Lockhart, Dr Barry Aldrich and Dr Maureen Brunt who in the early 1990s refused to back a Trade Practices Commission plan to authorise newsagents' home delivery monopolies.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the Senate, and to the Competition Tribunal, that, while they may have the power to technically override the Prime Minister, it would be a very dangerous thing to do. I believe the Senate would back up the notion that an elected government should have the right to deliver on its election commitments. This government has gone to the electorate with a mandate for small business. Last week the Prime Minister sent his submission to the ACCC only for Professor Fels to say, `Even if the ACCC were to give you that exemption, then you would have to run the gauntlet of the Competition Tribunal.'

The purpose for my rising to speak on this matter is to urge all those concerned in the ACCC, the NCC and the Competition Tribunal to stand aside and to allow an elected government and Prime Minister—elected with an overwhelming majority of seats—to deliver their mandate to the people. If they do take an opposite view to that, they will be running in the dead opposite direction to what the Prime Minister has offered small business.

I say to those people—to Professor Fels, to the chairman of the NCC and to the chairman of the Competition Tribunal: the people elected John Howard, they voted him in as Prime Minister and they voted him in to de‐

BREAK.PARA: liver on his policies. The people I have referred to are either non‐elected or non‐representative. They are people who have been put there by a government, whether this government or a previous government, to implement the government's overall strategy but not to interfere in their election commitments. I hope as this matter unfolds that these particular members of unelected bodies will take notice of what the Prime Minister has offered the small business community and say, `That is the wish and the will of the people who elected John Howard, and we take note of that.'

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 9 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What staff, other than staff employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984, were employed in or attached to the office(s) of the Minister and each of his or her Parliamentary Secretaries as at Tuesday, 8th October 1996.
(2) What were the total salary costs of such staff.
(3) What was the financial cost to the Commonwealth of the employment of such staff.
(4) What were the titles, roles and duties of such staff and what public service (or equivalent) classifications did they carry.
(5) Under what programs were they employed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As at 8 October 1996, there were three departmental liaison officers employed in Mr Downer's Office: two from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT), and one from AusAID. One liaison officer from AusAID was also employed in the office of the Parliamentary Secretary for Foreign Affairs, Mr Andrew Thomson .
(2) The annual salary costs for the above staff (based on salary figures as at 8 October) are $192,976.
(3) The cost to the Commonwealth of the above staff for the period 3 March 1996—8 October 1996, was $105,600.08.

(4) An Assistant DFAT Liaison Officer is employed in Mr Downer's office. He is an ASO1 officer acting in an ASO3 position. As well as assisting in liaison between the Minister's office and the Department, he is the systems administrator of the Department's secure communication network in the Minister's office, and responsible for logging Ministerial correspondence, submissions and briefs. He also assists with office administration.

The second DFAT Liaison Officer in Mr Downer's office, is acting in that position until a permanent officer is selected. She is a SOGC officer, and carries out liaison functions between the Minister's Office and DFAT and has responsibility for a range of foreign policy issues.

There are two AusAID Liaison Officers, one in the office of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (SOGB) and one in the office of the Parliamentary Secretary for Foreign Affairs (ASO6). The role of these officers is to provide a link between the Minister's or Parliamentary Secretary's Offices and AusAID on matters relating to the administration of the aid program. The AusAID Liaison Officer in Mr Downer's office also provides a link between that office and the Office of Pacific Island Affairs in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.
(5) The two DFAT liaison officers' positions are funded by DFAT under the Departmental Liaison Officer program. The salaries of the two AusAID officers are funded from AusAID's Running Costs Vote.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the President of the Senate, upon notice, on 20 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that much of the paper used in Parliament House is Reflex, and that wood used in its manufacture includes clearfelled native forests and rainforest species.
(2) Is any photocopy paper made from 100 per cent post‐consumer recycled paper and/or from plantation wood available for the use of members and senators in Parliament House.
(3) If no such paper is available, what steps will be taken to ensure that such paper is made available for the use of members and senators who are concerned about the future of our native forests.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However all paper purchased by the Department of the Senate is in accordance with the environmentally‐preferred paper policy of Purchasing Australia.

(3) The use of recycled paper and paperboard will increase as cost becomes more competitive and quality improves, particularly its compatibility with high speed printing and copying equipment. Despite claims to the contrary by paper suppliers and some equipment manufacturers, the use of recycled paper has frequently been found to be the cause of jams in offset presses, photocopiers and personal computer printers. Currently the department has in stock paper with a recycle rating of 80 per cent which is available for the use of senators. For cost reasons, it is provided on request only.
